description:
Shaanxi style cuisine in a casual setting. We've been craving Xian food and glad we stumbled upon this spot. Pork, lamb and noodle heavy menu. Mainly sour and spicy flavors... key ingredients in most of the menu are salt, vinegar, garlic, onion and spices. 

Here are the dishes we liked: pork rou jia mo (on menu as "original shaanxi style burger with pork"); Qishan spicy and sour pork noodles soup; three in one Biang-Biang noodles; mixed noodles with grounded pork; red oil wonton; lotus root with sweet and sour sauce.
author: Alex B.

description:
We used to love this place. 

When I said 'used', that means we will not go there in the future. 

Last week we just went there and was told they stopped serve their most popular dish : dapanji (大盘鸡）
And all other noodle tasted wayyyyyyy toooooo salty. This was our only place that we liked in San Francisco. They used to have the most delicious food......

Don't go there any more if you were their loyal customer. We used to be, not anymore.
author: Bin G.

description:
First time here! It's a medium size space can fit decent amount of people.
The place decoration is pretty good.

came here around 6 and the place is pretty full.

I am pretty sad they took out a lot of the stir fried menu they seem like it's pretty good


We ordered 
Beef bun - it's pretty good very flavorful 
Pork bun - it's good but the meat portion pretty small 

Garlic spicy pork slice - it's very good appetizer but it's a bit oily 

Shanxi stir fried with noodle and shredded pork. - it's a bit too salty for my liking and they don't give a lot of meat it's mainly the noodle (forgot to take photos) 

Overall I think it's a alright place cause the portion is decently big but the flavoring is just meh.

7.5/10 overall !
author: Sandy C.

description:
Terracotta Warriors' food can be variable depending on the day. We've had vastly different experiences in the couple times we've been. Overall, I'd highly recommend this place for noodle lovers or fans of Northern Chinese food.

Biang Biang cumin lamb noodles - we love cumin, lamb, and noodles, but this dish didn't come together. The amount of oily cumin on the noodles was overwhelming and the noodle-to-lamb ratio was too high. 

Cold Mian Pi - this was really refreshing. I wished they were more generous with the cucumbers in the dish

Spicy & sour pork noodle soup - this was just bad. Super overcooked noodles with a broth that was somehow bland and had too many things going on

Stir fried pork noodle - super oily, but was deliciously savory. Wouldn't get this dish for myself, but is great family style

Spicy beef noodle soup - much better than the spicy & sour pork noodle soup but not amazing. The beef was too thinly sliced

Cold spicy beef - a nice spicy starter to share. Small pieces packed a flavorful punch
author: Yuchen L.

description: Noodles, noodles, noodles, if you don't want anything else come here Bc this place gives you sooo many noodles you really won't know what to do with yourself. I'm not a huge fan so I'd prob pass on this place in the future. The noodle broth is tasty though.
author: Linda H.

description: Price is good and the decoration is nice. However, the food didn't meet my expectation. The food is a bit too oily.
author: Hanying H.

description:
When I initially visited Terra Cotta Warrior, it was flagged as a health risk.  My friend commented that it was the best time to go since they are always busy, the wait times can be long, and the health risk adds to the flavor of a typical Chinese restaurant ...WTF( well that's fantastic) Are you serious???

A brave group of us ignored the health risk and had an enjoyable dining experience.   Terra Cotta Warrior is located in outer sunset.  You can easily get there on the N-Judah.  They are known for their dishes from Shaanxi.

Since there was a group of us we each ordered a dish to share family style.  Some of the dishes we ordered were the cumin lamb and Chinese burger with pork, braised chicken, three in one biang biang noodles, celeries with dried bean curd sticks, and the fired bean past noodles.

Overall it was good food with great company.
author: Peter C.

description: Great service - pretty good food. Would come again. The wontons and cold dishes are the best. Not a huge fan of the sour noodles
author: Caleb W.

description:
Came here again recently and really liked the three styled pork biang biang noodles! It was quite spicy for someone that can't tolerate spicy food well, but I really liked it! It was bits of pork slices tossed in a tomato-based sauce - was very flavorful! Also fun because you get to mix your own food. Good textured noodles too! Also had the lamb burger, which was delicious too. Also recommend their cumin lamb noodles, very delicious! Sometimes I wonder how I survived in a restaurant with so much spicy food but I managed! They have these flavors that I would sometimes randomly crave.

Good ambiance, dim lighting, great decor. Pretty quick service because they're generally pretty busy, and there's always a couple people waiting for a table whenever I visit. Definitely would come back!
author: Sara T.

description:
I loved this place when I first checked it out last year. But dropped by for dinner today and the menu is different and the food was extremely salty. They primarily have cold appetizers, wontons, and noodles now. They removed most of the other dishes. 

I think I'll just need to make the drive to Milpitas and go to Xian Kitchen next time I'm craving Xian food.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Fairly authentic shaanxi/xi-an food! It is quite uncommon to find Chinese food outside of Szechuan, Cantonese, or Shanghai food so I was excited to find Northern Chinese food. I'm from Northern China so my infatuation with noodles is deeply rooted in this region's cuisine. The taste is pretty good and the portion sizes are decent. The service is aite, pretty average for a Chinese restaurant, they'll come when you call them but they won't really check up on you. The price is average not a fabulous deal but pretty filling for the money. 

It was just a bit strange when we asked for ice water and they handed us regular water and when we asked for ice again they took the cup back and brought the exact same thing back. Also they did not have pickled garlic for their "pita soaked in lamb soup" even though the photo showed it.

The "Mian Pi", Big plate chicken, shaanxi stir fried hand pulled noodles were especially delicious and a must try if you come to this restaurant. 

Overall my cravings are satisfied but I am not overly amazed or super impressed.
author: Ellen G.

description:
I heard of this place from Eater and decided to give it a try since I love Xi'an food. I came with a group of 3 and our overall experience at this place was OKAY. It was not as amazing as we thought would be. There are definitely much better Xi'an restaurants in the south bay. 

Items we ordered:
Celeries with dried bean curd sticks (1/5): Probably the worst dish out of all we ordered. The dried bean curd tasted like plastic/rubber and very hard to chew. The dish itself was more on the bland side.

Garlic taste pig's ear (4/5): We really liked this dish. It was pretty flavorful and the pig's ear was cooked well. I liked that the dish has a significant portion of marinated cucumber to go with the pig's ear.

Pita bread soaked in lamb soup (3/5): The soup smelled super lamby but the items in the soup were actually not as lamby as we expected. The only thing really frustrated us was the large amount of pita bread. Soon after we got the soup, the pita bread had soaked up all the broth. We tried to ask for more soup, but the waitress told us it would be additional $3 for the soup. WTH...

Three-In-One Pork Biangbiang noodles (4/5): This noodle dish was pretty good. I really liked the scrambled eggs and the braised pork belly. The noodles were hand-cut so super thick and chewy. If I ever come back to this place, I would order this dish again.

Spicy beef noodle soup (3.5/5): The overall flavor was not bad but we did not expect the noodles to be this thick--they were close to Udon noodles. All the beef noodles I have had so far use thin noodles so I was not used to the thick noodles from Terra Cotta. I wouldn't order this dish again.
author: Clare L.

description:
I am from xi'an, grew up there for nearly a decade and go back regularly, I'd say that I can make a fair assessment on terra cotta warrior. 

The quality has gone down, a lot. This is a common trend among a lot of Chinese restaurants - when business picks up, they become greedy, and try to "cheat" with either quality or quantity for more profits. While I agree the food here is good, it's really not amazing or super representative of what you can get in Xi'an. And I get it, most of you will never go to Xi'an and have the real deal, which is why I'm even more bummed that you aren't getting the real deal here. 

The last time I was here, the cold noodles (liang pi) was fine, but the big plate chicken dish was not great. The potatoes were undercooked, they used jalapeños, and I think they gave us the small dish even though we ordered the big one - I felt cheated. The pita in lamb soup was just completely off - we don't incorporate celery in the soup, we add way more lamb.... 

You'll have a great meal here, no doubt. But I hope the owners will demonstrate more integrity and represent xi'an cuisine more accurately, please!
author: Dana Z.

description:
This is definitely the place for you if you are a huge fan of lamb! I'm not... so this place was just okay for me, but my parents loved this place!

My parents really enjoyed the lamb noodle soups. My dad ordered the pita bread in lamb soup which came with glass noodles, and my mom ordered the regular lamb noodle soup with knife cut noodles. We were quite curious about 'pita bread' in lamb soup. In reality, it is just little dough balls cooked in the soup to a nice chewy bite, but before seeing/tasting it, I definitely thought it was strange that they would serve a soup with wet soggy pita bread in it.

I ordered the noodles in sizzling oil. It was actually quite bland, I think because I asked for it to be less spicy. I ended up spooning some of the liquids from our sauteed veggies over the noodles which made them a little more palatable, but just barely. If you order the noodles, I'd definitely recommending getting them as is, not less spicy. 

We also tried the chinese burger with pork, which my mom really liked but I thought was just okay. There meat to bun ratio was great, but I actually found the pork a tad dry.

Terra Cotta Warrior was a hit with the parents. They have already requested a re-visit the next time they are in town. Next time, I will probably order a variety of different things, and hopefully I can update my review to something more positive!
author: Sherry L.

description:
They had just opened about 20 minutes ago and there were already only a few tables available. My family and I had been craving some good noodles and I had heard about this place from my cousins.

We ordered 5 noodle dishes, the mapo tofu, and a pork burger to share. The pork burger was alright. I liked the bread better than the pork. The mapo tofu was really good and the tofu was very soft. The sauce did remind me of instant noodles spice, but I like that. 

On to the noodles. We ordered the biang biang noodles 2, minced pork noodles, pickled soup noodles, regular wonton soup, and clear noodles with beef. The minched pork noodles was my favorite. I didn't eat more of it at dinner so I could have it as leftovers for lunch the next day. The biang biang noodles were good, but next time I want to try it with the lamb and beef. Wonton soup was like how wonton soup should be. The pickled soup noodles were my least favorite. My mother likes that so she ordered it. The soup just had too much vinegar for my taste. If you like vinegar, you might like this dish. My brother ate the clear noodles with beef. The beef can get stuck in your teeth, so have some floss handy. 

Overall, I would definitely come back to try some other hand pulled noodle dishes and get the minced pork noodles again.
author: Allyson L.

description:
This place has pretty great noodles, and it's a shame that I didn't learn about this place before since I used to live very close to here for quite some time. 

Spicy Noodle Soup - 5/5. This had a nice sweet/sour taste that I haven't really found in other noodle places around here. The hand-pulled noodles had great chewy texture and worked well with the soup.
author: Nevin L.

description:
Place is still really good. I wish they had liang pi, but the cold noodles they have are still very good. 

Got the szechuan mian pi, shanxi mian pi, cumin lamb, combo biang biang mian, pita bread soaked lamb soup, and couples delight.

The couples delight was a generous serving, but just had one cut of beef and didn't have nuts, cilantro or anything else really. So I'd pass on getting that again.

Both mian pi's are really good. I thought that the szechuan one was a bit better since it had more flavor and that spicy flavor was closer to liang pi (which is what I really like). I wished they also used gluten pieces and seems like they just did bread.

The cumin lamb was kind of what you expected. Cumin flavor with onions.

The biang biang noodles I thought was really good too. However, I wouldn't advise getting a triple (especially not to share with a bunch of people). I'd just stick to one (probably just the spicy one). The third with meat actually didn't have much flavor I thought, and the tomato one was good, but I can see me getting tired of eating a bowl of that.

The lamb soup was pretty wholesome and is great if you just want some warm soup. The pita pieces seem to really soak up the soup and I wish there was more soup.

Be ready for long lines, we waited 30 minutes for party of 4.
author: Victor D.

description:
TERRA COTTA WARRIOR SHAME ON YOU

Let me preface, I have been an outrageously loyal customer to terra cotta because of my love of their Noodles in Sizzling oil. I have been coming here for years and have dealt with new ownership, microwaved noodles (when they should have been fresh), and now for the second time, driving all the way across the city to find out you are closed for a vacation. 

PUT IT ON YELP IF YOU ARE GOING TO BE CLOSED UNTIL JULY 5th!! It isn't hard, I will show you July 6th when I come in. This is the second time in the last two years that I have come and you are closed and mentioned NOTHING on yelp. 

I will be honest. My party of four were so disappointed as were the other five couples that showed up as we searched for some other option. Losing a lot of business. You are the only restaurant I know that goes on "summer vacation"... I know it's the dragon boat festivals but hire an alternate crew! 

Terra cotta, I love you and your noodles, but please let your customers know if you are going to be closed (in this case for almost 6 weeks) on yelp!! You will prevent a ton of frustrated customers. 


SHAPE UP!!
author: Lily A.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. The cuisine is west northern China so expect lots of spices as ingredients. On the menu you will recognize familiar Chinese dishes from anywhere but the taste is slightly different here, almost fusiony. Having said that many items are on the spicy side be it a hot or cold dish or something that does not appear spicy.

I'm not crazy for lamb but their lamb cumin was terrific. The dumplings are good but are better with the side dipping sauce. Get the hot and sour pork dumpling soup though which is as good as it sounds. The scallion oil ginger chicken is good too. If like fried rice the Shanxi fried rice is good if a bit heavy on the black bean sauce.

The noodle soups uses thicker noodles so it's harder to eat. They will cut the noodles to shorter length at your table. If not, just request it or else it could get messy. Tea and water are provided but I do prefer Tsing Tao beer with the food, which I've tried half of the menu so still have a ways to go!

Note reservations are not taken so plan ahead if have a group. The wait time is not atrocious probably due to the Outer Sunset location and parking is reasonable. It's easier to get in at lunch than dinner of course.
author: Peter L.

description: This place is criminally underrated! Wonderful hospitality (our teapots were replaced as soon as they were less than half full), chewy, fresh, hand-pulled noodles (black bean, pork, and my favorite - the lamb cumin), and quick service. We can't wait to come back!
author: Maria S.

description: Bomb main-pi (so flavorful and fresh) and noodle dishes! Tried the triple Biang biang noodles and the veggie noodles and both were delicious. The noodles are so fresh and the pork was chewy and delicious. Will definitely come back to try more dishes!
author: Sarah S.

description: A new cuisine for me; I really enjoyed discovering Shaanxi/Xi'an dishes! Nice staff, attentive service and tasty dishes.
author: Susan B.

foodkid fAAtcity
author: Ringo M.

description: WOW THIS PLACE IS AMAZING. Their hand pulled noodles are some of the best I've ever had in this city. The wait on a weekend evening wasn't too bad- 20 min. The noodle soups here are so good. We got one that tasted like hot and sour soup, it was delicious. Definitely coming back here
author: Amanda F.

description:
Terra Cotta warrior is a true gem. I lived in China/taiwan for several years, and let me tell you that you can't find this kind of Chinese food easily. I live out in the Sunset district of SF (pretty quiet and removed from the center of the city) and discovered this place right near my house when I saw a line of people waiting out the door on a random weekday night. I saw it was Chinese food and had to try it. 

Whether it's the sesame mian pi, cabbage, beef burger, lamb pita soup, vegetarian sizzling oil noodles, you can't go wrong. They handmake the thick noodles every day, so going closer to when they open is better (you can tell the difference in the freshness of the noodles). 

I've probably eaten there two dozen times. It's unthinkable that they have 3.5 stars in my opinion, though I will say that they could easily step it up, move to the center of the city and make a killing if they wanted. 

Also very nice staff.
author: Mateo K.

description:
TBH haven't been here in a few years (before all their initial hype). And I LUVV this type of food. The reason for my non return was bc their seafood/veggie options were extremely limited!

However, after today's visit, it looks like their menu has greatly expanded since my first visit. Cheers for that! The waitress was quick to come over and take our order. Never really a tough time to get their attn like a typical Chinese restaurant. 

As for what we order, the buds got a hand pulled noodle dish with beef. I ordered the seafood/veggie dishes, which included the shanxi fish (excellent silky fish atop mung beans, seaweed, and tofu), tofu with preserved eggs (the cold tofu wasn't my fav and neither was the egg...and not bc I don't like preserved eggs bc I do...it just didn't have the pungent flavor you actually want in this case), and mian pi noodle with peanut sauce (barely noticeable peanut sauce flavor). 

Initially we thought we under-ordered til the food came. And boy did the food shoot out! And it was 12pm on a Sunday (was raining out tho, so crowds were thinner). Overall, I'd consider coming back in the future, but to try diff dishes. Would 100% return for the fish dish alone! 4 stars
author: Jennifer L.

description: Had the chinese donuts with beef, beef lung in spicy oil, cold noodle and noodle with pita bread in lamb broth.. super good!
author: Dira M.

description:
My family and I really love shanxi food, especially since my dad grew up with it, and we always enjoy our visits to Terra Cotta Warrior. The parking is somewhat difficult and the wait can be terrible sometimes, but otherwise, this place is a great place for comfort food and noodles.

Every time I come here, I always order the liang pi! The noodles are super chewy and soft, and soaked in just the right amount of vinegar and hot oil. I also order the biang biang noodles, and I opted for the cumin lamb biang biang noodles, which tasted like stir fried belt noodles with savory cumin lamb. I really enjoyed the fragrant cumin, paired with the very spicy jalapeños and onions. It gets super spicy after a few bites, but it's also super addicting. My dad ordered the seared oil biang biang noodles and my mom ordered the mount qui spicy noodle soup; they both like it a lot. My dad even mentioned that this is place is pretty authentic to what he's used to from when he was younger.

The prices aren't too bad, and you will definitely leave full and super content. I definitely recommend a trip!
author: Sandra S.

description: The vegetarian pulled noodle thing is bomb, don't leave this place without ordering one! Put as much chili oil in it as you can!
author: Cinry L.

description: Delicious noodles and very good Chinese burger. I enjoyed the decor of the restaurant. I will try the other items on the menu next time .
author: Juan V.

description: Multiple friends recommended this place since we started searching for a favorite spicy food place. We came here for Chinese New Year. The portions were huge! We got 4 dishes and the take home lasted us 2 days... All the dishes were amazing. The spiciness is on point. Xi'an cuisine heavily involves noodles and lamb so definitely try some of those dishes here. The location is convenient, right off the N line.
author: Iris H.

description: Good amount of vegan options like shaanxi mian-pi (their best dish, with hand pulled noodles), vegetarian noodles with sizzling oil, vegetarian chinese burger, and gluten with bean sprouts. The noodles with black bean paste are vegan if ordered without egg, but come with way too much sauce.
author: W T.

description:
Legit Xian style food. I love this place. The Xian flavors of black vinegar, hot chili oil, szechuan peppercorn/flowers, and other spices are well represented. I love the cumin lamb flavors, so earthy yet the perfect level of spiciness. All the noodles are the perfect chewy texture from the gluten activation aka beating the shit out of the dough. 

The service was good, especially for a chinese/asian business. Clean restaurant as well. I hope this place continues to do well because whenever I'm out in the sunset I will definitely be hitting up the Terra Cotta Warrior!
author: Toby F.

description:
Amazing noodles! My grandma is from the Shaanxi area of China and makes the most amazing hand-pulled noodles, so when I say these noodles were really well pulled, I mean it! 

[Lunch]
I came with a friend and ordered the Minced Pork Soup and the Biang Biang Noodles with Lamb. I wasn't a huge fan of the Hot and Sour soup base for the Minced Pork Soup - the noodles really saved the dish here. I wish I had tried one of the other soup broths, the combination of egg and the hot and sour, and the potato was a little off for me. I really loved the cumin lamb and the Biang Biang noodles. The meat was pretty good quality for a Chinese restaurant and the spice was not overwhelming. The noodles also were not super oily. Highly recommend giving this a try!

[Service / Decor]
I really appreciate that they put a lot of effort into making the restaurant look nice and pleasant. Other restaurants in this taste category (House of Pancakes) don't have the same decor efforts. They're also well staffed and the service is a lot more attentive than I'm used too. Definitely will be back to try more of the menu whenever I'm out in Sunset.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Too bad I can't go lower than 1 star! 
First off, whatever you do don't let them seat you near the door! They will forget all about you! Did it to me and the ppl next to us. Sat there for apx 15min before I was fed up seeing 3 employees just standing there doing nothing, which I had to flag them down eventually. 
After that I've ordered 2 soup noodle bowls and 2 appetizers. When orders came out I only got 1 soup bowl and 2 appetizers. Waited 10min for mines and nothing? Flagged the lady down and asked where my is my other soup bowl? I told her I ordered clear noodle with beef, came back 7 min later with thick pulled noodles and 2 slices of beef which also tasted bland! Didnt want to deal with it so I just ate it. Terrible! Not even a sorry? Will never come back and will tell everyone.
author: Zoomer M.

description: Great Xi'an Northern-style Chinese food. Traditionally, in N China noodles were eaten more commonly than rice, as well as the lamb and cumin mixing Asian and Mid-Eastern flavors. The pita in the lamb soup has a delicious unexpected flavor and texture. They are most famous for their Mian Pi noodles and their Lamb burgers are full of soft, juicy, flavorful lamb, among our favorite dishes! The Pork hand pulled cold noodle dishes are light and refreshing. Service was fine for us, I know some people dining here seemed to have complaints about it, but we didn't have any trouble - mainly because we could order in broken Chinese. This place is perfect for adventurous taste buds looking to embrace more flavors, not for the average person. Nicely decorated. I've been here twice and loved dining here every time!
author: Karen T.

description:
The food here is NOT your typical southern Cantonese food, but rather, Shaanxi/Xi'an style. It's great to try a different type of Chinese food in SF! Think hand-pulled noodles in chili oil, lamb burgers, etc. 

Food:
Honestly every dish we ordered here was terrific! I would recommend coming with at least 4 people so you can try multiple things. I ranked them from most favorite to least, but everything was a HIT. 

-Guangzhou Hot Spicy Noodles - I think this is their signature dish. Noodles were super chewy, and I loved the hot spicy soup it was soaking in! Yes it was spicy, but just medium spice. A MUST!!!

-Mapo Tofu - Wow, this is another must. I had never tasted mapo tofu like this before. I think this is how it's supposed to taste - tofu was super soft (but not silken), and firm enough to make it to your plate. The SAUCE was INCREDIBLE! It had the perfect amount of chili oil and spice. There was so much flavor - now I want to find the recipe so I can make it for myself. This was a hit, and great for vegetarians too.

-Cumin Lamb Burger - I usually hate lamb, but this was excellent. They put a LOT of cumin with the lamb, and it made this really great flavor once again! Our friend usually hates cumin, but also enjoyed this dish - the cumin was not too empowering. It was also big enough to share among 4 people, btw, and I'd recommend just getting the one since it can be sliced into 4, easily shared, and you get to try it without being full. 

-Stir-Fried Lamb with Pita Bread Soaked in Lamb Soup - I've never had anything like this before! I loved the lamb broth. I also really loved how the pita bread was soaked up in the soup - it tasted soft and chewy, just like their noodles in a way, but little bite size pieces. Great if you're craving soup.

-Shaanxi Mian Pi with sesame sauce - this was a smaller dish, more of an appetizer. It comes cold, so refreshing on a hot day. Loved the noodles - so chewy once again, and also the sesame peanut sauce was unique to this Shaanxi cuisine.

-Shaanxi Stir-Fried Wide Noodles - This was a tomato based noodle dish, with sweet flavors. This was a nice contrast to the spicy, thin noodles present in other dishes. The noodles were so wide - YUM! This was a very comforting dish, not very complex. Great as a leftover too.

-Shaanxi Fried Rice Spicy - this was a great dish too! It did remind me most of regular Chinese cuisine though, so if you want to be more adventurous, I guess you can skip this one. However if you are a fried rice lover, just get it!

Service:
Nonexistent here, but I'm not surprised. Just laying the cards on the table. When they called our name to be seated, instead of showing us to our table, they literally said, "You sit over there" and pointed lol. When we were finished eating (only had been seated 1 hour for 4 people), they said, "we've got a long line and we're only open for another hour" implying that we needed to get the hell out of there. For the check, we gave 2 credit cards. They left our table with our bill, came back 5 mins later saying "is this your credit card?" and we were super confused. I guess they confused our check with another table, and charged the entire bill on 1 of our credit cards! I won't dock on their rating because all Chinese restaurants are similar in some way shape or form.

Verdict:
Food overall is excellent, and also very cheap. For 4 people, I think the total was around $100, with leftovers for 2 extra meals! Service is awful, but there's no way around it. Also, a tip - get there when it opens, because we had to wait at least 30 mins for our table on a Sunday night. THIS PLACE IS WORTH THE VISIT! FYI it's closed until Aug 5, 2017 for their vacation, unfortunately. Can't wait for them to reopen.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Dinner here may be a 20+ min wait, but come with one other person, and you won't be waiting forever for some yummy Chinese food.

We were going to watch the sunset at Ocean Beach, and came to Terra Cotta for dinner seeing all of its wonderful reviews. I was feeling some noodles, and the boy just wanted something warm.

Upon being seated, we were served hot tea (YAS the barley kind) and given menus that are both in Chinese and English. The items aren't very descriptive, and I don't usually eat Xi'An type of Chinese food unless I'm with my parents since they know what to order...so we did our best. We started with the silky tofu and 1000-year-old-century-egg because he's never had "black eggs" before. He got the biang biang noodles which are one of their specialties...lamb and cumin. The noodles are my favorite type--thick, chewy, and perfectly cut. I had the vegetarian chili oil noodles, which were made with udon-style noodles but still delicious. Even though the noodles are drenched in a chili oil soupy form, it wasn't as spicy as the biang biang, the boo said. I enjoyed the flavor and ate THE WHOLE THING.

We both wished for more veggies in all of the dishes. There were a few veggie options, but this type of Chinese cuisine is known for being meat-heavy and spicy. We expected that going in, but I'm glad at least there were a few meatless options. The service is fast and no fuss, not very polite, but what do you expect. When you walk in, put your name down on their sign-in sheet, and patiently wait your turn. You can also buy take-out, which we saw some people do because the lines did seem to be crazy long even after we finished dinner after 8PM. 

A great local Chinese spot in the area, noodles are cooked to that QQ perfection.
author: Jodi H.

description:
Tucked away in the less hip part of town where suburbanites reside and foot traffic is less frequent, Terra Cotta Warrior is actually a surprisingly hip and high quality restaurant.

While style often trumps taste in many SF eateries, it's not the case for Terra Cotta warrior whose decor simply complements the delicious food it offers. 

It is not only an eye catching, tastefully designed restaurant on the inside, but it also offers an array of unique and delicious local xi'an specialities. 

Xi'an cuisine is a subset of Chinese cuisine that's less well known to most Americans. Since Xi'an was historically an important trade center during the Silk Road days, its food has a lot of Islamic influences hence, the heavy use of beef and lamb in the dishes. 

Some of the Xi'an specialities featured here include roujiamuo or Chinese style pita bread stuffed with meat, biang biang noodles, and da pang ji (literally translated as big plate chicken) Most of the noodles come with the option of being served with lamb. 

We tried all the specialties except da pang ji (big plate chicken) because they were already out by the time we ordered. Everything else we tried however was good. I'd recommend the ruojiamuo, thinly sliced pork and garlic side dish and the very refreshing spinach and garlic side dish. (It's super refreshing!)

Many of the dishes skew heavily towards noodles and bread so beware if you were expecting the typical Chinese restaurant fare. Also they have many delicious vegetarian options. My friend got the vegetarian ruojiamuo substituted with tofu and bean sprouts and she found it delicious.

Definitely give this a try if you would like to explore a different and delicious side of Chinese cuisine!
author: Sherica L.

description: I'm honestly surprised that I forgot to review this place, given I've been here quite a few times already. This is a restaurant specialize in Xi'an style food. To be completely honest, a couple of my friends have complained that the food is not spicy enough. But being someone who can't eat too spicy of food (I guess I should be ashamed given I'm from Beijing), I love the noodles here! My favorites here are the minced pork noodle and the tomato/egg noodles. Both are must-get whenever I'm here. I don't know if I would give it as high of a rating if I compare it noodles from other cities. But alas I can't just travel to LA or NY on demand :P Thus 5/5 for noodle places in SF. Within the city, it is one of my favorite (if not THE favorite) noodle places.
author: Sharon L.

description: Xi'an food is a recent discovery for me. Xi'an Kitchen in Milpitas was my first foray and is A+ excellent. Terra Cotta Warrior is solid, I would return, but it's not up to that standard. The lamb pita soup is the best dish on the menu although it could use more meat. The burgers/sandwiches are prepared with dry bread as opposed to being pressed/cooked. And, the noodle dishes could use more flavor.
author: Andrew G.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! Late Saturday lunch wasn't too busy. Everything is great but cold noodles are the best.
author: Eric N.

description:
Food was good; service kind of meh. Overall a pleasant experience though.

I guess this is Xi'an-style, like Xi'an Famous Foods in NYC that I've seen mentioned a few times. The quality is pretty similar to the NY spot (which is arguably the best in that region as well).

The menu is broken down into hot dishes, cold dishes, specials, and such. We ordered the three in one biangbiang noodles (noodles with sizzling oil, egg with tomato gravy, and pork) as well as the cumin lamb burger, and shaanxi mian-pi (a cold noodle dish). For two people, that was tons of food and all were really tasty. The cumin lamb burger was almost exactly like the one at Xi'an famous foods. My favorite was probably the shaanxi mian-pi which had a really nice garlic oil that complimented the noodles perfectly.

The location is pretty sweet because there are tons of boba places around (walkable?) for dessert, which is what we opted for though the restaurant does have a couple options for sweets. Parking is all on the street but pretty available even at dinnertime on a weeknight.
author: Shannon H.

description:
You guys. YOU GUYS. We found handpulled noodles just like Xian famous foods in NY!!!!!! You have no idea how much it's killing me to give this place four instead of five stars. But it's ok, I'm certainly going to be back here because the food is UHMAZING, and they will fix their service, and I will update this to five stars. I believe in this place! 

Terra Cotta Warriors is one of the nicer Chinese restaurants in SF. We had to wait about 20-30 mins to get a table when we got there at ~1pm. I really like the interior of this restaurant. They have cool paintings related to the tetra cotta theme of the restaurant as well pictures of the food! I really enjoy pictures of food on the wall when it comes to ethnic restaurants. They are very well know for certain items so I always like to try the popular things first. We ordered the lamb cumin noodles, and it TO DIE FOR. Perfectly silky, slippery, chewy noodles and thinly sliced lamb are laced in this delectably oily, cumin-y sauce that makes your taste buds dance. There's also some onions and green onions to balance the dish out nicely and provides some crunch. I could write about this dish for days *dreams about being at Terra cotta warrior right now*.

The reason this place can't get five stars is because we ordered a second dish that didn't come forever. Table after table around us got more and more dishes and my order never came. When I finally asked about 30 or so minutes later, she apologized and brought out our second order which was a cold noodle dish with cucumber, minced pork and black bean sauce. It really didn't help that this dish was just okay compared to the lamb cumin noodle. 

I am hopeful that when I go back to eat lots and lots more of cumin lamb noodles their service will be great and we can all forget about that one little slip-up :)
author: Debika M.

description: Delicious！Im a fan of sheep dishes. Very satisfied about my order today. Definitely will come again
author: Ying C.

description: Loved the sizzling noodles, chewy and delicious. Cumin lamb burger the best with crispy bun.
author: Carla A.

description:
This place is pretty yummy! I'm not sure if I ordered the right stuff but I was super excited to finally check it out since the pictures looked so promising. 

I came here with a friend for a belated birthday lunch. First impression: place is staffed with two waiters and can fit probably 40 people? 

I had to get the spicy oil noodles and the lotus root because it looked so good in the pictures. My friend got the cumin lamb burger and we also got the mian pi noodles. 

Spicy oil noodles- I really liked the texture of the noodles but this dish wasn't flavored extremely well. I had to pair the sweet and sour lotus root with every bite. 
Lotus root- very refreshing, get this! 
Cumin lamb burger-meh
Main pi noodles- covered in spicy oil and what tasted like peanut butter. Not a fan 

Overall, service was good but the food was just ok. I will be back to try other things on their menu since I feel like I might've ordered the wrong stuff.  Also, the tea they serve is warm and not really hot. I love my tea hot so this was another thing to note.
author: Shelly W.

description:
I love noodles, so already this place sounds great. I went with two friends and we got to the restaurant around 10 minutes after it opened and only had to wait a few minutes to get seated. However, when it came time to order, our server told us that we should order everything we wanted and not order any more afterwards, since they were busy (and I suppose they didn't want us sticking around for too long eating).

I tried the following dishes:
1. Shanxi mianpi - 5/5 delicious, and I'll get this probably every time I come back. The flavor of the chili oil is just amazing and the cucumbers make the dish taste very fresh. There is some bread on top perhaps to soak up the oil and I was skeptical, but it turned out being a decent addition to the dish though not necessary.
2. Stir-fried lamb with cumin - 4/5 delicious, and I'd be happy to eat this dish again but also willing to replace it to try something new. I wasn't too much of a fan of the ginger pieces in it, but it still tasted great. The lamb was tender and the portion provided was reasonably substantial.
3. Sweet fermented glutinous rice with dumpling ball - 3/5 reminds me of home cooking, but the soup was a bit gooier than I've had before. I did like the dumpling balls, which had black sesame in them.

Overall, the noodles at this place are just excellent. I love how thick they are. Will definitely want to come back.
author: Livvie L.

description: I used to love going to eat at Terra Cotta Warrior. It has some great food, but I went recently and they removed a lot of their vegetarian friendly hot dishes. Also, we found a bug in one of our dishes. I'm not sure if it was just an off dish, or if the restaurant needs to reevaluate its cleanliness. Service has also been poor the past couple times I've gone. We either had to ask another nearby waiter for anything we needed. I'm sad because the first time I went I really enjoyed the food there and loved bringing visitors there, but I'm not sure I'll go anymore because of how my past couple times have gone.
author: Opal P.

description:
Came back and had the - 
Noodles with Sizzling Oil, $9.95

(I asked for extra spicy!)

The noodles are not in a broth, but they come slathered in spicy hot chili oil...! 

This topped the dish that I had previously. 

Remember to set expectations according to service. The food is interesting and good here.
author: Jimmy L.

description: Very authentic Western North Chinese food. Their Yo-po noodle is my favorite. Don't know why they name the restaurant like this though, seems unrelated to me lol
author: Jacky C.

description: very good value. Food is somewhat authentic, and it's not too crowded. I would recommend the pita bread soaked in the lamb soup. It's good and comfortable.
author: Lotus A.

description:
I am not sure whether it's authentic Shanxi food, but I absolutely love it! Absolutely everything we ordered. I had a lamb Chinese burger, sizzling noodles, and some 3-1 biangbiang noodles from my friend's dish. The waitress said that they are going to close one month for summer rest, and I'm glad to hear that -- or I may have to travel 1 hour everyday to get a bowl of noodles there!

Must go list!
author: Diana Y.

description:
Yum. Everything we ordered was good. I recommend ordering the pickled cucumbers or other pickled things to quell any extreme spiciness you're bound to feel.

The spicy fish soup was my favorite. Unfortunately, the menu is not very descriptive for English readers. You kinda just have to order stuff on a whim if you're not familiar with Shaanxi or Qin cuisine (from northwestern China).

I was delighted to see all the pork and lamb dishes. The food is very savory - salty, spicy, and balanced with vinegar notes. You can't miss with ordering any of the noodle dishes, especially the biang biang noodles.

The water glasses are too small. We were waiting uncomfortably for the server to refill the glasses which they did not do often enough. The servers could be friendlier for sure.

The wait was kind of long. Expect to wait outside in the cold or be crammed in the small area in the front of the restaurant if you go around prime dinnertime.
author: Thien H.

description:
i have to say since moving to the Bay Area, I've only had westernized chinese food, but this place is legit. When we sat down and looked at the menu we didn't even know what half the items were! The majority of the items were in chinese so we had to order by looking at the pictures and asking our servers lots of questions. Luckily our server was very friendly and patient.

We ordered a total of 3 dishes. We got the Biangbiang noodles with cumin lamb, lamb dumplings and the fried rice with chives & eggs. The Biangbiang noodles were hand made in the restaurant. Each noodle was extremely long so it was a bit of a challenge to eat. You can definitely eat this without any sauce as it is well seasoned. The lamb dumplings was a new experience as I never had lamb dumplings before. Fresh and packed with nothing but the lamb meat/paste inside. Fried rice dish was also good! A bit salty but the saltiness complimented the savoriness of the dish well.

Note that the dishes here are relatively oily, which is common in authentic chinese cuisine. Also note that this place is extremely busy! We came at 5:30 pm (the time it opens) and by 5:40 there was already a line outside.
author: Galen W.

description:
If you don't like spicy food, this is not the place for you. They are very limited dishes that are non-spicy.  We ordered the "Chinese hamburger" and I must say that although it was a recommended dish, I was disappointed. The meat inside resembled pulled pork but it was a little bit dry for my taste. The bun was crispy but again because the pork was dry and made the entire hamburger very dry.

I also ordered beef noodle soup. This was alright. The broth was tasty and the noodles was thick but springy and handmade, which is what they pride themselves on. 

Overall, it's just an okay place. Tried it once and won't be itching to go back anytime soon.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Terra Cotta Warrior features northern Chinese cuisine of Shaanxi province in China. As someone who comes from that region, I can wholeheartedly say this place is as authentic as it gets. In fact, the owners/chefs are all locals from the province last time I checked. 

In this region, we eat more noodles than rice, which is why most of the dishes on the specialty menu are noodle-related. I try to order things off of the specialty part of the menu only. This is because 1) northern Chinese cuisine is very hard to find in the U.S. and 2) IMO their regular Chinese food isn't that impressive.

If you are a first timer, I recommend Cumin Lamb Burger, Shanxi Mianpi, Lamb Soup w/ Pita Bread, and Sizzling Oil Noodles. I know, it's a lot, but you won't regret it. I have taken a lot of friends to this place, and this trial tasting menu has never failed me. It's super cheap too compare to other dinner spots, usually less than $20 per person with tax/tip included. They usually have a long line out of the door, so try to come before 6:30pm or after 8:30pm. And unfortunately for larger groups, you will have to wait longer (up to an hour). 

I really wish I lived in the Sunset area so I could come here more often. If you want to experience different Chinese food styles, make sure you hit this one up!
author: Angel C.

description:
Why do I love San Francisco restaurants  let me count the ways! 

Terra Cotta Warrior is my find of the yearly  pilgrimage! Counting the ways... this is not just Chinese food, this is cuisine from the Shanxi Province and it was amazing! Ordering lamb in a Chinese restaurant seemed so strange and now I know it is oh so right!

We were meeting a friend of a friend who happened to be from the same province and she took us on a culinary tour that I will never forget, and I will be back before I return home. 

We ordered the stir fried lamb with cumin. It  was tender, and thinly sliced with red pepper oil and onions and it was incredible. I am still in a dream like state thinking of this dish, it was such a unique combination and was my favorite. 

Also ordered  were the hand pulled noodles with lamb, the noodles were infused is the gravy and were a little tricky to pull up with chopsticks so our guide showed us the way and I posted a video!

 I wish I would have taken a photo of the menu because I can't remember the names, we had cold wide noodles in chili oil and sesame oil oh so good!

Fang told us about the artwork on the wall with the drawings and they depict life in the province. If you watch National Geographic and catch the Terra Cotta Warriors you will have a new appreciation. 

Do NOT miss this gem, you are in for a treat!
author: Kelly K.

description: A very good authentic Chinese restaurant with many specialties with hand-pulled noodles. It is not fancy but we were served rapidly lots of good food at a very cheap price!
author: Stefano Z.

description:
This restaurant is a little out of the way for most, but in my opinion, it's well worth the detour to this part of the Sunset. The food here is authentic, delicious, filling, and to top it all off, extremely reasonably priced. We waited for around half an hour after arriving at 7pm on a Saturday night, but once we were seated, service was prompt and efficient.

Since it was our first time visiting, we tried many of the starred items on the menu. My favorites were the biang biang noodles and cumin lamb burgers-- staples in Xi'an cuisine that I would highly recommend for anyone! We also tried the Shaanxi mian-pi with sesame sauce, which did have a kick to it, so approach with caution if your spice tolerance is not high. Both the minced pork noodle soup and lamb pita soup have a lot going on-- you'll find noodles, bits of meat, and miscellaneous veggies in a huge steaming both of sour/spicy broth. These five dishes were more than enough to satisfy our group of 4, and the total bill with tax and tip came out to be less than $15 per person--practically unheard of in SF!
author: Amy C.

description:
I LOVE the Biang Biang Noodles! I've tried it in Xi'an and it wasn't as good as here (ok I didn't find a highly recommended restaurant there so could have just been my bad luck). The hand pulled noodles were fresh and chewy and the sauce was delicious, especially with the tomato flavor. If this was the only thing I tried I would give it a 5.

The pita bread soaked in lamb soup (羊肉泡馍) was another Xi'an dish and tasted quite authentic. We also wanted to try the braised chicken, but they were out of it that evening :( The stir fried noodles and the Chinese "burgers" 肉夹馍 were ok, nothing compared to the biang biang mian. 

We had to wait probably 30 minutes or so for a table along with probably 20 other people. Service was not great, the waitress told us we had to order all our food at once and won't be able to add anything else later. She also told us what we ordered wasn't enough, so we ended up adding a bunch more dishes. It turns out the noodle dishes were quite sizable and we completely over ordered. But then again, that's what I expect from authentic Chinese restaurants :P
author: Julie Z.

description:
I'm not sure who decided it was "Good for Groups" on Yelp because it's definitely not. We got there about an hour after they opened and asked to seat a group of 12. They double-checked the number twice and asked me 3 times whether it was for "now". I'm not sure how else I could've been clearer. They had to move tables and the benches to make it work. It was quite the hassle and I wouldn't want to put them through that again.

Anyway, the food was interesting. I'm 100% Chinese but I've never had this "region" of Chinese food. My friends warned me about their spicy levels. I'm never trusting their spice tolerance again. None of the dishes we ordered were spicy, even though they had the spicy indicator next to them. You can tell they definitely attempted with their chili oils, but nope...

We ordered maybe 10 dishes, but they started blending together after a while. I could barely tell the difference between 1 noodle dish from the next. And there weren't very many meat options - a good portion of the menu is all lamb. I think the textures are what stood out to me rather than flavor. But my favorite was the Stir-Fried Lamb with Pita Bread Soaked in Lamb Soup. The "pita bread" was a nice chewy texture and there were some noodles in the soup as well. The soup was also yummy.

I think I had this place bookmarked for the hand-pulled noodles. All their noodle dishes are made with hand-pulled noodles, which I absolutely loved! I would've liked to try their "burgers", but it seems they were out. So I'll definitely want to go again some time in the future. But I would suggest not going with a group and not going ham on the menu by ordering everything.
author: Athena C.

description: Came all the way from the east bay to try out this Xi'An foods and it's pretty disappointing. The restaurant close at 9:30pm and we arrived at 9:08pm. (FYI: The sign said only to-go after 9:15pm) they sat us down and we quickly order our foods. It came quite pretty fast, but it's no surprise that their pork meat bun was microwaved and some of the meat inside were still pretty cold. We also ordered their cold dish, which is the cucumber salad and only realize that it has a dead ant in it. Aside from that, we also ordered their lamb noodle which taste awful. It's like all the food that they serve are hinting me not to come back again. Definitely not coming back the second time.
author: Alicia A.

description:
We arrived 5min before it opened for dinner, and most of the tables were already full. They When its crazy busy, it takes awhile for them take your order, but the food (especially the popular noodles) come out fast. 

Its my BFF's BF's favorite Chinese place, so the three of us went a little overboard with the ordering. 2 bowls of beef noodle, 1 bowl of 3-in-one and 1 bowl of lamb pita soup. Also with cold potato, crunch lotus, garlic pork belly and chicken in scallion oil. Tons of yums.

The noodles are very hand made and with a very good texture. I can absolutely see why the beef noodle and the 3-in-one is such a staple. I also friggen love their egg & tomato combo, although I've never had it noodle style like that before. 

I'm a total pansy when it comes to spice, but most foods (despite the intimidating shade of red), are a numbing spice rather than a fire spice, and mixes well with the other flavors. The pork belly was smothered in garlic chili oil, but the meat was cool and paired nicely with the cool cucumber slices. 

I don't know why its called pita soup. Its not pita. Its kinda like chewy chunks of sourdough, which I did not like. The smell of lamb is very strong, despite not having that much lamb in it.

The cold potato was... not like how my mom makes it. Surprisingly the lotus mix was more similar, gotta love that vinegar crunch. The chicken was drenched in oil, purposely, and its got an interesting smoky taste to it. 

This place is legit enough that I would actually consider taking my parents here. Will be back if I'm ever in the area.
author: Katy Q.

description: A very good restaurant. The style of cuisine is Shaanxi, which is Northern Chinese. There tend to be waits.
author: Karl K.

description: Pretty good especially if you love lamb! Proves are great and so are the portions. They do charge a $15 corkage for wine. Not sure about beer. Get the lamb soup and fish cooked in chili oil.
author: Helen C.

description:
First time here last week. Definitely will come back 
to try appetizers and reorder Sour & Spicy noodle 
and sliced lamb & cumin.
author: Liz S.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Xi'an cuisine, after my first taste of it in NYC at Xi'an Famous Foods. It's taken me awhile to find anything similar to it in the SF Bay Area; Terra Cotta Warrior comes the closest to it.

For those who are new to the concept, Xi'an is a province in China where the terra cotta warriors were buried with the tomb of Qin Shi Huang emperor (along with the empress and his concubines). Enough about the history...because Xi'an is located north, the weather was often harshly cold that people ate a lot of big bowls of noodles, hot soups to keep warm, often leaning on the spicier side of Chinese cuisine.  Lamb was also a quintessential part of northern Chinese cuisine, which it is often cooked really well with little gamey flavor. 

With that in mind, let's talk about the food. First off, Terra Cotta Warrior is great to come to if you are eating with vegetarian friends. They have many appetizers that feature only vegetables with delicious noodle dishes without meat. 

Some of my must-get/favorite dishes here:
1. Mixed cold-shredded potatoes: an appetizer that sounds simple, but is actually quite hard to perfect at home. First, it requires a super skilled chef to slice the potatoes (mandolines are never used in Chinese cutlery), which is then slightly cooked before it tossed in a tangy, vinegary, spicy oil. 
2. Mian Pi- cold noodles that was a specialty at Xi'an Famous Foods. This is best place I have found in the Bay Area that serves great mian-pi. It is essentially a cold, widely cut noodle that is tossed in a vinegary spicy sauce with pieces of pita bread or served with sesame pate (both are good!). This can be ordered hot or cold. I like to order this as a cold appetizer and then have the other noodles hot. I like to think of it like a mung-bean noodle because it kind of clear and has a jello-ish texture. If you haven't had it is before, this is an iconic dish to order. 
3. Preserved egg and silken tofu: it's pretty standard, often eaten in Taiwanese cuisine. I really like the consistency and flavors of the thousand-year eggs here. It smells less foul but has a great texture. 
4. (Vegetarian) Sizzling Oil noodles: simple, QQ noodles that are tossed in a nicely balanced mix of spicy oil, sprouts and green onions. Simple, yet so satisfying flavorful and tasty. I guarantee your vegetarian friends will love this. 
5. Cumin lamb biang biang noodles: this is by far, MY FAVORITE dish to order here, followed by the Shanxi Mian Pi. The flavors of the cumin and lamb are on point, adding a beautiful brown gravy that is just absorbed by the wide flour noodles. The noodles are like Chinese paparadelle's...QQ-chewing consistency. It's great. 
6. Lamb with pita bread (stir fry): Chinese pita bread is flour noodles that shaped and cut into little cubes that you eat like macaroni pasta, but it's better at absorbing flavors and has a better consistency. It holds up the sauce very well and is quite a unique texture and shape if you've never had it before. It's not actually "pita bread."

Some of my other favorites, but not must-order if you don't have enough people to split family style:
1. Chicken in scallion oil: it's like "mouth watering chicken" but without the spiciness. Very refreshing cold chicken appetizer that is a great palate opener. 
2. Lotus Root salad: another appetizer that I like which is crispy parboiled lotus root slices that are tossed in a vinegary sauce that really opens up your senses and taste buds. Very refreshing vegetable dish to add to your repertoire. 
3. Hot and Sour Dumpling Soup: great flavor! It's nothing like hot-and-sour soup, but has a similar flavor profile that is created with a different set of fresh ingredients. The dumplings were made well with a perfect texture of dumpling wrapping and juicy filling. 
4. ShaanXi spicy fish: this is kind of Xi'an version of "water boiled fish." It's less numbing, but has a similar idea. Spicy fish fillet that is boiled in a hot spicy broth of napa cabbage, onions and tofu. It's great to eat with rice or just as a rich stew. 

Not recommended:
Chicken and potato gravy with noodle: this is another popular Xi'an dish, but it is not made that well here. The noodles are overboiled and stick together, making it hard to eat with the gravy. The noodles does not pick up the gravy well, making it overall pretty bland to eat. The chicken and potato pieces are good but are overburdened by a heap of noodles. I am usually a fan of this fish, but not with the way it is cooked, seasoned and served here. My favorite version of this dish so far has been from "Chef Zhao Bistro" in Mountain View (check it out if you have time). 

Overall, a wonderful addition to SF Bay Area. It's a flavor and texture profile of Chinese cuisine that is underrepresented here, and is much appreciated by Chinese folks in the area. Be wary there is always a wait here, usually with parties of 4 or larger. The food here is good, authentic, which attracts a large customer base!
author: Jenny Z.

description:
Food: a bit oily to our family but the hand made noodle is great to taste.
Service: fast serving. Nice staff
author: Xbo Z.

description: 正宗。Authentic Shanxi food.  You know when you started eating and already thinking about what to order next time, is a good sign.  油泼面is a must try.  All the cold side dishes were very good.  Good service.  Good price.
author: Nathan H.

description:
There must be a battalion of terra cotta warriors underneath the restaurant keeping this gem mostly under-the-radar among amateur foodies, who tend to flock to commonplace dim sum or not-even-Chinese fried chicken wings. 

Terra Cotta Warrior specializes in Xian cuisine, which incorporates an interesting melange of Muslim influence and Sichuan spiciness. With the staples of Northern (dumplings and sub-par XLB) and Southern Chinese food (dim sum and wontons) throughout SF, it's refreshing to explore the bold exotic flavor profiles and intriguing compositions at Terra Cotta.

Special diet diners beware: while the menu is extensive, the noodles are not to be missed: low-carb sticklers and faux gluten-allergic hipsters may want to make an exception for this visit. Noodles are house-made and the texture is delightfully al dente, exemplifying the Chinese idiom "bouncing off the teeth". The MIAN PI WITH SESAME SAUCE goes all out with extra-thick ribbons of noodle, complemented by a nutty sesame paste and an intense bottom layer of neon orange chili oil. It may sound odd (especially with the imagery of bouncy noodles), but it was was memorable and strangely satisfying. It is no wonder they sometimes sell out of mian pi by early afternoon.

The BIANG BIANG NOODLES 3 WAYS boasts the same chewy noodles, now in a coarse knife-cut form for an even authentic and homemade feel. Mmm, deliciously carby. The 3 ways include the soy sauce pork belly, sizzling oil, and tomato egg sauces which are all ways that you can order the biang biang noodles. Not sure I'd recommend mixing it all together since it does become quite heterogeneous, though still delicious. This is a great way to sample three dishes in one, but if you strongly gravitate towards a particular one I would go for just ordering that because the combo does cost more. Note that the noodles, being housemade, are seemingly endless so it's a bit of a struggle to portion this out.

Initially I thought the LAMB SOAKED IN PITA BREAD sounded disgusting, as I had the idea of soggy pita bread in soup. But seeing how Yelpers seemed to enjoy it (and that there seemed to be no pictures of soggy pita bread), we went for it. This was my favorite dish, tied with mian pi.The soup was simple and soothing, the lamb was tender and not gamy, and there was a fascinating mixture of thick mochi-like noodle chunks (the "pita bread") starkly contrasted by thin silver noodles. It appears hodgepodge-ish, but all the ingredients and textures come together flawlessy as expected for a time-tested regional specialty dish.

While the GARLIC SLICED PORK is not one of their well-known items, it's a great appetizer that wakes up your taste buds with thin pork slices bathed in chili oil and liberally sprinkled with chopped garlic--nearly garlicky enough to inducted into the Stinking Rose.

Although I try to sound knowledgeable about regional specialties of Chinese cuisine, I am by no means well-versed (I hardly know my geography in China!). However when I google the restaurant specials I tried here, the Wikipedia gods tell me they are indeed all trademark dishes of the Shaanxi province.

Lastly, note that Yelp has a pop-up warning about the poor score on food safety inspection, but to be honest I always take that with a grain of salt. There's not much info on the exact metrics of the ratings, and I've seen worse at places with non-problematic ratings. In any case, the restaurant looked just fine. Either the spices kill the bugs, or the food inspector was weak and couldn't stomach any spicy food. 

While the restaurant does tend to get busier during peak times, there is usually no wait if you come earlier. The terra cotta warriors appreciate your thoughtfulness and save seats to the well-prepared who arrive ahead of time. Okay that may be taking the superstition analogy too far... but in short, thank you Terra Cotta for bringing an adventurous taste of Xian to Sunset.
author: Edna C.

description: Noodles are good, authentic flavor and texture - important in Shaanxi cuisine. Very crowded by 6:00 pm. The Chinese burgers (肉夹馍, roujiamuo) we're okay but they used ground pork instead of pulled pork, and the bun was a little oily.
author: Matt B.

description: After enjoying our food we wanted to sit and talk. At this the waiter kept giving us looks to leave and the waitress asked us to leave as the resturant was full and people were waiting. We understand the business needs to make money, but after paying the bill the experience changed from a welcoming location to one where we were burden... If you are in a hurry and want some good food this restuarnt is fine. if you want to sit and talk to your friends another location is probably better.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
I had higher expectations before coming here because I had heard good reviews about this place from people who have dined here and have even tried some of their takeout before. I came here on a Saturday, shortly after 2:00pm. They close at 2:30pm, but just after 2pm, they stopped taking people on the wait list. We were still able to get a table, but were extremely rushed to order. We barely even had a chance to look at the menu and the waitress wanted us to order because the kitchen was closing down. The only thing I wanted to order (the mian pi), they were out of...so, we had to scramble to choose some other dishes. 

We ordered the Biangbiang noodles with cumin lamb ($10.95) - this dish was pretty spicy! The noodles are loooong and wide, making it a little hard to break off. I thought this dish was not bad, but I wasn't crazy about it, possibly because it was a little too spicy for me. 

Mixed cold shredded potatoes ($5.25) - it's exactly how it's described. Cold, shredded potatoes. It's an ok side dish, but wasn't extremely special or flavorful. 

Chinese burger with pork ($5.25) - Too bland to eat as a burger. It's just basic meat and bread. The meat was marinated in soy sauce and tasted ok by itself, however, once you put the meat in between the bread, it becomes too bland. There is too much bread and too little meat, making the plain bread taste overpowering. I wouldn't order this again. It was disappointing.

Sautéed lamb slices with scallions ($12.95) - This was the only dish I really liked and would definitely order this again. Lamb was thinly sliced and very flavorful. This dish was very mildly spicy and tasted great with the onions. 

Overall, with 3 so-so dishes and one great dish, topped with extremely rushed service, I'd say my first try at Terra Cotta Warrior was just OK. (Not to mention they were out of the one dish I wanted to order and they have a poor food safety score.) I probably would come back here someday to try their mian pi and lamb with scallions...but I'm not in a rush. There are definitely some good dishes here. You just have to make sure to know to order them.
author: Jean S.

description:
My Asian pride was bursting after a delicious meal here. This will definitely be my go-to place to take people who want to eat really authentic Chinese food. Even when I reheated my leftovers from last night, I was in absolute heaven.

MUST ORDER: 

1) Lao Wan Yu - It's like fish boiled in a spicy hot pot... ugh that description just doesn't do it justice. Full of spices, the broth is deee-licious, the fish is so tender, and all the vegetables on the bottom just make this dish 6 out of 5 stars. 

2) Lamb Cumin Burger - SOOO good. The bun is really nice -- not too soft and holds the entire burger together very well. The filling is absolutely delicious - I love cumin with lamb. 

Everything here is on point. One of the BEST Chinese restaurants in SF for sure. You know because the line goes out the door and it's usually Asian people who eat there (mad respect to non-Asians who found this great gem and are willing to eat non-Panda food! It's better on the other side!!!)
author: Cindy W.

description: Great, authentic xi'an food! The cumin lamb burger is a must-try. They actually open a little earlier than 5:30 for dinner so get there early to avoid a wait. They also do not allow ordering more than once, so be sure to get everything you want at once (and a little extra to bring home!). The food comes pretty quickly, which is appreciated after a long wait to get seated.
author: Isabel R.

description:
More of a 3.5 than a solid 4?

Visited on Sunday with two friends for lunch, and we just managed to avoid the wait rush by coming in a couple minutes after the restaurant opened. We ordered the ginger spinach, couple's delight, and lamb cumin biang biang noodles. The flavoring for the ginger spinach & couple's delight was perfect and all 3 of us loved it. The biang biang noodles were a bit underwhelming given my expectations, but the noodles had a nice bouncy texture. I wanted to add a lamb burger near the end of our lunch, but our waiter brought out a pork burger (?) instead and that was so-so.

While the food was great, the service was pretty iffy -- our main waiter seemed confused when we placed our order so my friend had to check with the counter, he was a bit aggressive when I asked to add the extra dish (plus, turns out he placed the wrong order), and it took us 3-4 tries to finally have him get us the check. 

I'll probably be back for the food, but I hope the next time the service won't be as uncomfortable.
author: Shela H.

description:
The food here is pretty delicious, but a little bit pricy. Also the amount of meat/vegetables are very small compared to noodle/rice. My friends and I both feel that we had a lot of carbohydrate but very few meat/vegetables. Also, most of their dishes are spicy - even egg & potato noodles! (cannot believe this).

One of my friends refuses to go to this restaurant again because of a terrible waiter she experienced. She said she was not allowed to add another dish because there were so many customers waiting in the line. (Seriously? this is ridiculous). I did not experience the similar situation, but they do tend to have you finished sooner if it is peak dinner time (e.g. Friday night).
author: Cindy C.

description:
I am starting to become obsessed with this place and am willing to concede that it is the best Chinese restaurant in the Sunset. Yes, even better than San Tung, although it depends on what you like (I prefer hand pulled noodles over fried chicken any day, but most people I know would disagree).

You cannot go wrong with their Shaanxi specialties. I recommend the mian pi (chewy cold noodles mixed with sliced cucumbers, sesame oil, vinegar, and chili), noodles in sizzling oil (perfectly chewy noodles seasoned with chili flakes and black vinegar, and doused with boiling oil), and their soup noodles (I am partial to the pita bread soaked in lamb soup but again, you cannot go wrong with any of their specialty soup noodles). This is a noodle heavy restaurant and from what I can tell, the noodles are slapped, stretched, and torn by hand. You'll be able to tell immediately from the friendly resistance with each bite.

I think this is only the second Xian restaurant in all of SF. The spices and sauces the Shaanxi owner has developed in-house has really made this place special. It's nice to see other types of Chinese food be recognized and appreciated in the Sunset besides Chinese/Vietnamese and Northern Chinese (which has seen a tremendous rise lately in the area). Truly one of the big foodie gems of the Bay Area.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I've never had Shaanxi food before coming here, but it was a good first experience. I'll say straight off the bat, that all the food is pretty greasy. 

Food: 
- Chinese burger with pork: shredded pork between two toasted white buns.
- Hot and sour pork dumpling soup: you can choose the level of spiciness, but the soup was very tart (like vinegar). Hard to eat for someone not used to it, but the dumplings were good.
- Shaanxi stir-fried noodles: basically a derivative chow fun
- Fried rice with eggs and chives: this one was probably my favorite; for a very basic dish it was full of flavor

The service was good and the atmosphere was clean and cute.
author: Amanda C.

description:
My family and I tried to come here once before, but they were closed for construction or something. We finally got another opportunity to swing by on Mother's Day. I must confess that we came here with high hopes but left rather disappointed.

Rating Breakdown:
1/2 Stars for Taste --
OK, we were super excited to come try their hand-pulled noodles so we ordered the Biang Biang noodles three ways and the Shanxi stir fried wide noodles. Everyone knows that texture is the most important part of a good noodle. These were overly cooked and almost soggy, as if the water used for boiling the noodles had been used a few times too many. A restaurant that can't get noodles right? That's a no-no in my book.

We also tried the wonton in chili oil and the cold noodles (mian-pi). The mian pi was not great -- it was on the bland side. The wontons in chili oil were probably the highlight of the meal however, which was confusing because I figured the sauce for the mian pi was pretty similar. I ended up mixing the mian pi noodles in the wonton chili oil for more flavor. 

The lamb dishes were pretty on point here. The pita in lamb soup is definitely worth trying. The cumin lamb burger was great -- the diced peppers mixed in the cumin lamb gave it a kick that wasn't intolerable (And still good as reheated leftovers!). 

1/1 Stars for Value --
Each dish was around  $10 and came in generous portions. With side dishes, you will probably run about $15 per person. 

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
It's a busy restaurant and everything is jammed into a pretty small place, but the waiters manage to keep things going at a decent pace. When I asked for a knife to cut up the lamb cumin burger, a waiter brought by a pair of cooking shears. Asians and using scissors for everything, bless!

No bonus star because I probably wouldn't come back although I could be persuaded to give this place another chance in the future if I'm really craving that cumin lamb...

TL;DR: Cumin lamb burger! Noodles were meh, but maybe it was an off-day. Busy, expect a wait.
author: Abby W.

description:
Super busy during dinner time, but no wait during lunch time on a weekday. Craving some good thick hand pulled noodles and they delivered! Got the spicy cumin lamb noodles but requested super mild, which they were able accommodate so I appreciate that! Delicious, chewy noodles and perfectly seasoned. 
My friend got the biangbiang (?) noodles and they were tomato flavored, I tried a bite and it was good too.
author: Wendy L.

description: Really like their cold dishes.  I just wished they were opened for lunch on the weekdays.
author: b w.

description:
Best worst Xi'An restaurant I have been to yet. 

The food itself is good, and I think because this is the only place that has critics' recommendations for being a Xi'An hometown style food restaurant, it attracts all of the Chinese noodle lovers. However, its customer service is beyond HORRIBLE. I could've literally gone up to the counter and tell the cashier to input my food orders for me rather than having the "waiter" and "waitress" serve me. 

After a few minutes of first checked into the place, the waitress/hostess called out my name (or so I thought, another person with the same name) and I've answered. Out of nowhere, the waitress scolded me "why didn't you answer when I called you?!" In mandarin. After we got seated, the waitress fortunately got our order. Again, the food is good enough, however, still not close to actual food in Xi'An. The Xi'An cold noodle's portion was too small and I had to order another. Then, this is where the second red flag comes. After I finally waved down one of the waiters, I told him my orders clearly and he responded with ok got it. But, after we've finished all of our dishes, my second round of orders still didn't come right there and then, I knew the waiter forgot my orders, along with my glass of water and change out my overflowing dirty plate. 

All in all, I feel for a restaurant as "good" as this, their staff should come with better standard; being more professional and experiences. And I hope for the sake of the only few places that serves authentic Xi'An food, internally review all of your own performances and set improvements.
author: Nha V.

description: Very packed on a Saturday night. Long wait and must pay close attention to your name being called as they may not know how to properly pronounce your name. If you are chinese might as well write your name in chinese. Service was good, food is interesting and unique but the noodle dishes are very oily, felt like have to drink a gallon of water to rinse off the oil ingested. I like how unlike some other Chinese restaurants, they don't seem to rush out their customers even tho the lines out there is long. Would go back for the meat burgers, tried beef, pork and lamb all delicious and tasty.
author: Gracee G.

description: We ordered the hot and sour glass noodles, which aren't on the menu. It was very authentic and had the right flavors. We also got the refreshing cucumber dish which was a good palette cleanser between the slightly oily dishes. The service was good, and we also got in around 8 with minimal wait time.
author: Qingbo Z.

description:
I think that certain menu items are probably okay here, but some menu items may be disappointing. 

The stir-fried lamb in cumin is way too salty. I had this same problem at another restaurant with a similar dish. However, not all places will have problems with this kind of dish. I think it's always a risk when ordering something like this, and I was quite disappointed as I think there would be no way for them to wash it and reheat without making it saltier because it cooks more of the flavor into the meat with reheating, which is what I experienced at another place with the same kind of dish when I asked them to wash the salt out. I saw another yelp review commenting on how salty the food is.

The Szechuan mian-pi small dish is okay if you want a taste of the unique thick noodles, but there is nothing spectacular about that dish too. 

The Chinese burger with pork had good quality flour bread outside. However the pork was quite fatty, almost like bacon. If you don't mind the fat, it was not bad then. I did not expect it to be like bacon. I think someone else wrote this kind of comment too.

If I were to try this place again, I think maybe trying some of the cold dishes might work out.
author: J J.

description:
Food is average at best.  Wait staff needs to either verify orders or invest in hearing aids.  They only brought half of what I actually ordered, so this is a review on what we ate and not what we ordered.  Fried rice was made with a lessor quality rice and had a little Jasmine rice mixed in (the untrained cant tell bit I can).  The oil used was also of lessor quality and the onion was not the freshest.  It tasted like they use egg beaters instead of real eggs.  

   The 3 in 1 had a really bad tasting tomato sauce, a very generic brand probably purchased in 1 gallon drums.  Handmade noodles were made with lessor quality ingredients and had no taste, and were probably rush prepped due inconsistent in size and texture.  The chopped tomato in the 3 in 1 could have been of better quality and was not even ripe.  It tasted like a bowl of spaghetti-o's  The pork burger consisted of a lot of fatty meat and was just meat and bread.

This place has potential, might be great for late night food but not a high end meal.
author: Brandon M.

description:
This is my new favorite Chinese spot, serving Shaanxi cuisine.  It's a type of Chinese food that's rare in the United States, but getting more popular.  You can probably only get it here, LA, or NY, so take advantage!

So being fully honest here, I came here around a year ago and had some of the worst diarrhea of my life.  Like sitting on the toilet in a daze, wondering how my life has come to this.  And then I came back two more times because the food was so good, just to see if that was just a fluke.  But it wasn't.
