So then I learned how to make biang biang noodles at home because who comes to a restaurant for repeat diarrhea 4 times in a row, amirite?

However, while my homemade noodles are pretty damn good, they still didn't compare, and so I would check the yelp page occasionally, just to dream, and about 6 months ago found out that it was under new management!  I had to try it again.  And I'm happy to report that I've eaten here 8+ times and have had ZERO issues.  And now I can positively recommend it to you!

Food Fact Time - This place makes a special kind of noodle called Biang Biang noodles.  These are wheat noodles that are hand made, very thick, and very wide.  They have a stretchy texture with a very pleasant mouthfeel.  Biang is also one of the most complex Chinese characters with 57 strokes, it's unclear what the word means or where it originated from.  This is one of the only places you can get them in SF!

Things to get:
- Yopo noodles (Sizzling Oil noodles or something like that) - This dish is BOMB.  You might want to get two.  It started with Biang Biang noodles in a vinegar and soy sauce.  Then fresh garlic and fresh chili powder is placed on top, they heat a pan of oil until it's smoking hot, and then they pour it over, cooking the garlic and chili powder.
- Anything else that sounds good to you with Biang Biang noodles in them (cumin lamb, egg and tomatoes, various stir fries)
- Pork burger - I haven't had too many of these, so not sure how this one stacks up against other restaurants, but the idea of the dish is great.  It's a flatbread that's crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  It's filled with juicy, fatty pork that's been cooked forever.  The fat has rendered down and it's coating the inside on the bread, making it moist and delicious.
- Lamb soup with pita bread - Clean tasting lamb soup.  Has torn off pieces of the pork burger bread in there, along with some bean vermicelli.  Nice way to offset the heavy flavors.

tl;dr - sizzling oil noodes
author: Sean Y.

description:
Everything tasted about the same to me - spicy and a little overly seasoned. 

We asked that the dishes to be cooked MILD because my stomach can't handle spicy. Maybe it's because of this that everything tasted the same to me. 

Most of the dishes comes with some form of carbs (potato, noodle, bread, etc). We shared 4 dishes between 5 girls and it was too much food. 

RECOMMEND: 
- Shanxi braised spicy fish: Recommend if you like tilapia
- Braised chicken w/ potato & pepper: large portion, has noodle on the bottom
- Cumin lamb burger messy to eat but great seasoning 

AVERAGE: 
- Qishan minced pork noodle soup: a little too sour for me 

Satisfied service and pricing. Not too sure if I would come back here by myself since my stomach is not a big fan of spicy food.
author: Wendy F.

description: They offer very authentic Chinese food, especially their noodles! The place is small and there are always people waiting in line, so please come early.
author: Lingyun X.

description:
Super crowded but worth the wait. Terra Cotta Warrior serves Xi An Chinese food (bet you didn't know that was a thing, huh?), which means lamb, "pita" bread, and cumin.

Great dishes that you should order:
1) Chinese burger with pork: Pan-fried dough "buns" surrounding a juicy meat "patty." The whole thing was really flavorful, but I also might just be a sucker for the doughy "bao" buns...
2) Pita bread soaked in lamb soup: The "pita bread" was doughy and had the consistency of mochi. It soaked up the spices and flavor of the lamb soup really well.

I didn't get a chance to try the Shaanxi Mian Pi because they were sold out, but of course, that's a really good sign!

Definitely worth the trek out to the Outer Sunset (parking is easy, at least!). There's unfortunately not much to do in the area while you wait in line (some kind of crepe/boba place next door and that's pretty much it), so be prepared to kill time / stand around while you wait for some awesome Chinese food.
author: Brittany C.

description:
High quality noodles and the lamb burger was unexpectedly quite delicious. This spot has a cozy ambiance and a unique menu different from your typical Chinese restaurant. Service was friendly and food came quick. 

Food: 4.25/5
Value: 3.75/5
Service: 3.75/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Brian G.

description:
The food was good but it's not a flavour profile that I'm used to (like Szechuan food). If you like sweet and spicy or shanxi food then this is probably great.

We loved the lamb burger tho! My bf is from xi an and he said it was better than the lamb burger he had there.
author: Annie W.

description:
Love the flavors and the textures.
You have crispy, fluffy, savory, sweet, spicy.
If you have a monotone palette, then this place could be overwhelming.
I wish i could give this place 5 stars, but even with the smaller portion sizes, it was hard to try a lot of different dishes as so many of the dishes were carb heavy.

line can be long on weekends
author: Jason C.

description:
Came here with a group of 4 when it opened on a weekend and was seated immediately. 

Ordered the following dishes to share:
qishan minced pork noodle soup - best dish that I had and hand pulled noodles are delightfully chewy. the soup was addicting to drink and my entire group seemed to finish their soup. very few pieces of pork, but the ones I had were fatty and flavorful
guanzhong hot spicy noodles - also a good dish, but not quite as much flavor as the qishan minced pork
tomato and egg noodle soup - this was yummy and not too sweet. 
wonton with hot spicy oil - this dish comes with ~12 wontons. skin was a tad hard, but that may be cause I waited till it cooled to eat. 
cumin lamb burger - ordered 2 of these to share among us, but that was too much. Could have done with just 1 because it's so large. the buns are extra crispy and soaked in lamb oil for more flavor. cumin taste is quite strong. this was the spiciest dish out of everything we ordered.
shaanxi spicy fish - looks spicy at first, but actually not so bad. fish fillets are soft and easy to consume. 

My friends that have had authentic northern china cuisine were very impressed with the noodles. I liked that the noodles were chewy and also very very long. Service here was quick, food came out fast, tea was promptly refilled. Definitely will be back to eat here again!
author: Edward W.

description: Only place in the Bay Area to get hand cut noodles like this. Extremely tasty dishes across the board.
author: Dan M.

description:
Not even one star. Done with this restaurant. Worst ever. 
They didn't let us in when our number was called because one of us hadn't arrived yet. Then we tried to leave, and they reluctantly compromised. We ordered the lamb and that was raw, they simply recooked it and claimed that it was a newly made dish (we found out). When we haven't finished entirely they handed us the check, implicitly forcing us to leave. Very bad service and attitude for all waiters and waitresses.
author: Hean H.

description:
One of the best non-Sichuan/Canton Chinese restaurant in SF I'd say.

They serve Chinese food from Xi-An, which is the historical capital of China. (think Rome) Be adventurous and order from the Xi-An section of the menu. You'll be rewarded for taking risk.

Most dishes are really delicious, although the portions can be on the small side. 

Also this place gets pretty crowded even on weekdays. Expect to wait a bit.
author: Joseph L.

description:
For the first time I ate the familiar flavor of shanxi province, china
I love the mianpi, but the serve is a lit bit small, the soup of qishan shaozimian is very good I almost drink them all but it's not spicy and sour enough for me so I added a lot of chili oil and vinegar 
Roujiamo is very good especially if u take away and heat it again it makes the flavor more go into it but I wish the soup of meat is a lit bit more and the pancake is just a lit bit softer 
We also ordered garlic pork slice, my friend said it's salty but I found it perfect
author: 凯淇

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.
It's serving the cuisine from North West China, specifically, Shanxi. I've been to there twice. The food/noodles there taste exactly the same.
Handmade noodle is the must have dish.
author: J D.

description: Just went in during normal hours, was told we would be sat in a minute and then the waitress came back and said "The chef said he's too busy." Word.
author: Justin S.

description:
How many know that Xi'an was once the capital of China? Its cooking, and that of the Shaanxi Province, is Terra Cotta Warrior's specialty. The dishes here are spicy without overwhelming the intense multi-layered flavors from different spices and herbs.

The cooking is a special treat here and a great way to sample the rare cuisine.
author: Greg T.

description: Good fresh noodles. None of the dishes were memorable. The large chicken dish was huge but nothing special. Probably won't be back -______-
author: Fatty A.

description: I like this place, it is clean and quiet , service was awesome, food tasty and well cooked, I have to come back again , next weekend for sure!
author: Kevin R.

description: Came here with my parents the food is great and very authentic. One of the waiter's attitude was very rude. I asked if I can order first, since I have been waiting for a long time. The waiter did not look at me when he murmured just one word no and started being busy. I understand that the restaurant is busy, but basic respect is important. My parents and I come here really often and knows the owner, but it seems like the owner starts to hiring more people who are not respectful. It might affect if we can to come back in the future. A restaurant is not only about the food, but it is really about the whole experience.
author: Xiaofan W.

description:
I'm obsessed with hand pulled and hand-cut noodles, and Terra Cotta Warrior has some of the best in norcal. The noodles look like tape worms but taste like carb-heaven -- the unevenness of their edges catch at the sauce and keep every bite interesting. 

I also think their boiled spicy fish pot is A+! On par with Old Islamic Chinese's, though not quite as complex in their spices.
author: Jean L.

description: Haven't had such a terrible lunchtime experience in years. We five came a long way to try out the new taste but the service was so disappointed. No one greeted us, no one seated us, and the way they talk was extremely rude. Won't ever go.
author: Siwei C.

description: The most traditional Shanxi cuisine I have ever tried in Bay Area. Service is also very nice. I eat here or order to go every two weeks. Can't get enough.
author: Rui Y.

description: Where do I start? This is a cute little place with an amazing menu. I wanted to try EVERYTHING!! I really enjoyed their spicy wontons and cucumber salad. Their flat noodles were...meh. Only downside is the tables are set a little too close together. We hear all the drama from the table next to us. Would I go back? Yes! There's so much I still want to try.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Best Xian food ever!!!! I'm from Xi'an and it is authentic af. I drive 1 hour to get there and it's so worth it. Thank you'
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Over a year ago, our local paper published an article about the recent trend of Shanxi cuisine and foods from Xian.  Scattered mostly in the neighborhoods of the Richmond and Sunset Districts, there are several to choose from.  Of them, this seems to be the most popular.
On a late summer weeknight evening, my 808 Yelp friend Peter C. (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=guwRwwQLPJ2ie_7YNfHMmA) from the 808 happened to contact me about putting together a dinner; Al L. (https://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=8qpFUPR1wd3uz8N1QaWj_A) was another partner in crime as well as two other friends.  The aforementioned two were the first to arrive but they could not be seated until our full party of five arrived.  We were seated near the front on the right side on a decent sized table.  Being the first time for all of us, I suggested that everyone pick one dish and we order small appetizers and small plates to share.  This is how and why large party meals are a better gauge of a restaurant's cuisine and skills as we were able to try a number of dishes family style.  Given the number of dishes we ordered, here's my summary:

The highlights:
a) Braised chicken with potato and pepper, small (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=O5bZIuyl3CI4rFkF6z-YDA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Hearty portions and very deceiving.  The flavors were strong, different, and mouth pleasing though not the most particularly photogenic dish.  Our waiter recommended this so compliments to him on this one. 

b) Three-in-one Biangbiang noodles (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9-hpmTBgeMOUze1rt08SRA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - This was pleasing to the eye and I enjoyed this noodle dish the most among the three that we ordered.  Again, the variety of flavors was what struck me the most.  Menu states that all noodle dishes are made from hand pulled noodles which is nice to know if true for this dish.

c) Celeries with dried bean curd sticks (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qRorzR4rQjM_wo8cfRSADg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Very simple dish but good cold dish to open ones palate.  The sesame oil and light seasoning was a nice contrast to our other heavy sauced dishes.


The not-so-much:
d) Fried bean paste noodles (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=tTM8PWlTaHuOnVJ3efm6DA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Also known as Jia Jiang Mien, this was okay as I've had better elsewhere.  Nothing particularly wrong as it just didn't shine.  Perhaps the thick sauce and starchy (almost udon texture) noodles made this a bit one toned.  

e) Burgers (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qYSbjDA-ZGf47-JT7I83SQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - The pictured egg and hot pepper one was actually my favorite.  We also tried the cumin lamb burger and the Chinese burger with pork, cutting them each six ways so everyone could get a bite.   

Overall, this was a fun and interesting dinner, given that many of us hadn't seen each other in quite a while.  I could not photograph all of our menu selections as the kitchen cranked out food before we could finish plates, giving us a bit of pressure to consolidate dishes and unfinished food to make room.  Unfortunately, like many Chinese restaurants, Terra Cotta is more worried about turning tables over than the diners' experiences.  As our meal continued, the dining room filled and, by the time we left, there was a small crowd waiting for their names to be read from a sign-up list.
On the plus side, our waiter was honest and accurate in steering us towards the braised chicken and limiting our dishes.  We finished most of the food with just small portions to spare.  The menu is helpful with the "star" system which indicates their more popular dishes, many of which we tried.  Water glasses and tea pots were filled as needed.  
As we made our way through the waiting diners around 8:30 pm, a car stopped in front dropping off four other potential customers.  
Wouldn't recommend this for my family's palate, but for a younger demographic who wants to experience pretty genuine regional Chinese cuisine, you'd find this more interesting.  
Might come back to try some of their noodle soups during the winter months which are just around the corner now.
author: Mike C.

description: Food is just average. Their flavor is ok but the texture of the noodle is off. Their service could leave a very bad taste if you are taking your time. They would give you the bad look and yell at you: you have been sitting here for too long!"
author: Daveen L.

description:
Great Shanxi food! I felt that it was authentic and it was definitely very crowded when I got there. I waited about 30 mins to get seated (although the table was ready within 15 mins but my group was not fully present so we weren't seated). 

I ordered the Spicy fish, peanut sauce shanxi noodle (IMPRESSIVE) and we had the wonton in hot sauce, shredded potatoes. All were amazing but I must say the noodles were phenomenal and different! 

The service wasn't great as you would expect from authentic Chinese restaurants, we are not famous for our service standards..
author: Kelly L.

description: We ordered food from terra-cotta warrior before, and it was all delicious. This time, we got take out and the chicken wontons were raw. Not even rare, just raw. We asked for a refund and the lady said she couldn't refund unless we drove back down there. We called again and they refunded our order. Most of the stuff there is really good, but the chicken wontons were undercooked.  So just be careful!!!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
As a Chinese, I will recommend this place if you would like to have some authentic Shanxi/Xi'an cuisines. The noodle is very close to how they do in northern China and lamb burger is also pretty good.

You better arrive early and we had to wait for 20 mins during the peak hours, but it is not a big problem since 20 mins is worthwhile.

The service is just slow and they never ask if you need anything, I think that is the only thing that I am not satisfied.
author: Rui X.

description: Fresh noodles make for a great soup bowl. And this place has the perfect blends of spices and broth to go with them. Multiple options of meat and other not soup options. Great for sharing or load up and take it to go! Anything with lamb is awesome. Could have a better alcohol selection but that's not a deal breaker.
author: CJ S.

description:
MMMmmmmm!
Xi'An Famous Foods is always a must top on all my NYC trips and I've been craving a good plate of noodles without the 6 hour flight. 

Terra Cotta Warrior did the trick.

Mian Pi - Great to try for the first time; solid dish here but not as chewy as the noodles. Will order again if I ever get the craving for it. 
Broccoli - Delicious!
Dumplings in Soup - the soup was very sour and definitely hit the spot. I was not a fan at how loose and watery the dumpling filing was
Hamburger w/ Pork - Flavor was great; definitely bit into some fatty pieces of pork in there. Heavy on the carb vs pork ratio. Would order again if it wasn't so unhealthy!
Shanxi Stir Fried Wide Noodles - These were the star dish of our meal... the noodles were super chewy and the flavors and sauce was great!
author: Vicky L.

description: The food was really great,service was excellent. Noodles were perfect. And for what it's worth, I think they deserve to go on vacation once a year- or more! We had a vegan meal and were very happy,with plenty of leftovers for lunch tomorrow.
author: Carmen O.

description:
Food was ok. But service was beyond lousy. We were denied of water/ tea refill simply because the kitchen was closed. In fact our pot of tea was for sure recycled tea bag from previous use. It was completely bland and looked like water. C'mon, why would a restaurant cheap out on water ?? 

Also seeing their poor food safety score being the bottom 5% is alarming.
author: Lynn W.

description:
The food here is great. I grew up in Xi'an and can say that this is the most authentic Xi'an food in San Francisco. 

Having said that, I'm not sure if the food is enough to compensate for the rude and disrespectful service you get from this place. I go to a lot of Chinese restaurants and am fully aware that Chinese restaurants are not known for their service or hospitality. However, the terrible service you get here is much worse than your average service-lacking Chinese restaurants. They refuse to seat people well before closing time (with multiple tables open), forget your orders, and try to take away your food before you finish it.

While I'll miss the food, I don't think I'll be coming back to this place due to the terrible service. I wish the management would do something about it so that customers can enjoy their food without feeling like the waitstaff is hating on them and want them out of the restaurant ASAP.
author: Lara Y.

description:
Ok terra cotta, I am a frequent customer as I live within walking distance. But last night why did you have to be so unaccommodating?? My friends and I (a group of 3) were turned away BEFORE 9 pm, and mind you, the hours posted were until 9:30pm! We offered to make a to-go order instead but were told you couldn't do that. What?? You had more than a half hour left of OPEN time. If you were going to turn customers away, which I was told by other patrons you started doing before we even came, then you should change your hours to close at 9pm! 
So disappointing, especially since I know many people come from across the city to eat your food and wait long periods of time for it. 
I added a star because I had relatively good experiences in the past. 

I don't think I'll be coming back for a long time.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
The Shanxi Mianpi was really good. Best dish in the house. This dish alone is enough to bring me back. 
Go to this restaurant to overload on carbohydrates. Every dish has tons of noodles. Wish they offered more vegetable dishes to balance out the meal.
author: Hung Q.

description:
Terracotta warrior!!!
If you haven't tried this place you're missing out, this place is unbelievable. We got there at 7 pm and the wait wasn't too bad, we waited about 20 minutes.  Once seated we started looking at the menu, if you haven't been to a northern Chinese place a lot of it will look very unfamiliar.

We started with the Shaanxi mian pi (which was less than $5), it was noodles with sesame oil and chili, very tasty , worth every penny.
As an entree we shared the minced pork noodle soup, the noodles seemed as if they just made them, they were very freah, the soup itself was spicy and very rich, we loved it.
We then got the beef lungs in chili sauce and I got to say we weren't ready for this one, apparently it's made with numbing chili that literally numbs your lips, it was unique, I recommend it.
At last we got the lotus root in chili sauce ( the chili sauce here wasn't numbing ) , it was good but I could've gone without.

So 3 cold dishes (tapas style ) and 1 soup entree came out to be 26 bucks, very affordable and amazing food, this place is a diamond in the rough.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Hand pulled noodle joint in a nice setting, but a little too oily for my taste. And hot really isn't that hot, I found myself adding more chili sauce to my plate.

I wish I could say that I loved this place. But everything we ordered felt like it was swimming in oil. 

Biang Biang Noodles 3 Ways: Supposedly very popular, but it tasted like tomato chow mien. Hand pulled noodles tossed with a tomato sauce with some bok choy and fatty pork pieces. I thought it would have more flavor but it was pretty bland to me. Nothing about it stood out to me. 

Lamb Dumplings: These were my favorite that night, although I prefer my dumplings to be juicier and with some soup inside. Great flavor though and comes with some chili oil dipping sauce which you need. 

Shanxi Stir Fried Wide Noodles: Pretty much chow fun. Had some pork strips, bell pepper, and sliced bok choy. 

Nothing really stood out to me--If you're Cantonese, you'll understand it when is say that the dishes lacked "wok hei". Not enough flavor. I did see the couple sitting next to us eating this soup where you rip up what looked like bread and put it in there. It looked interesting.
author: Jen P.

description: Oh man this restaurant is incredible! Another fine installment in the Bay Area tour of restaurants that thrive entirely off giving a mostly Chinese clientele a pure, unmolested version of an unapologetically Chinese cuisine, and another place I can go to feel like I've flown back to China. A few palefaces mixed in here or there, but every one of them is down, and there's not a walnut prawn in sight. The one pro tip is get here early and mind the weekend hours, as they really do aim to close by 2:30 pm. Not that they ran us out, but they do run fairly close to their announced schedule. I'll have to be back to confirm the delectability of the widely praised hand-pulled noodles. Meanwhile what I did order was wonderful, and the calorie-per-dollar ratio embraces the straightforward efficient hedonism I love. I especially enjoyed the Shaanxi mian-pi with sesame sauce. Do that one, even if it means doubling up on noodles. These are destination noodles and there's no reason not to get your fill. Strangely enough I wasn't wowed by the tofu with preserved egg, something I found wonderful in China, but this version is passable and doesn't dampen my overall enthusiasm in the least. So many wonderful things bulging out of all sides of the lengthy menu here. I'll be back again and again and I'm sure will stay well-entertained.
author: James D.

description:
I will never go to this place again. I felt this place was great until I saw what happened in the kitchen - A chef or waitress put her finger in her mouth to taste the dish, and then put the finger back to the dish. She did this several times without washing her finger at all. 
我很喜欢这里的食物，直到看到一个厨师或者是服务员吮吸手指来尝味道。她把手指先放进嘴里，然后又把手指直接放进做好的凉皮。 来来回回这样做了好几次，而且中间根本没洗过手。
author: Meilin Z.

description:
I love this place.

Sadly, when I tried to eat here today, it was closed and there was a sign posted on its door that said something to the effect of: "closed for renovation until 8/2/16 and under new management." Sorry didn't have my phone to take a pic. 

A little bit sad, but I will be waiting for it to reopen.
author: Dao C.

description:
Such a nice change from the usual Cantonese fare!

The highlight of our meal was the Szechuan Mian-pi, a cold noodle dish tossed in a spicy sauce with peanuts and slivered cucumber. This was excellent. We also tried the Shaanxi stir fried wide noodles. These were long, hand pulled noodles fried with onions, peppers and chiles. This was also pretty tasty. 

The smashed cucumber salad was a nice crunchy contrast to the noodles. 

Chinese pork burger was good but nothing special

The spicy sour shredded potato stir-fry was my least favorite although definitely the most innovative and different. The julienned strips of potato were still crunchy which is definitely different to how western cuisines cook the tuber. 

Can't wait to come back to try more things!
author: Ada C.

description:
Profit has gotten in the way of their authenticity to Shanxi China.

Service is hit or miss. Not to mention the food is inconsistent and the tables are always sticky.
.
Some dishes are spicier than average and quite oily too. Yet their distinctive flavors from herbs, peppercorns and sometimes numbness might attract your senses.
.
At $9.95 the Shaanxi Stir-fried wide Noodle is hand pulled and has a little shredded chicken and jalapeños mixed in.
. 
At $15.95 Shaanxi Spicy Fish with shredded seaweed, tofu skin and fungus may actually leave your mouth numb.  
.
At $9.95 the Spicy & Sour Shredded Potatoes are not spicy but have great texture and flavor. If you don't like jalapeños the very few there can be easily picked out.
author: Caesar A.

description:
A little restaurant hidden in the Sunset, Terra Cotta Warrior was a nice surprise to someone who has disdained the oily, artless Chinese food that so many restaurants attempt. The prices are what I'm used to, and pretty great for a San Francisco-based restaurant. 

The wait was incredibly frustrating and the reason I knocked off a star. We were a party of 5 but wrote 4+1 because we had a small child with us. Given the small space, most tables could only seat 2-4. There were about 5 groups after us, and they all got to go in before we did. Then when a table that looked big enough to seat us opened up, one of the servers called my name, asked who our +1 was, and then told us "wait" (like we hadn't been doing that already) and seated another 4-person group. It ended up being about an hour-long wait while we watched other tables beadily.

Once we got seated, the experience was a lot better. Our food arrived within minutes, and we would clear each plate in seconds. The mian pi is cool and slippery, and I think it was made with garlic oil. We also ordered the pita and lamb soup. I've had this at other places, and I always thought the pita was really gross, but I loved this dish. The soup was so flavorful, the lamb tender, and the pita was soaked with flavor. The lamb sandwich was really oily and got all over our fingers, but once again, so good! We were worried that we didn't have enough to eat because of the small size of the dishes, but the chicken plate was huge and loaded with tender chicken, soft potatoes, and saucy noodles. We ended up having to take leftover chicken home. 

Service was good, excluding the seating issues in the beginning. Our waiter was good with responding quickly to our requests, which is more than I can say for most Chinese restaurants. 

And now my mouth is watering again.
author: Sophie W.

description: Ate here on 10/26/17 and found multiple hairs in my food. Sesame sauce was rancid. Noodles were soggy. This restaurant used to be good but food sanitation and quality have evaporated, and so have the lines.
author: Zhixi L.

description: The noodles were amazing but the service left something to be desired. They always have a wait, so my party of two shared a table with a party of three rather than continuing to wait. I was surprised that it took them much longer than average to get the check sorted when they had so many people waiting and we were ready to leave.
author: Rachelle D.

description:
Great food, horrible service. For the past few months, every time I think about going there I have an internal debate whether the food is worth the abuse you get from the waiters. But I am a sucker for their lamb burgers and those damn delicious noodles. It's like being in an abusive relationship that you can't get out, instead of being with a person, it's with an restaurant...

The service wasn't always this bad when I first stared going there 3 years ago. It's horrible now by any standard. I'm sure they know what they are doing, they do it because they can get away with it. Came here as a group of six last time, they refused to make certain dishes and didn't properly explain why. Very pushy about ordering as soon as you sit down. They didn't allow to order more food after the initial order. What? I'm trying to give you more money!
author: Hao L.

description:
Totally enjoyed a recent visit to Terra Cotta Warrior. We had a dish with prawns and bok choy that was super delish, bok choy cooked to perfection. Also one of the noodle dishes....there are so many to chose from and I can't remember which we had but it was great. I don't think you could go wrong with any of the noodles....

The only sort of disappointment was the ma po tofu, which didn't seem to have much meat at all in it. Still good flavor though....and we'll be back. 

Go early to avoid a long wait.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
A-OK is exactly how I would rate this place. You read my mind Yelp. 

You know its authentic when:
-the people who actually cook the food speak the language
-the tables are stickier than glue
-you can smell the food a block down 

::FOOD::
**FYI, Im no expert in Xi'an food, in fact it's my first time so I prob dont know much**
Pita Bread soaked in lamb soup 9.25: i didnt quite grasp the concept of this dish. it was literally a big bowl of soup with mochi texture balls and small pieces of lamb scattered throughout the bowl with tiny thin strands of clear vermicelli noodles. I dont like lamb, and it was boiled so much it was soft and melt in your mouth texture. There was absolutely no grimey-ness to it at all which was good. But nothing too special. In fact the bowl was 75% the mochi balls. I didnt quite understand pita bread part? 
Qishan minced pork noodle soup 8.95: I choked every 10 seconds I was eating this. Don't get me wrong. it was GOOD but it was so spicy it caught me by surprise. This was super flavorful with the thick noodles. I know it said MINCED pork, but I wish.... it was bigger haha. It was the size of a lady bug. I like my meat so it would have been nice to actually have a bite of it with my noodles. Other than that, pretty bold flavors with a lot of spice so BEWARE non-spicy eaters like me. 

::Service/Atmosphere/Parking::
Service was decent. One of the waiters noticed we were struggling with the never ending noodles and gave us a pair of scissors after we fought them noodles for 3 minutes. THANK YOU. All the other ones were quite emotionless. 
We came on a Thursday around 7:30pm and we were seated within 10 minutes. 
Atmosphere was pretty loud like any other restaurant. Tables were definitely sticky. Did not want to touch it at all hahaha. 
Parking sucks ofc, since its in the sunset area. But we managed to find residential parking 1 block away.

Yes, the price seems a bit high. But it's SF (so sad that this is the excuse for everything now). The portions were pretty big. My friend and I could not finish the food. But it was probably because both were soup based so we got full quick too.
author: Chena N.

description:
I'm generally skeptical of Chinese food in the Bay Area as it's usually not very authentic, so when a restaurant has a touristy name, I'm even more wary. That being said, I thought the food at Terra Cotta Warrior was very good. I would give it 4 stars but it wasn't exactly all Shaanxi cuisine, so I downgraded by one to 3 stars.

Must Haves:

1. Mianpi: this in my opinion is the most authentic. It's spicy but on the refreshing side, so it's a great appetizer. I like that there are little bits of bread soaked in the sauce.

2. Tofu skin and celery: this is a cold dish that is not spicy, but it'll save you from all the other spicy dishes. This is a very homey dish that only Chinese people know to order, so if you want an authentic experience, get this.

3. Spicy pork or lamb cumin sandwich: these are the two best ones, don't get the regular pork. Very flavorful but very spicy as well, so beware!

Other good dishes:

4. Spicy lung and tendon: this is a Sichuan dish, but one of my favorites. Very numbing spicy, so beware. But it's really good. My friend described it as a spicy bacon, so I guess that's a good thing, huh?

5. Spicy chicken in gravy: not sure what this is one the menu, but it's basically the most expensive dish there is (and even then it's only $21). It's humongous, so only order this if you're 4+ people. It's basically a slightly sweet and very spicy chicken dish in a gravy-ish sauce, served over hand pulled noodles. It's really good, very hearty and delicious.

Prices are very reasonable here. If you're in a group, you'll average maybe $25 here  for each person, which is such a steal considering you'll pay more for less authentic Chinese food elsewhere.
author: Sherry L.

description: The food is not even authentic. Also the food is very salty. The noodle taste like having at least 3 spoons of salt in there. Very bad customer service when asking to change the noodle.
author: Mohan Z.

description: This place has the worst customer service that I have ever experienced. They asked us, party of 3, to sit at a table for 2 people. We asked whether we can switch table. The waitress said they were busy and told us to wait in line again. Do not recommend this place.
author: Allen H.

description: Definitely one of the best (if not the best) hand pulled noodle places in the city.   Just need to ask for less salt in all the dishes.
author: Jing C.

description:
The last time I was in Xi'an it was over 12 years ago, I was with my cousin, who astonished me with his woman-in every-port swinging single lifestyle. This being early 2000s China, made it seemed even more scandalous. I did benefit from this, because I had a very nice tour guide, who was his Xi'an girlfriend: she took me everywhere and introduced me to Chinese muslim food. I hung out at Xi'An's muslim quarter and ate nothing but lamb soup with pita bread, or a variation of it. I had dumplings and buns, I had every kind of food that was made of flour and wheat. Then I ate more of that. That trip impressed me so much so that I've been on a hunt for that special brand of pita bread in lamb soup everywhere. That hunt was unsuccessful until I read about Terra Cotta Warrior's opening. One time we were riding the N Judah line to the beach and I saw the line out of the door at this place, this made me wanting to come here more. We drove over here one evening after dark for a pre Chinese New Year meal.

The cold dishes, especially jelly fish salad was quite delicious, so was the cucumber dish and mini burger style buns. Just as I had remembered but way better ingredients than what you'd find in China in general. The main thing to get is 羊肉泡馍, aka Paomo, wiki it and you get the gist of this dish: levin bread crumbs soaked in lamb stew. It reminds me a bit of Irish lamb stew, actually, but the pita bread in small pieces reminded me nothing of Irish, only that it's also not stereotypical Chinese, it's Chinese muslim from Shaanxi region.

Legend has it, once the Song emperor was down and out, and his people fetched him some soup and he soaked his hardened bread into it, and made do. When he was the emperor of China, he became reminiscent of his humble past and made this a national dish of a sort. 

For me, the best part was to order in my flawless Pekingese mandarin, communicate to the staff without missing a beat, get the dishes I'd get in China, and watch my (white) companion say, "This does not taste like Chinese food." It was a great opening for me to tell him the story I just told you.  

My cousin eventually got married. He did not marry his Xi'An girlfriend. I was saddened by that, because that girl was the best Xi'An tour guide I'd ever had.  I don't know if I'd return to Xi'an anytime soon. So for the time being, I shall take any person who's been to Xi'an, who's not good at speaking Chinese, to this restaurant, 1. to show off; 2. to eat what I like to eat; 3. to retell a story of a happier, simpler life back when I was traveling through China.
author: Victoria E.

description: I used to like this place. They offers spicy and tasty Chinese food that is different from the ordinary Chinese restaurants. But the recent visit got me really concerned about their cleanness. The glass tea pot was full of stains and grease. The table was sticky. I'm usually not a picky on it because most Chinese dishes cooked hot. But eating their cold dishes, I  feel uncomfortable by observing such poor hygiene practice.
author: L C.

description:
The service is horrible!
Came here with my girl friend today. The place is small and there are some people waiting in line. After we took the seats, the waitress came ask if we could place the order. My girl friend is picky for food and likes selecting the dishes after closely looking through the menus, so we asked for more minutes. About two minutes later, the waitress came again. We asked could we order some first, adding some later. But the waitress refused claiming there were too many people waiting. So we said we still need some time, then she went away sulkly. After after that, there came another guy who seemed to be the waitress's superior, asking if we could place the order and told us to be quick. We said OK, we were ready. Then, that guy went away and we were left there for about ten minutes! We waved to the waitress and they just told us to wait. 
The food is not good neither. The lamb is thin and the so called lamb soup doesn't look like made from true lamb but some artificial ingredients. We can't understand why such a terrible restaurant stays open.
author: Chao W.

description:
They obviously raised their price after new years. However this place remains popular and the food is still very good.

I am a fan of the Shan xi mian pi, and hot and sour soup. 

For the Da pan chicken plate, I am not sure.. it's too oily for me. 

Overall service is good.

One bad part is the parking... just as all the other restaurants in SF, parking is a pain.
author: Emma Y.

description: Food is okay, service???? What's is that? I don't think that "service " is in their dictionary. "None service "except the time they want you to pay, so that they can clear the table for the next customers. They don't care if you still eating or not when they give you the bill & dare to charge 18%tip when there was no service. Address the issue with the one who claimed to be the manager in the restaurant, if they are aware of they are busy all the time then tell the owner to hire more help instead of providing bad or no service to the customer, because without the customers they won't make the money to paid the employees or their bills. Maybe they just don't care, let see how long this business will last with the way they are running now. If there is the option for no stars I definitely won't put a star for this restaurant's service
author: Ivonne N.

description:
Awww yisss. Xi'an food don't get much better than this.

I'm telling you before you leave San Francisco that you gotta try this Xianxi flat noodles in all of its spicy sauce goodness. The hand-pulled noodles' texture is just perfect, with flavors covering every inch possible.

If you're looking for flavor overdrive, do try the lamb cumin dish as it packs an equal, if not more flavorful punch.

Oh, feeling even more adventurous, you say? Go for a dish packed of chili peppers with the Szechuan beef! That'll get you talkin'.

When a place gives you memories of NYC's Xi'an food scene, you gotta be in the right place. Killer food. Old school vibes. Bring an appetite or some friends, because it's take a while to try their whole menu.
author: Anthony N.

description:
It was okay...too spicy for my taste. If you're into spicy things, this is your place. We arrived around 6:45pm and waited maybe 10 minutes for a table, not too bad even though the place was packed.

Had the lamb burger, so spicy http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/terra-cotta-warrior-san-francisco?start=100&select=8NKnrAexr-EV1-3nzAShEg#8NKnrAexr-EV1-3nzAShEg

Qishan minced pork noodles, the chewy noodles yummm and it was a tad spicy http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/terra-cotta-warrior-san-francisco?start=100&select=XhOzdhtDSSeBtMV_8HMI-Q#XhOzdhtDSSeBtMV_8HMI-Q

Mapo tofu, it was a good amount of spicy when I had this with the rice, I think I had a good rice to tofu ratio so it wasn't spicy spicy http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/terra-cotta-warrior-san-francisco?start=100&select=Y3hpxi4lgIVQKzA-TGps3w#Y3hpxi4lgIVQKzA-TGps3w

Beef lung, tasted way better than it sounds, tastes kind of like chinese beef jerky yummmm didn't taste like heart or intestines which I assumed it would http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=CAveDmi9tYg3Gbs9VVnm2Q&select=snZGh35f7gpyVKKBqlCTRA

I really liked this because it wasn't spicy, the pita bread was chewy and interesting and the lamb was thinly sliced http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/terra-cotta-warrior-san-francisco?start=100&select=gUYxOU7zq9gIaHJTQvE7Xw#gUYxOU7zq9gIaHJTQvE7Xw

But the best thing we had was the herbal tea http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/terra-cotta-warrior-san-francisco?start=100&select=yj6dH3g_n7TuYG_macLt9A#yj6dH3g_n7TuYG_macLt9A it was worth $2.50 even though I'm sure you could buy this for $1 elsewhere. It tasted like a grass jelly drink without the grass jelly. This item gets 5 stars on it's own. My mouth felt so cool after I drank it.

The waiter we had didn't speak English or Canto, only Mandarin but they will understand you if you speak any of those.
author: Kylie L.

description: This place is good, but if you're coming from NYC and expecting Xi'an Famous Foods, you might be a little disappointed.
author: Nick A.

description: Worst service, pushing us to finish our food asap. We ordered the meat, but the meat was still raw. They ended up took it back and "redone" it. But obviously it was the same dish.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I actually really like this place despite it's rather subpar Yelp reviews. I remember a friend once telling me that he judges his Chinese restaurants by how badly they violate health regulations. Seems like this place gets a lot of flack for not meeting health regulations/having bad service--I was fortunate enough to not have to experience either of those things when I went.

A friend and I came for an early dinner on a Sunday night. When we arrived, the place was pretty empty (around 5pm), but once we left around 6pm, a line was already going out the door. For a pretty isolated restaurant, it gets quite a bit of business for the right reasons.

Terra Cotta Warrior has a few stand out dishes that other Yelpers have also mentioned. They have the Shanxi mian pi which is a typical Shanxi dish and a minced pork noodle soup that I absolutely loved. The noodles are made in-house and SO good. The soup is basically the best sweet and sour soup that I've ever had with some amazingly chewy and flavorful noodles. My friend and I also got the dried bean curd appetizer.

Shanxi mian pi--I liked this though I found it to be very spicy and on the drier side of spicy. I'm not an expert in Shanxi food, but I thought this was decently good

Minced pork noodle soup--YES. This is really what hits the 5-star mark for me. This bowl of noodles is fantastic. Don't let all the red scare you--it's actually not that spicy, but the noodles are sooo good. It also comes in a gigantically large bowl, so you're better off ordering one and sharing with a friend rather than just getting one for yourself. Seriously, the portion is absurd.

Dried bean curd--good, but it felt like they put way too much pepper into the thing.

Service was pretty good for us even though I spoke in English. I always find that speaking in Chinese at Chinese restaurants gets you better service, but didn't quite feel like it that day. They were great at taking our order and addressing needs like grabbing more tea or water. The food also comes out just as quickly as food comes out in China--literally in minutes. It felt like we had just put in our order before food came right out.

Final bill was $23 for two. Credit card minimum is $25. Pretty sweet bargain

tldr; one of my favorite noodle spots in SF!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Four stars, because while there were several things I'd like to see them improve upon, they're largely easy changes. Plus overall, I enjoyed the food, and the service was prompt and courteous. 

We tried the scallion oil chicken, the cumin lamb burger, the mian pi with sesame sauce, and the lamb noodle soup. 

Scallion oil chicken: good flavor, but there was too much oil on the plate - it kind of drowned the chicken near the end. The portion was small, but at 4.95 to be expected.

Cumin lamb burger: probably my favorite! Great flavor in the filling, and the texture of the bread was a great complement. One qualm was that the filling was too oily (sensing a pattern?), and the oil soaked through the bottom bun, making things a bit messy. Reduce the oil and this is an absolute winner.

Mian pi with sesame sauce - didn't really enjoy. Ok, so I'm comparing this to the mian pi I once had at a Lanzhou themed restaurant in Beijing, but first and foremost, I think it would be vastly improved if the chili oil and sesame sauce were served in little dishes on the side so you can customize your flavors. The sesame sauce also seemed really clumpy, not smooth and easily mixed like I was expecting. Finally, the noodle was a bit softer and stickier than I was expecting - not a huge deal, but not really what I was looking for texturally.

Lamb noodle soup: highly recommend! There were tender slices of lamb, handmade noodles with great texture, and a really flavorful broth. Other components were a bit of bok choy, and leeks and cilantro for garnish. I would definitely get this again as well.

Overall, I'm a fan of the flavors, and I like their variety of noodles and breads - they definitely fill a niche in Chinese cuisine in the area that isn't really present. Just tone it down on the oil a little!
author: Delia Z.

description: The waiter was ignorant and rude when I went there by myself. They didn't claim that they don't accept 1 person nor they said that when I arrived. The waiter just ignored me and arranged seats for customers who arrived after me. After a while another waiter came and put me on the bar seat without any explanation or apologies. It was the worst experience I've ever had.
author: Yaretzi Z.

description:
My friends took me here on a recent trip to the Bay and I want to go back just for Terra Cotta.

We got there towards 9PM on a Friday and were seated within half an hour. I think we missed the dinner rush. I was told the wait can be over an hour. 

Once seated the waiter was quick to get us drinks and our order shortly after. Fortunately, my friends went there often and knew exactly what to order. The restaurant is family style, so you just order a few different items for everyone to share.

There is a popular chicken dish that sells out relatively soon after opening. I guess I will (wait really, really early to) try that dish next time. 

On this trip, I tried the Pork Lungs, several different noodle dishes, and soup. I would recommend trying the Pork Lungs. It sounds strange and also gives your mouth a tingling feeling when eating it, but definitely worth trying.  The noodles were amazing! I believe they are made fresh daily.

I don't think you could go wrong ordering anything here.

Planning my next trip to the Bay around going to this restaurant. ;P
author: Jessica P.

description:
Terra Cotta Warrior is a great little gem near Golden Gate Park. They don't take reservations, so everyone has to write their name on a notepad when they come in, and the restaurant will call your name once they are ready. There isn't much else around the area, except a liquor store and an ice cream shop, so you'll most likely be standing in the restaurant waiting for your name to be called, and that could take a while. We had to wait about 45 min. 

The interior is nothing fancy. It looks like your classic Chinese restaurant, with some Asian decor on the walls. Which is fine, because everyone comes here for the food! Not the decor. They serve complimentary tea when you sit down. And the food was pretty outstanding. However, they were out of ALL of the Shaanxi mian-pi dishes...which was the main reason we came to their restaurant. So that was a bummer, but there is always next time. We ordered: 

- Pork with hot pepper burger: The bread was like a fluffy naan with a perfect crunch on the outside. The pork was shredded and cooked in a delicious, rich spicy sauce. Great for 2 people to share.
- Qishan minced pork noodles: This was my favorite dish of the night. The noodles were silky and you can tell they were handmade. The pork was a great addition to the dish. And the broth that the noodles were in had a red color. It tasted spicy and smoky and just had incredible flavor. The dish was very big, it could probably serve 2-3 people.
- Noodles with sizzling oil: This was also a very large dish. My husband and I could only finish half of it. The noodles were very thick and dense, and tasted amazing. It didn't have much sizzling oil though, so that part was confusing. The noodles were mostly tossed with spices. We took some of our broth from the Qishan minced pork noodles dish and put it on top of these noodles which made it taste better.

Overall the food was great. I definitely want to come back and try the Shaanxi mian-pi dishes since that's what everyone raves about. The service was the only disappointment. The entire staff was not friendly or welcoming. They all move very quick and are in a hurry. I feel that their mission is to turn tables as fast as possible. I think their mindset is "get in, sit down, eat, get out." We only saw our server twice. Once to take our order, and once to give us our bill. They aren't accommodating and don't check in to see if you need anything else. I don't think their customers mean much to them - they just want to give you your food and then turn the table for the next party.
author: Chisholm T.

description: Really good Chinese food. We loved the lamb soup with the dough bits in it, and the Chinese burger. I'm Chinese and have never eaten cuisine from Shaanxi, which is where the food is from! Will probably try to take my Asian parents here. It was really crowded on a Saturday night, but the wait is so worth.
author: Claire L.

description: Super rude staffs. Dirty floor which is very slippery. Not taking credit card unless you order $25+
author: Melissa W.

description:
All 4 stars I give for food, -1 for customer service . Honestly I have been there too many times, but after this time, will never ever come back.
How can they ask us to leave immediately after finishing food, we were even asked to check when we haven't finished our food. Huge disappointed for this place!!!!
author: Cici T.

description: terrible attitude. the waiters are just not helpful at all. they ask people to leave immediately after they finish food.
author: Yixing C.

description: I have been here enough times, and have given this restaurant plenty of chances because of the food.  Food, 4 stars.  Service is BELOW 1 star! Tasty food here. But the girl who works there. Omg!  Every single visit, she acts like she is either on pms or just finished an argument with someone.  Please!  If you are so unhappy in customer service. You should not be a waitress! She might be related to the owner, that's why she wasn't fired?  I honestly like the food there, but every time when I think about this girls service and attitude, it turns me away to other noodle house. Sorry this is not China, customer service means a lot here even if you provide good food!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Great Chinese food and swift, efficient service! Excellent hand-pulled noodles with amazing and unique texture! 

I came here with a friend on a Friday night, and it was packed. They asked us if we wanted to be seated immediately at the bar, and we agreed. However, it was extremely cramped, with other customers' chairs in our way. One of the servers saw our situation and offered us the small table reserved for the takeout orders! It was much more comfortable and roomy. 

We ordered the garlic pigs' ears ($6.25), noodles with sliced beef ($9.95), and Shanghai stir-fry wide noodles, non-spicy ($9.95). The garlic pigs' ears came first as our cold appetizer. Even though it's labeled spicy on the menu, I didn't taste any spiciness, (coming from someone who cannot handle spiciness at all). Half the dish was thinly sliced cucumbers and the other half was the pigs' ears. It was my first time having it, and I found the pigs' ears' texture pretty interesting. It was slightly crunchy, but also chewy, definitely an acquired taste.

The noodles with sliced beef also delicious. It was a soup noodle with beef slices, cilantro, green onions, and bamboo shoots. The beef slices were cooked just right, not too rare and not too dry and overcooked. But the hand-pulled noodles were the highlight. They were chewy and thick and irregular. Fun to eat and complemented the soup.

The Shanghai stir-fry was also excellent. We asked for them to make it non-spicy. It had a unique taste: sour and tomato-y. In it was chicken, ginger, and onions. (Beware the little slices of ginger! It has quite the intense flavor.) It also featured the hand-pulled noodles, once again the highlight of the dish.
author: Grace C.

description:
Probably my favorite restaurant in the city. How did this happen?!

My family's from Beijing, and this place totally reminds me of home, only everything is slightly oilier. But in a delicious chili way.

Here's what I totally recommend:
- Mixed cold shredded potatoes
- Pork lungs in chili sauce
- Sir-fried lamb with cumin
- Cumin lamb burger
- Qishan minced pork noodles

Here's what's just okay:
- Lotus root slices
- Mapo tofu
- Noodles with lamb

If it weren't so far away, I'd probably eat here once a week, and get through the entire menu as quickly as possible! Totally obsessed.
author: Shendi X.

description:
Came here for dinner with my parents on a Sunday night around 5:30 and there wasn't a wait, but shortly after we got there the restaurant was packed! The atmosphere is very nice and clean, they have lots of waitresses and food came out pretty fast. 

We ordered:
Shanxi noodles- thick wide noodles with spicy oil, bean sprouts, cubes of bread, and cucumber, a little spicy and sour served cold (very oily)

Lamb pita soup: three slices of lamb (not too gamey), fungus, clear noodles, and "pita"-blocks of dumplings. Soup was a little flavorless. 

Minced pork noodles: chewy noodles in a spicy broth, fungus, carrots, potatoes, pork cubes (not really minced pork)

Hot sour soup pork dumplings: not your typical hot and sour soup but so good!! The dumplings on their own are good too

Garlic spinach: pretty greasy but good

Over all we enjoyed our meal, everything was pretty good and would order again except the lamb pita soup. We will definitely be back to try their main/meat dishes. 

The restaurant gets pretty busy so come before 6 if you don't want to wait. Food comes out fast and prices are VERY reasonable.
author: Linz C.

description: Kind of alright, like it's not particularly bad xian food but it's definitely not among the good ones in terms of flavor. The price was ok but the restaurant is pretty small and not particularly inviting.
author: Danielle A.

description: Terrible service I've ever received！！！ All the dished were almost thrown to our table. We took 25 mins to finish our dinner and the glass waitress came to tell us check sooner. NEVER COME BACK AGAIN  They need to learn how to be a waiter.
author: 迪

description:
There's nothing I have not enjoyed from here, no lie.  Disclaimer - I am on the experimental side with food and find it difficult to find something I actually don't like.  When coming to Terra Cotta Warrior, be prepared to wait because usually for dinner they will be busy.  Just put your name down on the legal pad at the front and maybe waive down one of the waitresses for an estimate on the wait time.  Also, they don't like to seat you unless your whole party is here, so try to come all at once.  If you like Chinese food from the Shaanxi Province, you will really enjoy the food here.  If you are into Lemon Chicken or Mongolian Beef with fortune cookies at the end, turn around and run the other way!

Came here on a Sunday night around 7pm to have dinner with mom and brother.  We ordered:

- Shaanxi Mian Pi (stir-fried wide noodles) - 4.25
- Qishan Minced Pork Noodles (hand-pulled noodles in a chili oil broth) - 8.95
- Noodles with Sizzling Oil - 9.25
- Baby Bok Choi (because they were out of the Water Spinach)

Everything was so tasty. What I ended up doing towards the end is dunking the Noodles with Sizzling Oil into the broth of the Qishan Minced Pork Noodles - soooo YUMMY.  I will be back to try some other dishes I saw on tables around us.
author: Elisha Y.

description: Like their homemade noodles. A taste of home. Though appitizer dishes and their service are so so
author: Danyang W.

description: This two star is not for the food, just for the service!  The female owner is always angry and unhappy. Never see smile on her face. She seems frustrated with too many customers on the waiting list. I feel sorry that I come here to add more job to her.
author: Ziyu Z.

description:
Super authentic dishes from Shanxi province.  The lamb soup with pita is so darn good and so addictive.  The giant plate of spicy chicken with noodle has a great spicy kick but make sure  chicken, sauce and noodle are well mixed.

Unfortunately, I've had to call them out a few times for forgetting a dish or two and were sneaky about still slipping the charges on the bill, so beware.
author: Angel W.

description: Not bad. But had better ones at xi'an china. Well, can't really compare to the source
author: John C.

description:
My favorite Chinese restaurant in the city. Food comes out super fast, it's cheap ($45 for 3 people!!) and everything is delicious. 

I always get the Qishan Noodle soup. It's so good! The lamb with pancake bites soup is pretty good too. The lamb with cumin burger is also great. (I'm probably translating this all wrong)

I also like getting their cold potato appetizer dish and some of the cold dishes. I wish it was closer to where I live, but I've gone here a handful of times and I take tourists there too!
author: Joanna S.

description:
One of the best Chinese restaurant I've ever had!!! I'm a big fan of spicy food and pretty much all dishes they have are SPICY!!
my favorite dish was qushin minced pork noodle soup. OMG, I can eat this everyday. Also their noodle is hand pulled not factory made!! this makes huge difference.
This restaurant is not located in main street but busier than any other restaurants on Irving. MUST GO place in Sunset district.
author: Woong C.

description:
I came here with a few friends to grab an early dinner after the Hardly Strictly Bluegrass Festival. I'm normally never in the GGP / Sunset area and had to take advantage of all the different Asian foods out here.

We could tell this restaurant was popular when there was already a line forming around 5pm. There's a clipboard with a list by the hostess table for you to put your name. We only waited ~10 mins. on a Saturday evening for our group of 4. Service was a little slow to begin but we got our food pretty quickly after placing our orders.

There are oodles of noodle choices here and they are all super delicious. I highly recommend getting any of the NOODLE SOUP dishes and you won't be disappointed, especially on a cool SF day! If you're like me and enjoy lamb hot pot, then I would go with any of the noodle soups that have a lamb soup base--they're very flavorful and don't skimp on the meat or noodles. Each bowl can easily be split between two people! 

I also liked the SHAANXI MIANPI for a mix of cool and spicy in your mouth. This makes a great appetizer to share or as a small entree for yourself. In addition, I ordered a LAMB BURGER because I missed getting these in Shanghai. It had a good amount of spice but the meat was a bit tough; I had better ones in Chinatown NY. 

The prices are very reasonable (appetizers ~$4-8, entrees ~$8-10) and the portions are large. I think the quality of food is also pretty authentic.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars. If you have a vegetarian friend, take them here and you'll be their new best friend. This hidden gem in Sunset is a must if you're tired of the usual SF restaurants. A good bang for your buck!!! =]

Warning: Parking can be difficult during the weekend and evenings, so please plan accordingly. 

The portions are not massive, so make sure to order a lot. 2-3 orders for 2 guys? No. I advise at least 4 or more. Plus, they are all relatively inexpensive too :) Try something new, or ask for a recommendation from a nearby neighbor or the waiter. 

Like any other Chinese restaurant, getting service could be hit and miss. Fortunately, it didn't take too long. My water glass was probably filled once, but it wasn't a big deal since we had tea. 

We ordered:
Hot and Sour Pork Dumpling Soup
Shaanxi Mian-Pi 
Chilled Spinach 
Noodles with sizzling oil 
Chinese Pork Burgers

The Shaanxi Mian-Pi and Noodles with sizzling oil were both a huge hit! I loved them so much. I was pleasantly surprised neither of the dishes had meat. Both of these noodles were drenched in massive amounts of flavor and oil. If I ever venture to this establishment again ( which I might!!), I would definitely add at least one of these to my order. I really hope my arteries won't hate me too much. 

The Chinese Pork Burgers.. just forget them. The appetizer was dry as the Sahara Desert.

The Hot and Sour Pork Dumpling Soup tasted pretty standard and wasn't too memorable. The dumplings did taste homemade, which is a plus. 

The Chilled Spinach did have an interesting garlic taste. It wasn't bad, but the food definitely could be forgettable. The subtle taste... was just subtle and nothing else. 

Overall, this place is pretty good with their reasonably priced menu options. I would definitely come again!
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Wow! I'm so impressed with their noodles in sizzling oil! The texture of the noodle is perfectly chewy... I haven't had such good noodles since my last Japan trip! These noodles reminded me of the best udon noodles I've had. Sure the noodles are a bit oily, but that's much of the dishes from that area in China... Spicy with powerful flavors, you add salt and soy sauce to balance that out. So knowing that, I didn't think this was too salty because the salt really did help balance out the spiciness, and you can add some table vinegar to taste. 

I also tried their pita bread soaked in lamb soup. The lamb soup had good flavor. The 'pita bread' was more like a hand-cut noodle type texture but cut into small cubes. There were also mung bean noodles in that so overall it was an interesting dish with various textures. 

Would definitely come back for the noodles in sizzling oil and to try other dishes! Customer service was great. The restaurant was clean and they use cute some dishes/cups! Sign up on the wait list by the door. Closed on Mondays. Minimum credit card charge $15 and max one credit card per table.
author: Iris H.

description:
Came here on a friend's recommendation and I'd happily recommend this restaurant to others as well! Between the six of us we had three pork burgers (Chinese styled minced pork in a pita-bread like bun), two spicy cold noodles (Szechuan and Shan Xi styled), shredded Chinese cabbage with pork belly, stir-fried wide noodles, lamb with cumin, Shan Xi styled spicy noodle soup, and noodle soup with pita (not spicy). I thought all of the food was pretty good but I'd skip out on the lamb and the stir-fry noodles next time as the lamb had too much cumin and the stir-fry noodles were a bit generic. All of us came out quite full at close to 20 dollars each but we probably overate. 

Some of the and across the board the food definitely had more than just a modest amount of oil. Maybe you can ask for the amount of oil to be toned down a notch but I don't know how reliant the taste of the food is on the amount of oil they use.

One of my friends that I was with claimed that this was some of the closest food to authentic Shan Xi/Xi'An food he's had since he left New York and would take his parents here if. He's not the biggest foodie but I'd still say that speaks to the satisfaction people can get from the food here. 

Service was kind and they kept our tea pot filled and were patient with our slower than average pace of ordering. The space is quaint and is a bit tight but it's not uncomfortable.
author: Eric S.

description: 服务奇差！The custom service was extremely horrible!!! One older waitress always tried to take away my food and even my clean napkin without asking me at all. I just asked why you take my napkin away and then she started to yield at me and quarrel with me! And she yielded that all the waiters and waitresses said I'm very tough. What??! I'm from Xi'an and telling the truth the food is not so close to our local taste. It's definitely my worst experience ever!
author: Dan S.

description: This place is the bees knees. I haven't had shaanxi noodles in forever, and this place has satisfied my craving. Everything we ordered was delicious!
author: Elly F.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF. You have to know what you're ordering - we love the small dishes (cucumber, bean curd and celery, xianxi mian-pi) and the sizzling oil noodles. Great vegetarian options here, and the servers are all really nice.
author: Cando W.

description:
Nothing will ever beat my love of Xi'an Famous Foods in NYC, but the food here is really, really tasty and frankly excellent Shaanxi cuisine for San Francisco.  I look forward to coming back sometime!

We arrived around 8:45 for dinner last night (Tuesday), and the place was pretty packed (although we got seated immediately - not THAT ridiculously pack).  Impressive for the day/time - clearly, people like what they're putting down at Terra Cotta Warrior.  They pretty quickly brought us a pot of tea, though we did have to ask twice before we got water.

For dinner, we had the cucumber salad, the cumin lamb burger, the Qishan minced pork noodles, the noodles with sizzling oil, the noodles with lamb, and the Shaanxi braised spicy fish.  Definitely a lot of food for two people - could have taken two noodle dishes off easy....but we wanted to make sure we tried everything.  We had wanted to also get the famed Shaanxi mian-pi, but they were all out, sadly.

The cucumber salad, cumin lamb burger, noodles with sizzling oil, and braised fish were all amazingly delicious.  I would absolutely get all of these items again, and I even considered getting a second order of cucumber salad to go last night (we annihilated them).  Everything had the perfect balance of salt and spices.  Plus, the cook on everything was excellent - nothing was over- or under-cooked, nothing was oily (beyond expected chili oil "topping") or fatty, etc.  We actually didn't really love the Qishan minced pork noodles despite thehype - thought they were kind of bland and had too much potato (weirdly...) - and we definitely didn't love the noodles with lamb - that was the MOST flavorless thing.  So lacking in salt or seasoning or spices...  

I'm excited to go back for all of the things we did love, however, and to try the Shaanxi mian-pi.
author: Tay H.

description: My friend from Sacramento came to visit and she recommended we go to Terra Cotta Warrior. It was delicious with the spicy oil noodles etc, the environment was chill, decent setting, good amount of seats, you could wait in line but we went on a good day when it was low in customers. The services was good, servers offered tea first and our meals came after. Overall good place for a flavorful meal!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Busy busy! Saturday night was packed and there was a long line out the door so we got to go bc we were hungry.

We ordered:
-Chinese burger with pork: pass. After a few bites I got tired of the taste. It's basically pulled pork on a bao bun. I saw someone order the pork with hot pepper and that looked really good! So try the other options but the regular pork is not worth it 

-qishan minced pork noodles: Yum! So good. The pulled noodles were perfect! And the soup has so much flavor. Interestingly it has small cubes potatoes in it too. The "minced pork" is more like thin sliced diced pork. Almost like bacon. Portion wise my BF and I shared this and it was good size between the two of us (see our photo which we portioned off into our own bowls bc again we took it to go) 

Overall I would come back to try their other dishes. Def order from their specialty side of the menu bc the other dishes looked a bit uninspiring. 

Tip: $25 min on credit card and one credit card per table. Call in to go if it's on Saturday night bc it's busy!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Four stars because this is authentic Shanxi province food, at least according to my dinner mate who comes from this region of China. I don't particularly like this style of cuisine, but that is a matter of personal preference. I appreciate the authenticity nevertheless. 

One of the best things about the Bay Area culinary scene is that you don't have to settle for generic food like "Asian food" or "Chinese restaurant."  Restaurant featuring specific regional cuisines offer much deeper exploration into different styles of cooking. Shanxi style has a nice mix of spicy and sour (from greater use of vinegar), and more lamb dishes.
author: Jack L.

description:
Fantastic Chinese restaurant in town. Even my friend from LA says that this is up to the standard of Chinese food in Rowland Heights where hundreds of restaurants compete for the business of the Chinese immigrants with authentic palates.

Everything we had was excellent, and the restaurant ambience was really nice (for a change for a value-oriented Chinese restaurant.

The best dishes:
Shaanxi Mian-Pi  -- so authentic and balanced in flavor with a bit of spice. delicious!

QISHAN MINCED PORK NOODLES -- a bit sour in taste but excellent. the noodle had the perfect texture

Noodle with lamb -- very flavorful. the lamb is so tender that it started falling apart to pieces when it's fished out of the soup

CELERIES with dried bean curd sticks -- excellent. the bean curd is not overcooked and celeries are crunchy. just like in China

Chinese Burger with pork -- this is actually closer to a panini than a burger. crunchy bread. good quality pork. 

One could skip:
MIXED COLD SHREDDED POTATOES -- too big of a dish, better as an appetizer size. could be a bit drier in texture.

So four people, we ate until we couldn't eat anymore and the bill was $50 between us. A fantastic deal!!!
author: Rebecca C.

description: First time here since I heard that this is the best Xi'an food in SF area and wanted to have a try. The line was surprisingly long and had to wait for like 40 min before seated. Really like pita bread in lamb soup! But the noodles are pretty similar to Xi'an famous food
author: Derek Y.

description: they didn't give the changes back，and all the things are sour！！！！！！ not enough spicy， the thing that show pepper，is sour not spicy...
author: Cindy W.

description:
This is a great little spot on Judah! I don't spend much time in this area of Sunset, but I think this place is relatively new. The bf and I spotted Terra Cotta driving by a few weeks ago and I had yelped + bookmarked it. SO glad I did.

The decor inside is very nice, a good mix between modern and traditional. It's also very clean and tidy, and bright (since it was the afternoon when we came). We were greeted immediately and seated. The menus are just brochures/pamphlets and it's pretty short, but lots of items to choose from. There's three main categories: cold dishes, hot dishes, and specialties. Prices range from $5-$15 per dish, which I think is pretty good.

We ordered the cumin lamb, noodles with sizzling oil, and the hot and sour soup with pork dumplings. Portions are pretty big -- the three dishes we ordered could've easily fed 4 people instead of just us two. 

Cumin lamb - Spicy, which I love, but was a bit too much for the bf. It comes with a ton of jalapeno slices and red chili slices. You can definitely taste the cumin, and for some reason, it also reminds me of the Taco Bell taco mix you can buy in grocery stores. Overall, very good.
Noodles with sizzling oil - Not spicy, and a bit plain in flavor. Definitely very oily haha. It also smells sour like vinegar, but you can barely taste it. It comes with a few veggies and bean sprouts. I loved the wide, flat noodles (likely handmade), but wish the dish had a bit more flavor.
Hot and sour soup with pork dumplings - Our favorite dish! The soup is definitely very sour, but very good. It is not spicy so no worries on that for people who can't handle the heat. The dumplings are SO good and go perfectly with the soup -- no need for any other dipping sauce.

Service was also nice and attentive -- had our tea refilled because the server heard the tea pot clink when I checked to see how much tea was left in it.

Definitely coming back to try more of their food!
author: Doris K.

description: Said they were too busy to make an entire section of the menu, which makes no sense, aren't you supposed to be prepared when it's busy? The restaurant was pretty much empty by 8:00, waited to be seated - which took an hour. I only wanted to order one thing, but they said the chef was too busy to even try to make the entire hot dish section of the menu. That is like going to In N Out and the guys in the back saying they are too busy to make a hamburger.
author: Wells Y.

description:
We took the N-Judah to Terra Cotta Warrior after going to CAS.  It's not very far away, maybe another 10 minute bus ride.

Place was packed on Sun even at 2pm.  I usually never eat that late for lunch so was pretty shocked to see that.  Had to wait maybe 15 minutes.

FREE hot tea given, inside was 2 tea bags, we liked the tea though. Nobody got iced water, wish we had asked at least because they food can be Spicy.

Dishes we tried:

Shaanxi Mian-Pi Sesame Sauce aka Cold noodle w/ sesame sauce $4.25 - small plate was good!  I wish I had my own dish.  Cold wide noodles w/ sesame oil and some thin cucumbers and some cubed bread.  Don't need that bread with noodles, aiya!  Still recommended.

Cucumber salad $3.95 - they cut it all in big chunky slices, tasted fine.

Spinach ginger sauce $3.95 - did they put numbing hot sauce in this?  Maybe because we thought it was spicy, but since we mixed everything hard to tell.  We liked it.

Hot sour pork dumpling soup $6.25 - huge bowl of the vinegary soup and about 9 pork dumplings.  I liked the dumplings fine, just didn't need them in the soup.

Wanted cumin lamb but they didn't make it for some reason, had waitress take it off our bill.

4 dishes for $18.40 tax $1.6 = $20 before tip!  Cheap!!  Charged it, minimum is $15, made it!

One unisex bathroom.
author: Ann L.

description: AVOID WEARING WHITE CLOTHES! The hot chili oil will get on you, one way to another! The portions are pretty big and I think meant to be shared as they gave us little bowls when we ordered two noodle dishes. It was also not that expensive! For two noodles and two appetizer the total rang up to be $33! I recommend the Qishan noodles for a tangy spicy broth. The liang pi... I would pass, it was too thick and didn't have much flavor. But the cold potatoes were a perfect appetizer! It was a tangy savory cold dish. Their tables are sticky and you can see your food in the evening with their dim light. Overall great food and service! There does seem to be a wait at prime dinner time (7:30-8pm)
author: Lianna L.

description: Real Chinese food . Not the Panda Express crap. Price is fair. A lot of people at all time. Suggest oder pick up over the phone
author: Draper K.

description:
Delicious traditional shaanxi food.  Pretty authentic. Try those on the menu with a little star in front of them if u come here for the first time. The Pita bread soaked in lamp soup could be better if the pita bread was more well-fermented and roasted and not already cut into small pieces but let customer tear it into small pieces by hand (which was the right way to do it).  Also we had Qishan minced pork noddles soup, vey delicious and a little sour if you like vinegar this ideal for you.  The other dish we had was Shaanxi mian-pi which was good too. 

A very busy restaurant.  Be a little patient, if possible come a little earlier.  You won't be disappointed.
author: A C.

description:
We waited 10 mins to get a table, ordered right away and then waited for 30 mins to get our first entree. Everyone else after us got their entrees. The other 3 dishes we ordered were nowhere to be seen after 10 more minutes of waiting, so now it's been 40 mins total. So we asked for the progress: the waitress barely said one word, and turned away. I wasn't even sure she heard me. Asked to get our check without waiting any longer. The total amount of time spent was an hour at this restaurant just on one entree. 
The kung pao chicken wasn't even flavorful... I'm sad because I was really anticipating it.
author: Alice S.
