description: Great tasting noodles. They were understaffed the night that we were there so we couldn't order any stir fry dishes - only noodles and cold plates. The cumin lamb with noodles was my favorite dish. The lamb burger was good, but the bun tasted a bit stale.
author: Amin S.

description:
The wait can be up to an hour during peak dinner times on weekends, because the restaurant only holds 38 people. We put our names in at 7:30pm on a Saturday, and weren't seated until an hour later. I think this place suddenly got popular due to the recent article in the SF Chronicle. 

Beware: This restaurant has a habit of running out of items and not telling you until you ask. i.e. They ran out of the liang pi and didn't bother to tell us.

The restaurant was very decorated with a modern, touristy touch with pictures of Terra Cotta Warriors on the wall and assorted driftwood along the walls.

The food was not bad, and some were definitely quite unique (as in you can't find them in other Chinese restaurants in SF). However, the cold dishes such as the pig's ear and  bean curd were much TOO SALTY.

I've heard that Xi'an Gourmet in Inner Richmond has the same owner, but just isn't as nicely decorated. I'd rather go there for similar food and skip the wait here.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Best cucumber cold salad... Crunchy, cilantro and sesame oil.  

Everything else is very country bumpkin good street food.  Cumin is found to in many of the dishes... Reflective of this region.  Wish the quality is higher.

Tons of yummy spicy oil, not good for your health.
No msg I can taste
author: David H.

description:
It is so good to get some northern chinese food here in the city. I didn't really grow up with dim sum and I was ready for some nooodles.

Things we got:
lamb pao mo--they call it lamb broth with pita bread. Not like the pao mo I had in Xi An, but it was close enough that it made me think of it. I wish the pita bread was more bready, and the broth was more lamb-y, but they'll get the hang of it, I'm sure.

Lamb with cumin--everything I'd been missing. Spicy, cumin-y, lamb-y. It was perfection.

Lian feng--the rice noodle with spicyness. Also pretty good.

The pork belly--not something I'd recommend, really. Thin slices, not that flavorful.

I am definitely looking forward to the next time I can come back, because mama's hungry.
author: Rosy H.

description:
Let me prelude by saying I like spicy dishes...but something here made my mouth tingle so bad that I just couldn't enjoy my meal at all halfway through. 

That said, what we ordered and what I could handle was pretty good. Started off our meal with a variety of appetizers. The thin sliced lotus with spicy oil was delicious as was the beef lung...not actual beef lung, don't worry. 

Next was the hot and sour pork dumpling soup. Dumplings were huge! And soup wasn't too hot or sour, just enough to get the buds excited. The pita bread soaked in lamb soup was next and provided a brief break from the strong flavors. It was different. The pita pieces were a little chewy, kind of like rice cakes in my opinion. Now, I'm not sure which of the following caused my tastebuds to flare...but next came the noodles in sizzling oil and cumin lamb. I just...had to tap out. We also had the shaanxi stir fried noodles which wasn't supposed to be spicy...but really didn't help my situation.

All in all, not an expensive meal. Ambiance is modern and pretty nice. Restaurant is a little drafty though and bench seating is not the most comfortable after a while.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
3.5 star place if you factor in the location (out of the way for many), long wait, average food, and almost non-existent service (if you sit in the front of the room).

Let me explain the average food, since the location, wait-time and lack of service are self-explanatory: if you've had Xi'an Famous Foods in New York, you would understand what I mean, but if you've never had Xi'an, I think the novelty of this type of Chinese cuisine would blow your palettes away (in a good way). 

The essence of Xi'an food are their snack/street food items such as Rou Jia Muo (beef/lamb burgers), cold noodles, and skewers. I was disappointed by the cold noodle as the noodle itself tasted store-bought; the noodles were hard and there just weren't that much for the money you're spending.

I would be hard pressed to come back.
author: Lee T.

description:
I would like to recommend this place to anybody who want to try traditional Chinese food. The food here is so special and full of flavors! 

The cold dishes/ appetizers here are amazing! The reserved egg w/tofu, spinach and chicken dishes are all my favorites! Highly recommended! 

The lamb soup with bread is the best! It tastes so good and authentic. 

The overall dinning atmosphere here is so creative and nice! I love their interior designs. 

I'll always come back!
author: Evelyn W.

description: One of my best place for dinner. Really like their food so good! Like their appetizer, noodle soup, always remind me I'm in China !
author: Yueming G.

description: I went here for 油泼扯面 and 孜然羊肉夹馍. As an ardent fan of 油泼扯面, I was let down by the water-y noodle which should be dry and covered by spicy oil. But overall, the food is on par with what a standard Shan Xi restaurant would offer. Just don't set your expectation too high...
author: Yuhuan T.

description: Really delicious!  Loved the minced pork hand pulled noodles and the lamb burger.  Spicy wontons were good, but not out of the world, I might pass next time.  Get there early if you want to avoid a wait.  It's no frills inside, but the food is excellent and service is efficient.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Terra Cotta Warrior's decor is really nice. subtle upscale ambience. about a dozen tables, big and small.  pursued the menu outside and decided on take out. 
glad i did.

menu: appetitzers (4ish) specials, noodles, soups, entrees, specialty.
genre: northern chinese, not cantonese, shanghaiese

eats. shredded lamb with cumin: (11.95)
-very intense heat (chilis?) made it impossible to eat it all at once,
actually took a few bites starting at lunch, finished at dinner, 6ish.
-cumin pasty like, not subtle flavoring.
-onions, peppers, chiles?, etc.
-item nbt indicated as "hot", certainly was.

takeouts:
-my concern was entrees would be too spicy and it was.
-didn't take much time to study menu, should have
-even soups looked to be very spicy
not interested in too much spice these days. stomach doesn't like, etc.
-food fresh and spiciness should be indicated.
3.5 stars
author: Victor G.

description:
I've been coming back here whenever I feel like having something spicy.  I'm in love with the Qi Shan Minced Pork Noodles.  Great noodle texture, love the spiciness with a hint of sour in the soup.  Also decided to try another of their burgers again, the Pork with Hot Peppers is worth getting.  A ton of hot peppers is between the pork and the buns, it's so good, much more flavorful than the regular Chinese Burger.
I'm still giving the same amount of stars as my previous review cause some of the items are hit and miss: Hot and Sour Pork Dumplings and the Shanxi Mian Pi.  Not a fan of these two plus some of their appetizers.
author: Karen L.

description:
Authentic and delicious food from the Shaanxi region of China. I highly recommend the spicy noodle soups, lamb dumplings and the Chinese "hamburger" -- everything was really excellent though!

Be prepared for a long wait.
author: Justine L.

description: Amazing and interesting Xian food at a great price. Very authentic flavours with big portions at a great price. Will be going back 100%.
author: Ben G.

description:
This place is paradoxal: the food is incredible but the restaurant had issues with food safety lately. Anyway, I truly enjoyed their Xian noodles and the lamb burger was absolutely delicious.
You can't beat the value for money of this place.
I will definitely come back.
author: Sebastien G.

description:
It is still my favorite spot after 30+ times visits in the past 4 years or so. 

Anyway, flavor is awesome and I vouch almost every dish here! I defend them from people commented their food is "too" spicy or "too" flavorful. Thank god! This is exactly what it should be. It may not fit perfectly with all American palate, but that is fine, because it suppose to be Chinese.
author: James M.

description:
I checked out Terra Cotta Warrior after hearing some good things from a nice friend of mine. Located near Outer Sunset, it's a small Chinese restaurant on Judah Street.

I've never had Shan Xi food before, so I was pretty stoked to try it. Since the place is small, you may have to wait in line if you come on a weekend, but luckily my friend and I got in after 5 minutes. I have to comment on the ambiance first because the atmosphere was just right! There are beautiful paintings and pictures of Terra Cotta Warriors on the wall, interesting music playing, and lovely tables to dine on.

With a simple menu, we knew exactly what we wanted to order. We got the noodles with spicy oil, jellyfish, and twice cooked pork.

First, the noodles were AMAZING. Who knew that such a simple dish would taste so good. I will definitely try to replicate this spicy dish at home- it seems like the key ingredient is the type of spicy oil they use (it kind of reminds me of Din Tai Fung's). Next, the jellyfish was pretty good and coated with an interesting sour, vinegar- like sauce. It was a bit too sour for me, but the jellyfish was bomb.

The last item we got was the twice cooked pork. The pork itself was very tender and the chili/black bean sauce was good, but there was a weird, salty aftertaste that lingered in my mouth. I kind of didn't like this aftertaste but at least the noodles made up for it.

All in all, I had a good time at Terra Cotta. When I come back Im going to splurge on the big plate chicken and the lamb buns. I will definitely come again someday because of the atmosphere and the noodles!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
First time here, and we were unfamiliar with this kind of food. 

The food that I could eat was tasty. We tried:
+ Chicken with scallion oil: a cold dish, mostly just finely chopped white meat, very moist, tender, and salty. Very little scallion oil. A very delicate dish tasting of salty chicken.
+ Shaanxi mian pi: Very good. Fresh noodles, loved the chewy texture, in a nice chili oil sauce, served cold with julienne-cut cucumber. Didn't know this was a cold dish, since it was not listed under cold dishes but under the house specialties. 
+ Lamb with cumin: This smelled great - lamb + lots of cumin. Unfortunately, I could not eat it because it contains red bell peppers, an ingredient that was not listed on the menu and to which I have a life-threatening allergy. 
+ Shredded potatoes: Another cold dish, and another dish containing red bell peppers, so I couldn't eat this one, either. My dinner partner said it was excellent.

Portions of the things we ordered were about right for 2 people, but since I couldn't eat 2 of the dishes, my dining partner has leftovers for tomorrow. And I came home and ate a cheese sandwich.

Drinks: I ordered the canned herbal tea, but they didn't have any, so we drank beer. After the female server who wears glasses informed me that there was no canned herbal tea, she did not ask if I would like anything else, but left our table. It took a couple of tries to get her attention so I could order a beer. Meanwhile, we had eaten half of our (spicy) food. The free tea: well, you get what you pay for. Very weak tea.

Ambiance: Nice decor, not too noisy, but not a place to linger. It's about the food. Eat, pay and get out, so they can turn the tables several times a night. 

Service: We live in the neighborhood, so we called to ask about the wait. We were told there was no wait. When we arrived, maybe 10 min. later, there were several parties waiting for tables. We waited maybe 10 min., so not too bad. We might have had a shorter wait, but the female server who wears glasses skipped over us to seat another party of 2 - and I was standing right in front of her! There was a method to her madness though...read on. 

Glasses-wearing female: rude, abrupt, never smiles, seems very stressed out. In her defense, it seems that she is having to do 2 jobs in a very busy restaurant: the hostess function, plus waiting tables. I sure hope she's an owner; otherwise, she is being overworked. If she is an owner, she needs to hire another server, relax, and develop a more service-oriented persona. Or, maybe, if the food is good and reasonably priced, no one cares about the service. Except me.

A word to people on the wait list: periodically she would yell out the names of several parties on the list. But actually, they had no empty tables for these patrons at that time; she was just "taking attendance." If the patron did not speak up, she crossed their names off the list. She did not check outside, where some people had gone to wait because the front space was already full of people waiting. 

Another odd thing happened wrt the service. We (2 white people) were next on the list. She went 4 parties down the wait list, past several other parties of 2, to the next white couple, and told them that they would have to share a table. She never said anything to us about sharing a table. But she sat us and this other white couple at the same table. The asian parties of 2 that she had skipped over were then seated at tables for 2 as those became available.

So, in summary: excellent food, half of which I could not eat; abrupt, unpleasant service with a soupçon of racism. Will I return? Not likely.
author: Deb L.

description: Came here on a Sunday for lunch before the rush hour around 12pm. We were seated at a large table near the back and had 4 dishes between 3 people. We started with a cucumber salad, which is never a bad choice because it was garlicky and refreshing with all the spicy hot dishes we ordered that came soon after. Shaanxi stir-fried wide noodles was next and is my favorite out of everything we ordered - loved the noodle size with the onions, tomatoes, green bell peppers and pork! Enough flavor and not too oily like most asian dishes. We also had the braised spicy fish (spicy sauce) but the fish was good with a bit of crispy and spice to it. The Qishan pork noodle soup was my least favorite because it was too vinegar-y that lacked flavor all around. Also, the pork burger didn't wow me. Would return for the stir-fry noodles though! All for $50 including tips and tax.
author: Amanda C.

description:
We came here after a friend recommended this place. I always pass by but never thought to actually try it. After my friend was placing a pick up order, I decided to also try it for my first time. I ordered 2 dishes, twice cooked pork and their famous thick noodles with beef. 
The noodles were pretty flavorful compared to other restaurant that serve hand made thick noodles, but I wouldn't say it was the best I've ever had. The quality of meat they give was very sad. Mostly was just the noodles and a few slices of beef. I mean for a 10$ item at least have more than 5 slices. That was disappointing...
My twice cooked pork was 13$... I've never seen it to be that expensive, usually it's never more than 9-10$... yet again the quality was even less than the noodles. Very disappointing, mostly just cabbage, very few slices of pork and 1/3 of the to-go box was filled with oil... not very appetizing and definitely not worth 13$! 
I wouldn't go here again unless someone wants to try it, wouldn't be my first choice if I were to pick a restaurant let's just say. Good if you want to try it once but not worth making it a regular place to dine at.
author: Vicky C.

description: I must say I was not that impressed with this place.  We were looking for a place for my father's birthday and I thought this was going to be more of a traditional restaurant.   I'll take responsibility for that, but in the end, the food was not that good and I think it's more designed for a younger crowd and not a family meal.
author: Edgar C.

description:
Food: a little bit salty and oily; pork could be much tender 

Service: not very welcome, 

Price: cold dishes are over priced 

Overall: not too bad 

Best luck
author: Annie Y.

description:
Are you a global foodie and a fan of Xi'an Famous Foods?  Well, this is the closest thing you'll get here in SF, and lucky for you, it's really tasty!  

It was a cold and dreary day, and I wanted to eat something hot and spicy that would warm me up.  This place did the trick!  We walked in and were embraced with the fragrant smells of Chinese cooking.  This is a different kind of Chinese food than you'll normally get in SF.  Most places in SF serve up Cantonese food, but this little gem specializes in Shaanxi cuisine, which means lots of spices, chili, heavy use of lamb and mutton.  Strong, fragrant flavors.  Spicy flavors.  

We ordered the "Chinese burger," which was basically pork in a bao, the noodles in sizzling oil, and the cumin lamb stir fry.  The "burger" was a bit on the salty side; I'm not sure if it was supposed to be that way normally or if maybe they spilled extra salt into the dish.  I liked the texture of the pork, which seemed like it was braised, but the saltiness detracted from my enjoyment.  The other two dishes, however, were outstanding!  I'm not normally a lamb person, as I find it to be too pungent and gamey, but here they cooked it in such a way that it didn't have that strong gaminess.  Rather, it was tender, delicious, and perfect over a bowl of white rice (necessary! Do get white rice!).  It also wasn't super spicy, which for a weakling like me, was appreciated.  It had just enough spice to give it a good kick, but not so much that it interferes with the taste.  My favorite dish was the noodles in sizzling oil.  The noodles had such great texture!  Each bite was hearty and chewy, such great bite!  They must have been hand-pulled noodles, I don't know how else you can get that kinda bite.  I was also concerned it would be too spicy, but it was only moderately so, and the spice only worked to enhance the flavors.  I loved this dish!

I would recommend this place and would be happy to come back again and try the other dishes!  It's always nice to try something different once in a while, and I'm glad Terra Cotta Warrior exists to fill that niche!
author: Vivian C.

description: Rarely do I have Chinese food in the US and think: this restaurant is made by an artist, someone who'd be famous even back in Asia. Deng is the real McCoy. My favorite Chinese restaurant in SF. Try everything, and please don't tell too many of your friends about this place.
author: Ken H.

description: The food was sub-par at best. The cucumber salad was all garlic and not edible.
author: Moussa Z.

description: Very bad service!  One person was not here because he is looking for parking. I told the person that we will order for him but she would not let us sit down.  Looking around at all the tables, no one got their order placed for 20 mins after sitting.  We can simply sit, order, and the last person will be here.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
Totally terrible experience ,it's extremely terrible,I haven't seen such a mean and unwelcome waiter ever,also I do not wanna come there any once!

Update on 01/21/2017:
My friend just went there today and he said he had really bad time at there cuz he didn't get any great service and he was charged 20% tips without being aware.And also food there are getting worse and worse.lmao
author: Jerry ' Jiaqi' L.

description:
Love this place! I used to live in China and miss being able to get delicious Xi'an food. Terracotta warrior's food is authentic, delicious, and not too expensive. The noodles are the perfect amount of chewy, the rou jia mo are the perfect amount of greasy and the pao mo isn't half bad either.

The only downside is that the service is also a little too authentic, parking can be a pain, and it is a bit of a trek to get all the way out there. That said, it's always worth the trouble when we go.
author: Andrew J.

description:
This place is small and can get packed. Come a bit earlier to avoid a long wait. We came on a cold Thursday weeknight and managed to be seated nearly immediately. 

I love love loved the sour & spicy pork tripe soup This is something I would drop in for as take out for cold nights alone at home. just the right amount of hot and sour and a nice amount of thinly sliced up tripe. DELISH.

mixed cold shredded potatoes - first time having this and it was interesting. a bit different but it's a nice palette refresher when your food is too spicy. 

cucumber salad - LOVED THIS. tons of oil and garlic with nice snap and crunch from the cucumber. 

pork lungs in chili sauce - SKIP. These were so boring and overdone. It tasted like over dehydrated beef jerky in chili oil 

shanxi mian pi was also very good. nice and refreshing with just the right amount of chew from the noodles. 

DO NOT order the $18 braised chicken dish. Although it is huge, it's not worth it. The chicken is extremely overcooked and dry. It's very carb heavy as there are chicken potatoes AND noodles underneath. I guess you could order it once just to say you've tried it (believe me, you're going to be tempted to order it because everybody else has it on their table) but it's seriously  not worth it. I would say that was the only dish my friends and I regretted ordering. We barely touched it and didn't want to take the leftovers. 

I need to come back for lamb soup.. and some hot and sour lamb dumpling soup. also want to try the garlic pig ears, tofu w/ preserved eggs..
author: Susy C.

description:
Absolutely amazing food - I can't wait to come back!! 

Expect a wait when you arrive, especially on weekends - my friends and I came with a group of 7 at 7pm on a Saturday and waited 1 hour. There are only enough seats for around 40 people inside, but people eat pretty quickly.

Every dish is reasonably priced. My favorites were the minced pork noodle soup and the spicy fish entree. I love numbing hot and I definitely found that in the fish. The noodle soup looks deceptively spicy since it is red and oily, but it is mostly a tomato flavor, and has some sour from vinegar. The noodles come out very quickly so you can expect to be delighted and full very quickly.
author: Jenny M.

description: If you love noodles (especially hand pulled noodles), you have to come here. I saved this place a while ago, but only first came here last week. It was so good, that I came back for lunch three days later. I'll be back every three days to try new things on the menu.
author: T D.

description: every single dish noodles are raw!!!! Taste soooo bad, i don't know why ppls are giving 5 stars. Never come back
author: Bingcheng W.

description: Flavorful! The food was worth the wait.  Ordered lamb with scallions, shaanxi wide noodles, and pork with green pepper. I was mesmerized! Ordered a pork burger - I can miss that next time.  But I will be thrilled to come back again to try other dishes.
author: Trisha S.

description: Came in before rush hour, but still greasy tableware and table. Will not recommend for people who cannot eat alot; their credit card minimum is 25 dollars.
author: Tina H.

description: Bad service. They didn't let us in because we didn't have all our people arrived even we said the last people was parking and we can order first while we wait for her. When they saw us want to leave then they called us back and let us in. However when we ordered, they said it's not enough food but they are so busy that we can only order one time and can't add any order later. When the fired lamp came, some of them are raw !!!  So we tell them to recook it but when it arrived it's half portion left with a lot of onion and pepper to make it looks a lot. They also gave us the receipt while we were still finishing our food. They don't care about their services because their bill already included the tips!!!
author: Olivia K.

description: Wow. Wow. Wow. I eat a lot of chinese, here, in china, whatever, and this place is a stroke of genius. Reasonable prices - a huge lunch for $15 and you can get a "burger" for $5". The tastes are authentic, vinegary, mutton-y, all in a clean and reasonable place. Can get a little crowded because it's so small.
author: brian b.

description: The food was good but service was bad. Also, I got food poisoning from this place. Ordered the popular spicy chicken with noodles.
author: Anita Z.

description:
This place got really popular recently! A year ago we didn't have to wait 45 minutes.
Since it has become so popular the service is really terrible.
1) After a 45 minutes wait. we finally got a seat! We were a group of 6 and we deiced what we wanted to order. So while placing the order we were denied the chicken and fish dish because "there are too many people waiting and not enough time to prepare the dishes" Seriously? i thought it was a joke.
Ok so anyway, then we looked at the menu again.
2) we are ready to order additional items. Another waitress was like, once you have placed your order you cannot order additional items. Then she went to talk to the other one and we ordered our items.
At this point it seemed like customers are a burden to the restaurant. Our tea and water glasses were empty, nobody bothered to refill them. We asked for extra napkins, we didnt receive any.
3) The food was good, but the service was so terrible and I don't think its worth all the commotion. The one star is for the food and thats it.

Note: they don't serve beer anymore and you cannot BYOB.
author: K S.

description:
It was a cold day, and for some reason I always crave warm noodles on cold days. 
Came across Terra Cotta Warrior and saw they had handmade noodles and the Qi Shan Minced Pork noodle soup picture looked delicious!! I was so excited my mouth was watering during the drive there thinking about what I was going to eat.

Got there, it was in a pretty dead-ish neighborhood but it looked busy inside. The waitress asked my +1 and me if we would be willing to share a big table with another party of 2. We were fine with that so we got seated right away. The interior decor looked nice and very fitting with the name of the restaurant. We ordered the Qi Shan Minced Pork noodle, the lamb with cumin, and Shaanxi stir fried wide noodles. The prices are very reasonable, and it all sounded so good. 

The lamb and stir fry noodle came out first. The lamb was actually pretty good, although I do with the lamb pieces weren't so broken up. It was hard to pick up the meat with chopsticks at times. The sauce of the stir fried noodles was sort of meh to me. It kind of tasted like BBQ sauce mixed with the szechuan style sauce. Maybe it's just a flavor I'm not used to? Either way my taste buds weren't the most satisfied. But, the quality of the noodles was really good! You can really tell it was handmade. Really liked the chewy noodles :) 
I think they forgot about my minced pork noodle soup because the waiter looked shocked when I said I was still waiting for it. So.. by the time that came I was already a bit full from eating the lamb and stir fry. Similar to the stir fry noodle sauce, the soup flavor just didn't vibe with me. It was too sour for me. Again, noodle quality, great! Just didn't really like the sauces.. 
I did get the tsing tao beer and that was really nice and refreshing!
author: Christine Y.

description:
Great place for Shaanxi food.  Limited menu though, they make some things really well but dont have much variety.  Really not a pure Shaanxi place, more of a variety of NW Chinese dishes.  Good amount of Gansu, Sichuan, and Shanxi thrown in with the Shaanxi food.  

The RouJiaMou was the best I have had outside of China.  It wasnt perfect, but it was head and shoulders above most of what you get in the US.  It didnt look the part but the flavor and texture were pretty on.  

The hand pulled noodles are the best thing they make.  Make sure you get something with them.
author: Richard B.

description: Yummy! The food are so authentic.  I strongly recommend the mian-pi and Noddles with sizzling oil（油泼面）.
author: Emma L.

description:
==LOVED==
The sauce in shan xi mian pi. Mian pi itself could have been softer

==LIKED==
none

==DECENT==
Qishang pork noodle - got quite a sour flavor so you will like it if you like sour stuff. Noodles were excellent

Yang Rou Pao Mo (lamb soup w/ pita) - prefer softer pita, broth too much lamb flavor

==BAD==
Beef lung w/ chili sauce - the white sesame was strange, no cilantro, also don't like the numbness from the spice

Cumin Lamb Hamburger - pretty disgusting, I've had way better. Stay away.

I see some comparisons to Xi'an Famous Foods. This place, while the food is similar, the taste is far below that of Xi'an Famous Foods.
author: Mark D.

description: I will not recommend this restaurant. The space is limited, the foods of Xi'an are below average. I don't feel they are any better than doing the noodles myself. The Sichuan foods from there are even worse which is understandable. They take credit cards, which adds one star.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
I've had Northern Chinese food when I was China, yumm those handpulled noodles. But I haven't had it here in the Bay Area.

We came about 15 mins before close. I was worried they wouldn't take anymore customers, but they kindly seated us and took our orders. Yay!

We ordered the Shaanxi Mianpi, the pita bread soaked in Lamb Soup, the spicy pork burgers, and the minced pork soup. Everything was delicious! My favorite was the Shaanxi Mianpi which I highly recommend. The noodles are delicious and cooked to a perfect al dente. The sauce was really what made it stand out, a bit tart and tangy, I think there's vinegar. It's also cold and refreshing. A great appetizer. The burger was also very good. The spicy pork itself wasn't that spicy but they place a lot of sliced peppers in it, a lot of it fell out when I bit into it. But the pork was very flavorful. I wasn't that big of a fan of the pita bread in the lamb soup. It wasn't like pita bread at all. It was more like dough and they give A LOT of it, which soaks up all the soup. It didn't have much flavor and it's soft mushy and chewy. But everything else in the soup was delicious, just wasn't a fan of the pita bread. The minced pork soup I liked way better. The soup was more flavorful and I loved the noodles it came with.

Prices are cheap too. We paid about $28 for 4 dishes.

The decor was also very nice. This place definitely looked a lot nicer than your typical chinese restaurant.

Service was quick when I came. I didn't get any negative impressions from the workers. I was happy with the service even though we came close to closing.

I will definitely be back to try some other dishes.
author: Stephanie L.

description: This place's taste focuses more on the spicy and sour tastes of cooking. Went and got the lamb with pita bread,the tendons (I think), the shredded potatoes,and their noodles also.
author: Wesley K.

description:
Love, love, love this place. When I walked into the restaurant, I knew I'd be content eating here. The vibe and decor is very interesting and reminds me of the Asian Art Museum. 

-The food has a unique taste-spicy, bitter, or sweet. 

-They have a variety of foods and it was hard to choose what to order.

-Service is good and the people working there are very patient and cooperative.

-I guess the con is that the lighting here is not good for mid/elderly people? It was hard for my mother to read the menu.

I usually don't eat this type of food/steer clear because I can't eat spicy food. But, after tasting an appetizer, I was hooked. The spicy level of it actually isn't that bad!
author: Erica K.

description: Tasty and authentic! Been meaning to try this place for awhile and so glad we finally did. Perfect place to pop in for a bowl of noodles, especially in the foggy sunset.
author: Chelsea V.

description:
Authentic Xi'an food. 
Lamb soup was great. 
Lamb burger and pork burger were better than NYC's Xi'an Famous Food.
author: Larry C.

author: Cheng J.

description:
We were not that familiar with Xi'an/Shaanxi cuisine. We arrived at around 5:30. Not very crowded but the place was packed by the time we left. I liked the decor of the restaurant, not overstated and more contemporary feeling than most Chinese restaurants. We loved it and will be going back. Based on reports here I told the server we liked very spicy food. Except for the Ma Po Tofu, the food seemed free of the overload of MSG you get at many Chinese restaurants in the US. Husband mentioned the food had a Silk Road feel and I agree. The prices were very affordable especially considering the high quality of the food. Here is what we ate:

Pork with hot pepper burger. Burgers are meh to me. But this burger I LOVED. This was my favorite dish. The pork itself was sweet and contrasted nicely with the sharp spicy jalapeños. The toothsome bread was the perfect vehicle.

The cumin lamb burger. This was good but not as good as the pork one we had. My husband said he had a better version (more crispy lamb) at the restaurant he went to in NY.

Shaanxi Mian-Pi. I have never had a dish like this. We really enjoyed this. The noodles were toothsome and spicy with a satisfying sourness.

Pita Bread Soaked In Lamb Soup.  Really homey, comforting and tasty. This soup was permeated with an intense satisfying lamb flavor. The pieces of bread were almost like tiny dumplings and together with the mung bean noodles they added a satisfying texture to the dish. Very different, very good. Great food can make you feel like you are transported to a different location. This dish made us feel like we were transported to some exotic destination on the Silk Road.

Ma Po tofu. We got this because I love Ma Po Tofu and I am always curious to try different versions. This version was very good. The only element it lacked was that there was not enough Sichuan pepper. A bit more Ma La would have knocked it out of the park.
author: George T.

description: My new favorite Chinese place! Having lived in China, where I used to eat one of the xi'an meat buns almost everyday, I was excited to find a place that also specialized in xi'an food. The meat burgers are just as good as the ones I've had overseas, as are the pork noodles.
author: Jean J.

description:
Overall a very modern, hip Chinese restaurant. Great place for larger parties, because each dish is relatively cheap so you can order a variety to share! Service, however, is kinda slow and inefficient, hah. 

We split the following: 
(1) Jellyfish in mixed sauce-  sooo gooooood. Good portion for $4.95. The jellyfish is fresh and crunchy, and the sauce is a light spicy vinaigrette. Very similar to the jellyfish dishes you get at dim sum. Definitely recommend and would order again. 

(2) Lamb soup with "pita" on the side - the broth is yummy! Some other reviewers noted that it was "bland", but I thought it was a refreshing addition to the meal. It's not overly oily nor salty, and has a natural gamey taste from the lamb. However, there was very little lamb and the glass noodles were just okay. 

I'm also still intrigued by why they call the bread a 'pita'. It's shaped like a pita, but looks more like a thick, flattened out dough. Honestly, I was not that impressed by the grease-rubbed 'pita' and did not think it really enhanced the overall dish at all. 

Probably would not order again because of the sad portion of lamb... 

(3) Shaanxi Mian-pi- this was my bf's fave because the noodles were chewy with good flavor. It's slightly spicy.

(4) Hamburger with beef - the meat reminded me of Chipotle's carne asada. The "hamburger buns" are actually "pita" breads. Kinda fun to try for the first time, but would not order this again.
author: Samantha C.

description: The worst service I've ever experienced. If I can give no star, I would. The male servicer left one menu on our table in case we want to add other dishes. We end up wanting to add more food and the female server raised her voice and said "You cannot add any more food. We are so busy and if everyone wants to add more food and it's really annoying!" Then she came back and asked if she can take our plates but we are still eating!! As soon as she saw we clear our dishes, she came back and said "I can take them now right? We are so busy! A lot of people is waiting!" We were rushed out of the restaurant. From the time the food arrived, we only have 30 mins to eat. I will never go back again. The food were just ok. A lot of bread and noodles.
author: Oi T.

description: Great food had the lamb dumpling soup & it was amazing. Will definitely be coming back here!!!
author: Erin R.

description:
SUMMARY:  Sauces are decent, but the ingredients need to be higher quality to get the full fabulous flavor of Shaanxi cuisine. The steamed bread, tofu, and noodles just weren't as flavorful as they are in Shaanxi. Don't substitute American white vinegar, when you need special vinegars from China. I enjoyed my two spiciest snacks the most: the mianpi (cold noodle) and the cai jiamo (veg burger). 

- liangpi (cold noodle with spicy oil etc.):  not bad but not great. rather small.
- tudousi (potato strips): too expensive! didn't order them
- cai jiamou (vegetable burger): excellent - perfectly seasoned vegetable, savory sauce, in a traditional steamed bread mit. yum!
- liancai (lotus): too sweet, strange (American?!) vinegar. failure. 
- spicy tofu: good sauce, meh tofu. so-so

DETAIL:  It's wonderful to be able to order liangpi with numb/spicy - but as liangpi goes (for someone who has eaten authentic liangpi in Xi'an for years), the liangpi here is just so-so. Not quite flavorful or plentiful enough. And I didn't order the tudousi, because they're now $11 which is outrageous! The spicy tofu was pretty good, but needs to be made bite-sized. The lotus was a failure: too sweet, strange white vinegar (American white vinegar or what??), no seasoning. Again, I'm thrilled to find attempts at authentic Xi'an cuisine -- I think they need to ask customers: "Do you want authentic, or less spicy / less garlic?" I prefer the real northwest and western Chinese cuisine best! Don't water it down for me. Keep all the spice. I heard the people at the table beside mine asking whether dishes could be done without the spiciness. Not really! If you want bland food, you'll need to visit an authentic Shanghai restaurant, in my experience (of Shanghai and American Shanghainese cuisine). Keep trying -- I know you can earn 5 stars. BTW very concerned about the hygiene safety alert that appeared when I visited this page: 

ALERT:  Consumer Alert: Poor Food Safety Score!

Did you know that local officials inspect food service facilities to improve food safety?

Following a recent inspection, this facility received a food safety rating that is in the bottom 5% locally, and is categorized by inspectors as "poor."

Being in the consumer protection business, we care a lot about your safety and will display this alert for six months or until we receive a significantly improved food safety rating for this business. 

CHINESE REVIEW:
能在这边点碗又香又麻的凉皮，我很高兴。但是！跟西安的凉皮来比较，这个店的凉皮很一般。不够辣，面皮也太少了。还有，土豆丝十一美金？不可能！我没点。菜夹馍不错！好吃。香辣豆腐还行。凉拌莲菜太甜，醋的味道怪怪的...... 总之： 还不是正宗的。再辣再香一些， 原料、佐料要质优：） 加油！ 另外：我查 老家陕西 时，出现了一个关于"违反卫生规定"的通知。管理好啊。：）
author: K S.

description:
Me: "Can we have two glasses of ice?" 
Waitress: "We don't have ice."
Me: *blank stare*
Waitress: "We don't have ice."
Me: "oooook."

What kind of restaurant doesn't have ice?? 
-__- 

So I guess all the water they give doesn't have ice in them.

Another customer: "We have a reservation for 10 people"
Boss: "We didn't take down any numbers"
Customer: "You just called me back 10 minutes ago"
Boss: "oooh.. Ahh ok"
Customer: -_-'


The food is ok. The service was minimal and rude... they weren't very welcoming and rushed us to leave. There were a lot of people waiting.

But I do love the decor of the restaurant.
author: Tammy F.

description:
I just took my mom there this weekend. I'd just come back from NYC, where I almost ALWAYS pay a visit to Xi An Famous Foods, so I was pretty stoked to see we had a xi an place of our own now. They did the decor really nicely (especially given that it's a Chinese restaurant, in the sunset). Smaller dishes around $4-5, noodles and soups around $8-9, super reasonable. I heard it gets pretty packed so we got there 30 mins after opening and got seated right away; as we ordered, ppl started to line up.

The jellyfish, a very standard Chinese dish, was good but very salty. The lamb "burger" was pretty dry (the bread is their "pita" and is super dry to begin with) but it can be helped with a healthy dose of chili sauce. The mian pi cold noodles was great -- I strongly recommend it. Shanxi minced pork noodles was one of their specialties, and it was definitely a great bowl of noodles.. huge and flavorful, but seriously where's the meat?

We also ran into apparently a pretty common problem here: unavailable menu items. We had ordered the pita bread soaked in spicy lamb soup dish, and then as we started getting our apps, the waitress said they were out of the spicy lamb soup but we can get the lamb soup... which was weird so I asked how that could be, and she said they didn't make the spice mix for that day. Okay.. fine.. just the normal lamb soup then. Then she comes back and tells me that they're out of that version, we can't get the pita bread soaked in lamb soup, just pita bread on the side. What? Is there a special skill involved? At that point, we were just like fine, just bring whatever. So it was just those 2 very dry pita bread (kinda like mantou) on the side of lamb soup. PS the soup is delish, but the meat is kinda dry.

So the food is decent, the noodles are pretty great, and I wouldn't mind going back, but it does feel pretty inconsistent, and it's very frustrating not knowing what the kitchen's gonna feel like serving you that day...
author: Vivian H.

description:
Don't expect "Chinese" food in the traditional sense from this restaurant. You are not going to get chow mein and kung pao chicken. Terra Cotta Warrior serves food from the Shaanxi region of China. It is very spicy and uses a lot of of wide noodles. I've eaten there twice and loved it both times.

I have tried the cucumber salad, jellyfish in mixed sauce, stir-fried lamb with cumin, braised chicken with potato and pepper, Shaanxi braised spicy fish, pita bread soaked in lamb soup, Chinese burger with pork, and the Shaanxi mian-pi.

Of those, everything was spicy except the cucumber salad (which is small,) the jellyfish (also a small dish,) the Chinese burger with pork, and the pita bread soaked in lamb soup. 

The first time I went we ordered carry-out, which was very easy. The second time we ate in. They brought the soup out last which I didn't entirely understand, but after eating the soup after eating everything else, I think it makes the most sense. The soup is not spicy. After eating some of everything, my mouth was on fire (in the best of ways.) The soup really helped mild that out, with the delicious comforting tastes of the lamb with the square chunks of pita in it (which hardly seem like bread and seem way more like a noodle.) The soup was an excellent way to end the meal.

They do not take dinner reservations. The restaurant is small. You must have time to wait to get seated. But our party of 6 got seated within 45 minutes, which really isn't bad. The service was great. And really, the prices are excellent.
author: Ellie C.

description:
I finally come try this place after staring into their window looking at people slurp up their noodles, looking so yummy..Ok that's creepy.
My friend and I ordered a bunch of stuff thinking it will be too much, we ordered the chicken salad small plate but they ran out...

Jelly Fish small plate- Very tasty sauce, not enough jelly fish, it was alot of lettuce but it was refreshing and tasty.

Beancurd and Celery- My friend wanted this, sounds nasty, it was nasty bland. Sorry.

Minced Pork noodle soup- Yumo! It was very pretty coming out, the soup was good and spicy and sour. Noodles were chewy and hand made. I didn't see alot of pork but flavors were real good.

I saw this girl at another table eating a wide noodle, I told the waitress, I want that! It was Spicy oil tossed in noodles. OMG this was my favorite. If I saw this on the menu I would have never ordered it on my own. It had amazing flavors, this is a dry noodle. 

Only downfall, after eating this meal I felt so oily and clogged up. It was good but I'm sure not the healthiest meal you'll eat ha! I needed some draino to unclog my intestines.
author: Karen T.

description:
I've eaten here twice in under a week.  Once for dinner and again today for lunch.  I have to say I'm a fan.  

Shout outs:
*The cold thinly sliced pigs ear with cucumber.   Refreshing.
*dumplings in hot sour soup - the right balance.

Stay away from: 
*braised chicken with noodles which is listed under entrees.  Don't bother.  The soup broth and wide rice noodles in it are good; but the braised chicken pieces are chicken necks and backs.  
*the cumin lamb burger on pita bread.  Too much cumin and the pita was dry.

Prices are very reasonable.  Split among your friends, average bill $13-$15 for six to seven dishes.  Just enough food to satisfy the palate without overindulging.
author: Shirley N.

description:
I waited until I came here 3 times to write a review for this neighborhood restaurant. I tried all the starred specials on the menu. I appreciate the helpful staff on explaining what each dish is and what they recommend. They offer to substitute beef with lamb because I wanted lamb dry noodles and that wasn't on the menu.
I honestly enjoyed every dish I had here so far. Some memorable ones were shaanxi  mian-pi, lamb noodle, cold spinach with garlic, and pig ears. 


Just remember they are closed Mondays. Don't get molded like I did.
author: Kelly C.

description: Terra Cotta Warrior is a small, CLEAN, Chinese restaurant serving Shanxi cuisine. I've been here a couple times and each time I had to wait at least 30 minutes so be prepared. Shanxi cuisine is known for their lamb and tend to use vinegar to prepare their dishes so most of the dishes here are tart (which I do love). One of my favorites is the Shan xi mian pi which is a small cold noodle dish with a bit of chili oil and vinegar. I've also ordered their dumpling soup and egg and tomato soup which I recommend. I would definitely be coming here more often if it wasn't so far out in the Sunset.
author: Cindy A.

description: I wish place was closer to where I live. Sometimes I consider moving to the sunset just to be closer to this place. Everything here is delicious. Everything is cheap. The sizzling oil noodles are a must try. We usually get about 1 per person, not even considering what other entrees we might get. A big bowl of the lamb soup with little pita bites is a great thing to share between a group. We come here about every other Sunday and would definitely recommend it to anyone up for authentic northern Chinese cuisine.
author: Michail Y.

description:
I ordered 33 min ago. 
And I'm still waiting.
Bad experience regardless of the food.
I'm starving.
author: YE Y.

description:
I was so excited when I heard about Terracotta Warrior because I love Shan Xi food and handpulled noodles! I was almost bouncing in excitement when I came here with the BF on a Thursday night. Despite it being late, the restaurant was pretty full. 

The interior of the restaurant is really nice and classy, definitely not what you expect of a Chinese restaurant. The service was a little slow though. Although there were empty tables lying around, it took them 15 minutes to notice us, yell at us and then lead us to a table.

We ordered the:
-Jelly fish appetizer
-Pita bread soaked in lamb soup
-Noodles with sizzling oil

JELLY FISH APPETIZER:
This was really delicious and refreshing. I love jellyfish and it's always exciting when it's done in a new way. The jellyfish was cut into thiin strips and was chewy and flavored with really fragrant sauce. It also came with a ton of vegetables which I appreciated.

PITA BREAD IN LAMB SOUP:
Really wanted to like this but really hated it. The pita bread tasted gross like croutons left sitting in a salad for far too long. The soup was also really bland, if you are a lamb lover, you might be disappointed by the lack of taste. The lamb was also overcooked and not well seasoned. Overall a very meh dish, unflavorful, with uninteresting textures. PASS.

NOODLES WITH SIZZLING OIL:
This is why I came here to begin with! I love biang biang mian and this looked like the next best alternative. Overall, it wasn't a terrible dish, but it wasn't a stand out either, the noodles did taste a little soggy, and not as bouncy as I would have liked. Although the dish did have a good amount of spice, it lacked flavor and fragrance, so it was literally like eating noodles in chilli oil. Disappointing, maybe I should have gone for the mianpi instead.

All in all, I can't complain as the dishes were cheap and generous in portions, unfortunately, I was unimpressed by the taste of food here. Oh well. The search for biang biang mian in the bay area goes on.
author: Sarah T.

description: Great selections of Shannxi style food. Very authentic and price is reasonable. If you on weekends, the wait can be very long.
author: William C.

description: AMAZING!  FRESH made noodles and YES, you absolutely can tell the difference!  I'm not going to leave a long review! It's FREAKIN GOOD and I'm mean, I'm Asian and I eat Asian Food ALL the time GOOD!
author: Paul A.

description:
Hand made noodles were delicious.   They are too spicy however, for taste...price is reasonable.
I like that they give you a pot of tea for the table.
author: Ree'Ay I.

description: After recovering from a bad health inspection (everything good now) wife and I decided to return. The food before was awesome. Unfortunately everything has changed... only ok now, and no longer worth the drive from South San Francisco.
author: Rob P.

description: Have been there for quite a few times but won't be back again after this time. Their owner asks us to leave after eating for 40 mins on a Saturday lunch time by saying "Please understand us, this is busy time. You should only expect to fill your stomach. Dont expect to eat well."
author: Robbin Y.

description: Great place. Original Shanxi 陕西味道。order the Qishan Saizi 臊子面 noodles and the Youpo Noodles 油泼面。地道的陕西菜。just as good as the Shanxi food that I eat in Beijing.
author: Will L.

description:
If this review is strictly up to me, I would only give it 2 stars max.  However, the hubby insist that I give them another chance and based on the food alone (at least what was available to us), it warrants 3 stars.

We thought by coming here on a weeknight when it is usually less crowded, they won't be sold out of things.  WRONG!  Luckily, we got seated right away and when it came time to order, certain items were already "sold out" for the night.    Mind you, this was only 30 minutes after they opened for dinner service for a night that only had 3 other tables beside us!  However, the only thing we really wanted...their homemade wide noodles...our waitress assured us that it was available.  She even told us she prefers the wide noodles over the thin ones.  Overly excited, we finally thought we found a place close to home that serves comparable noodles to the ones we had in NYC so of course we ordered away.  Got a few different noodle dishes, some mixed with sesame sauce, another in sizzling oil, and the spicy pork one - thinking all the noodles will be different since we chose a mixture of both wide and thin.  We specifically asked our waitress for wide noodles in our soup dish and she assured us that it was not a problem.  Sadly, that was not the case.  Without even informing us that they had ran out of the wide noodles , they just brought out all of our dishes w/ the same type of thin noodles, just mixed in different sauces.  I'm all about noodles too and would choose that over rice any day, but when I have 3 dishes served with the same kind of noodles, it got boring fast.  Just wished someone had the courtesy to let us know, especially coming from 2 people who's eyes literally lit up when she told us they had the wide noodles.

Taste wise, food was good, bold flavors packed with a lot of heat.  It's perfect for spicy food lovers but my mouth gave out after awhile.  Service was overall friendly, waitress took the time to explain the menu to us and offered some of her suggestions.  However, it's time like these that I wished I had taken Mandarin in HS.  I basically had no idea what she was saying to me and I felt bad that she was trying her hardest to explain everything to us in English.  We literally took out our phones and just pointed at pictures from fellow Yelpers at the end, I think she was much more relieved when we did.  

Hubby wants to go back and give them another try, but I think I'll wait awhile until they work out their kinks.
author: Janetto L.

description:
Shredded Tripes With Soy Sauce - Spice Level: 0 
A bit on the salty side...

Chicken In Scallion Oil - Spice Level: 0
A very simple dish yet one of the most delicious out of everything I ordered. Very tender pieces of chicken breast (I'm assuming this because there was no dark meat to be found).

Braised Chicken With Potato & Pepper - Spice Level: 5-6
This dish was MASSIVE. MASSIVE as in it was twice the size of the standard dishes you'll find in restaurants. Perhaps three times the size. But that's somewhat expected since it's $20.95. I saw everyone order it, so I had to follow suit. Had the first bite and was a bit disappointed. It's just a typical braised chicken dish. I think my expectations were too high since everyone else in the restaurant ordered it.   

Hot & Sour Pork Dumpling Soup - Spice Level: 5 
Flavorful soup with a good balance between hot and sour. The dumplings were well made, especially the skin. It was opaque and had a slight bouncy texture.

Pita Bread Soaked In Lamb Soup - Spice Level: 0 
The lamb was tender and was not gamey at all. Never had pita bread soaked in soup before and felt that it was quite an interesting first time experience. The texture is comparable to tong yuan (glutinous rice balls), but less chewy. The soup was flavorful, but really greasy. I had some leftover and popped it in the fridge over night. The following morning, I found a thick layer of coagulated fats on top of the soup. 

Shaanxi Mian-Pi -Spice Level: 6-7 
Refreshing dish! Once again, a good balance between hot and sour. Tasted exactly like the hot and sour pork dumpling soup base. The sliced cucumbers were a good addition as well. 

This place was PACKED like sardines. I waited for 40 minutes, so this translates to slower service. But that's understandable. I brought my parents with me and they just couldn't hang. I have never seen them chug so much water in one sitting. Just a big cup of NOPE for them. Their Southern Chinese palates couldn't handle the spice and sodium. But for me, I really enjoy strong flavors and can handle my spices. I'll be coming back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
One of our favorite finds in SF! Being LA transplants, we missed all the easily accessible and authentic Chinese food options we had before. We have been here twice, and both times loved everything that we ordered. In particular, we loved the spicy tangy-ness of the Qi Shan Minced Pork noodles and the cold dishes - especially the Fu Qi Fei Pian and tofu skin appetizers were great. We were also pleasantly surprised by the Cumin Lamb - the preparation was different than what we were used to, but the meat was very tender and the flavor profile was unbeatable.

Other than the fact that getting a table is usually a 30 minute battle (even when we came after 9pm on a weekday night), nothing to complain about!
author: Angela D.

description:
The last dinner of Thanksgiving holiday in CA. This was my third time here. For first two visits, I was pretty impressed by its big plate of chicken. It almost became the reason I want to visit SF again, and I always recommend this place to my friend who would visit SF. I would give it 5 stars if I didn't go there for a third time. However, it's a little disappointing this time, both food and service. 
There was already a line when we got there by 6, but the wait wasn't too bad. We orders a small plate of chicken, spinach as cold dish, and pork burger to go. I didn't have pork burger this time, so not sure if it's as good as before. But the small plate of chicken was not as good as I remembered, with too much noodle and oil in it. Besides, one of the waitresses was pretty rude. We waited for twenty minutes with no dish came, even the cold dish as appetizer. So I asked her to take a look for us. She just told us to wait as there were three table's order before us. I can understand the main dish need to wait, but how about the appetizer!
So overall, 4 stars. I will try it again in future to see if it still worth 4 stars.
author: Zhe D.

description:
I'm in love!

I had great food and great service (even though I came in with about an hour to go and running past closing time. 

The portions are MASSIVE. I repeat, MASSIVE. I went with my boy and we saw that the menu items were inexpensive ($5-8 range) that we assumed the portions would be much smaller so we ordered shaanxi noodle and hot and sour soup and a pigs ear dish. We were so surprised when the bowls came out bigger than out heads! 

It was definitely worth the money! Also, the decor is so nice. Not your typical Chinese restaurant. I know it's a little strange but whenever I walk into a super nice Chinese restaurant, I get a little worried. The dirtier the Chinese food, the better it tastes (I think the best tasting Chinese food looks strange and not Instagram worthy haha). This place was the complete opposite but it was just perfect.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Best kept secret of the Northern Chinese food variety in the city, according to a San Fransisco foodie friend. She was SO RIGHT!

The cucumber salad is the best $4.50 you might spend on a salad this year. Super simple, the dressing was garlicky, sweet and salty, and the cucumbers fresh as all fresh.

Qishan minced pork noodles are a Northern Chinese specialty, we couldn't stop spooning the broth onto everything on our plates. Sweet, sour and tangy, noodles perfectly cooked - very addictive.

Friends ordered veggie fried rice and kung pao chicken, both good, but the qishan took the crown.
author: erika s.

description:
One of my favorite noodle places in the city!

I come here with my friends often or I get take out to bring home. We usually get the cucumber salad, shanxi wide noodles dish, and qishan minced pork noodles -- all of which are my favorite. I believe they hand pull their own noodles in the back and you can see that based on the width and length of the noodles in your food.

The only down side is that parking is a pain and there's always a wait, which comes with the neighborhood the restaurant is located in and its popularity. I think I got there around 8:00PM before and waited about 30 minutes? Nonetheless, this is a must try place for those who haven't been here!
author: Brian T.

description:
Friendlier, more welcoming service than the typical outlying SF Chinese restaurant with a specialty menu.  Lovely austere dark wooden decor.

I had cumin lamb, extremely lightly seasoned version of this dish without any overwhelming taste from the cumin, although it was still fairly spicy.  Curlicues of not very distinctly flavored meat with onions and green peppers.  Fairly greasy.  Good, but I'll try something else next time.
author: David B.

description: This place gets five stars for being super unique and giving me the nostalgic feeling of being in China. It really doesn't get more authentic than this. Plus, service and environment is great!
author: Andrew B.

description:
The food is a little hit or miss but what they do really well is the pita lamb soup. Pita is soup makes for these sort of chewey boba like squares, which combined with the gamey lamb flavor is really a winner.

Our other starred (on the menu) dishes were ok, but lacked the flavor punch this sort of western chinese food usually brings, despite it's fiery appearance.
author: Misha T.

description: The food is tasty! But service not that good! Feel surprise they always has food safety problem on the yelp
author: Momoko S.

description:
If you love spicy food, you will love Terra Cotta Warrior.

I enjoy moderately spicy food but now and again I like to live on the edge and get super spicy options. My fiance loves spicy food so we went all in with our order. We started with the Chinese burger with pork. It is on a really tasty pita bread, almost like a less messy sloppy joe. I did have to remove the jalepenos or else it would have been a bit too spicy for me. 

The Shaanxi stir-fried wide noodles were tasty, definitely tasted fresh. The hot & sour pork dumpling soup was by far my favorite thing we tried. Like everything else, it was spicy but not over the top and the flavors were very unique. The dumplings tasted very fresh and the broth was to die for. I very much recommend this dish.

The Shaanxi braised spicy fish should have "extra spicy" next to it. The pieces of fish were soft and delicious but beware of the broth... it is crazy spicy. I tried it and my mouth was on fire! The flavors are delicious but a bit too spicy for me.

Be ready to clear your sinuses with the spiciness of this food, can't wait to try other things on the menu. The price was spot on as well, the 4 dishes came to about $35 and the ambiance feels far more fancy. Not bad for a date night. Definitely recommend checking it out.
author: Stephanie S.

description: The food here helps satisfy my cravings for Shaanxi noodles -- the "three as one" was almost as good as what you actually get in Xi'an.
author: Kaleigh K.

description:
This place has potential to get better. On a Sunday night, the place had run out of hot and sour pork dumplings and Shaanxi mian pi, two items that I came here to try. We opted for the following:

Chinese burger: shredded beef wrapped in pita bread: decent
Pita bread in lamb soup: very good , like chewy dough bits in soup with some vermicelli, eventhough I'm not a huge lamb fan in general
Qishan minced pork noodles: good hot and sour noodles in soup but very little pork
Shaanxi stir fry noodle dish: noodles were good but way too spicy with too many jalapenos
Buckwheat noodle with chili oil: Bland tasting and way too spicy 

Service was ok, they didn't give soup bowls for sharing until we asked.

I might be back in the future and to get the items that I missed.
author: Ali F.

description: It is a very traditional Chinese restaurant. It is on the 31st avenue, Judah. A friend highly recommended the restaurant. It is very popular. A lot of people are waiting there. The environment is nice and the waiters are so kind. There are various kinds of food, such as noodles, rice and so on. We ordered pork lungs in chili sause, cumin lamb burgers, pork with hot pepper burger and braised chicken with potato&pepper. So delicious. You should have a try.
author: Nancy S.

description: Very delicious! The flavors are always spot on. Portion sizes are good for the price. The flat noodles are tasty. I mean for the uninformed that tend to avoid Chinese restaurants it's very welcoming and warm. I suggest you bring all you friends here that talk bad about Chinese food because this place will definitely impress. A lot of people will compare the authenticity of this place to mainland China however you have to understand that anything outside of its home country will never be exactly the same. Terracotta warrior does very good.
author: Timothy W.

description: This is THE BEST Shanxi bistro in town. Authentic food and cool eating environment. I drove an hour just to eat here and I will be doing it a lot!
author: Leon Z.

description:
Food is good but had to wait
45 minutes. Service is average to poor but typical for Chinese restaurant. will not recommend.
author: Greg W.

description: Check the health code score, 68 out of 100! This is horrible and uncalled for with any highly rated restaurant. Nope nope nope. Mishandled food, pests and so much more. Don't be fooled here!
author: Kyle S.

description: Reluctant to post a good review because it just means the wait for a table will get even longer... but I LOVE this place. You can't find this style of Chinese cuisine anywhere else, let alone done so well. Would eat here every day if I could!
author: Erin L.

description: This place is the best. None is better. I'm from Xi'an and I am biased.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Despite what happened, I am still giving it 4 stars (should I?) because the food here is always great! So this evening we and our guests were told explicitly to leave the place... How rude! 

We ordered so much food (including the giant spicy chicken plate) that we worked quite a long time trying to eat as much as we could. After an hour, the owner came to our table and asked if we needed a box for the spicy chicken, which we were still working on. We said no because we would want to finish it in the restaurant. And we and our guests wouldn't be in the city the day after. We just wanted to finish the not-even-cold-yet dish right there. Then WE WERE ALL SHOCKED BECAUSE HE STARTED TO TAKE ALL OUR FOOD AWAY!!!!!! We said we did not need a box. It made him mad and he started to shout at us: "You should go somewhere else to talk. You eat here, not talk here. Can you see so many people are waiting?" Yes, we did see the people and we tried our best. We just had the tiny wish that we could have more of the food tonight. We left with humiliation. I am still so upset after four hours. We just did not know it is a fast food place...
author: Cindy C.

description:
Came here with my friend on a Wednesday night around 6:30pm and was seated immediately! We ordered 2 appetizers and 4 entrees to share. I know that's a lot of food, but don't judge :)

We LOVED noodle in sizzling oil! It was super unique and flavorful. I feel its a combination of wet and dry seasoning. 

I wish the waiter would warned us before we accidentally ordered 2 noodle dishes and one dumpling dish tp share between the two of us. We wanted to try the lamb burger, but we ordered lamb soup instead.

Will definitely be back sooon! Btw, it does get busy around 7 to 7:30. I saw couple groups lining up as we are leaving at 8.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Have to say terra cotta warrior is the place where I had my worst experience of eating Chinese food. One of my friends recommends this restaurant to me, I had really high expectation about the restaurant so me and another friend went there yesterday. 
After we got there the waiter wanted us to sit on the bar counter where is so narrow, but there were few empty tables, the waiter told us those empty tables are for 4 people... Aight, we sit down on the bar counter and few mins later I saw 2 guys left from the table for 2, then we asked the waiter can we move to there and he said yes. Couple mins after the waiter came and told us somebody just came in and sit on that table... WTH? I just saw 2 non Asians sit on the table that we wanted to move... ( I'm Asian) I guess that's how they treat Asians... Btw I give negative point for another waitress' service attitude, she acted like I own her money. Even though the food is tasty, I ain't go terra cotta warrior anymore.
author: Joss L.

description:
love their homemade noodles. it has a nice chew. they have regular or wide flat noodles. can choose unless one is sold out. 

I always get their minced pork noodle soup. not too spicy and a little sour. love the soup flavor. good amount of noodles where you can share. also tried the Kung Pao chicken. delicious and so tasty. LB ate two bowls of rice with this because of the yummy sauce. they gave generous amount of dry whole chili peppers. the cucumber salad was a little small for the price. it is a little sour but has a nice crunch and garlicky taste to it. 

LB was a little disappointed since they only had one type of beer, Tsing Tao. of course they would serve a beer from China. but if they offer more variety of beer, I think they would get even more customers. We all know alcohol is a money-maker in a business. 

not a lot of small tables, maybe around 3 of the 2 seater tables. I remember the first time I went, me and my friend shared a table with another couple. they divided the table with the hot sauce condiments.
author: Jules L.

description:
I went into SF trying to get my Chinese food fix on and was excited to try this place due to the high ratings and all the tasty pictures. We came right on time to avoid the wait. The place is a little crowded although it is very clean. A female waitress came out to take out order and since we didn't have huge appetites we ordered three options and the waitress looked at me and asked "that's it?" I don't know why but this kind of caught me off guard. I'm not sure if she meant to be rude but at least for me it felt a little ride. So customer service wise - don't expect much. The waiters all seemed rushed which made me feel a little anxious the whole time. So our dishes came out one at a time and there were at least a 15 minute wait in between. Which made me feel full quicker - not sure if this is a good or a bad thing. Then the waitress came out and asked me if we received all of our food yet and we didn't we were still waiting on our noodle soup. She said we didn't tell her that order, which is a little weird because I saw what I wanted on the menu, I ordered it by speaking of it out loud I'm not sure what she means by "we didn't tell her that order." Hmmm strange I think she meant she didn't hear our order? Very possibly because she was rushing the whole time. So that was that and she never said sorry. 

But overall I give this place credit for their noodles. I had the minced beef noodles which was my favorite. The slickness was just right and I liked the slight sour taste of the broth. Also the noodles were very tender and tasted very well made. The cold noodles I thought was ok you would have to actually be into cold noodled. The pork burger was a little bland for me so it wasn't a favorite. 

Conclusion: 2/5 stars if the service was better it would of been 3/5 for the food.
author: Teena N.

description: I tried this restaurant the first time when the name of the restaurant caught my eyes.   I ordered the Noodle soup with lamb.  the look of the noodles wasn't very appealing to me, but the taste kept me going, and I finished the whole bowl of noodles at last.   It seemed to me that it was just one very long noodle inside the bowl, and I had to use the scissors the restaurant provided to cut the noodles
author: Debby P.

description:
Shaanxi regional Chinese cuisine in a nice looking restaurant. There are not many serving this type of Chinese in the SF Bay Area.
They do a good job cooking up authentic dishes.


Picks:
Stir-Fried Lamb With Cumin ($8.95) was not as hot as expected. Thin chopped lamb was plentiful in quantity.

Pita Bread Soaked In Lamb Soup ($8.25) or Pao Ma is the reference Xian regional dish.  Frankly this one had more robust broth flavor than ones we had in Xian.  Nice lamb and vermicelli noodles.

Chinese Burger With pork ($3.95) was pretty big and filled with minced pork.  Nice rigid bun.

Shanxi Mian-Pi ($3.95) could have been a lot more spicy, but hit the mark anyway.

OK:
Noodles With Lamb ($8.95) had bland broth but lots of veggies and lamb.  Stick with the Pita Bread Lamb Soup.

Pans:
None

Overall - Very Good
Food - Very Good
Decor - Very Good
Service - Good
Value - Good

Would we come back - Yes
author: Ellen H.

description: Maybe it's because I am not Chinese but the food here was okay. I'll try again, maybe.
author: Anonymous ?.

description: Well after they reopened the food has too much oil in jt. Still pretty good but just a bit too oily for me. I'll probably keep comment back here because I like the Chinese hamburgers
author: Jerry Z.

description: Pretty awesome Xi'an food. I've been here a couple of times and tried most of their noodle options. They were always excellent.
author: Chen P.

description:
The noodles are out of this craziness!  So insanely good.  On top of the noodle greatness they make their own chili sauce.  It's insane toasty yumm-yumm!  But it's not that spicy!  (I'm a spice baby!!)  It's just flavor for days.   Unlike anything I've had before.  Sick!  
You're a noodle freak? , Come here, eat til you burst!!
author: Sarena B.

description: This place gives me a tickle on my tongue and i like it.  Best thing i remember trying was the sour pork soup dumpling.  They also have this noodle dish with some fire hot red sauce.  Lotus roots were a good mix to everything and then we ordered that FATTY brown chicken and potato dish.  Chicken was a bit dry to me and is the reason for the 3 stars.  I'll be back to try other shiz tho.
author: Vince L.

description:
Food is great. Definitely like ordering take out when I'm too lazy to cook. Husband and I love the hot and sour dumpling soup and the braised chicken with potato and peppers. Prices are fairly reasonable for the amount of food you get. 

One thing I hate the most about this place is the service; it's horrible. They don't attend to you while eating, don't pick up on refilling water, and need to be asked for than once for things like napkins and utensils. Overall they're just pretty rude. I once walked in the pick up and order and no one asked me if I needed anything. I was literally standing in the middle of the restaurant and they just walked around me. When I asked for help, one of the girls just looked at me and pointed to the older man who was working. It was just a really awkward experience. But I guess I'll suck it up since the food is good and the location is super convenient. 

Tip: don't sit at the table in the front of the restaurant in the evening unless you want major sun in your face.
author: Kaydee D.

description:
Real genuine shaanxi food. Absolutely amazing noodles that are chewy and tasty. Many varieties that you can choose from.
It's a popular spot and lines can get a little long sometimes. And it takes 5ever to eat, so if you are starving, u will prob die before you get to eat lel. But worth, good food
author: Ryan H.

description:
A nice place for small dishes to try with a group. 
- My favorite dish is the pork ears, marinated in lime and garlic, refreshing and tart. I could eat two! 
- Not a big fan of the pork burger; it was dry and not well flavored
- Shan xi mian pi are spicy noodles that are great
- The large chicken and potato dish is the largest plate but a lot of food and just ok for the price
author: Xtina W.

description:
在羊肉泡馍里发现了一条很大的菜虫，老板走过来不但没有说对不起，不好意思，反而很不耐烦地说要不要换一碗，还是不要了。换了一碗之后，虫是没有了，但是发现了一根中长度的头发。很噁心的店，老板态度又差！
Found a big bug in the soup, the owner was very impatient and said do you want a new one? No any apologies at all. After that, I got a new soup with a hair in it. Very disgusting and bad attitude.
author: Eva Z.

description:
Update: I was a little nervous about coming back here after they re-opened (they closed for a few months for unclear reasons), but I am pleased to report that the place is as amazing as ever. None of my favorite dishes changed, and there are a few additions to the menu that we will have to try. SO relieved. 

I do not want people to know about this place, but I also want them to stay in business, so....... :) The hand-pulled noodles are incredible and make an appearance on quite a few dishes. My personal favorites are the qishan minced pork noodles, the shaanxi stir-fried wide noodles, and the mian pi. We haven't had anything here I wouldn't order again!
author: Julie R.

description: The service is soooo  bad.   One of the young waitress seems so rude and did not respect to us when we are on line. The quality of the waiters service should be improved.  They even did not SMILE to any customer.
author: Jie W.

description: Kinds of authentic Shaanxi/XiAn food.  Liked it very much.  Got meat sandwich and spicy noodle, feeling like the taste of one from my hometown :)
author: Victor L.

description:
Extremely bad service here. They must think they r so popular that they can be mean to customer. When I asked for a to-go order, they seemed not to want to make it and said it might need 30min. I said it's Ok, then came back after 30min. They were not ready and didn't want to serve at all! I can't blame they r using MSG because this is a Chinese restaurant, but come on, u need to be nice to people!

By the way I called them several times before I came. Their phone was always busy. I asked them why, they said they didn't know. Can I make an assumption that they just manually made the phone busy and didn't want to serve??? Based on their behavior, I think I can! Next time if u don't want to serve, just say 'we r closed' or 'I want tips for to-go order', please don't lie to your customer!
author: R W.

description:
The food at this restaurant is amazing. I'm actually quite passionate about this restaurant. I travel to China every month for my job. And when I get back to San Francisco, I will come here for dinner that day, literally without fail. It's what I think about on the 12hr flight back.

Give it a try. There is no reason to get anything other than the signature dishes (羊肉泡馍，肉夹馍，凉皮). Some soul-healing stuff, really.
author: Leo Q.

description: Very good, yummy and hometown style food. Service was great too. Definitely will come back again!
author: Frank W.

description:
I thought this was an interesting name for a restaurant, and growing tired of the same old American-style Chinese food, I thought I would give this place a try.

The restaurant features a cozy dining room with photos of food and Terra Cotta Warriors on the walls.  Many of the tables feature benches for shared seating, which I don't mind, except for the fact that the wait staff kept assuming that my friend and I were with the couple sitting next to us. To their credit at least, the service was quick.

I'm not a big fan of spicy food, and although Shaanxi food trends spicy, I found a lot of things on the menu for my sensitive tastebuds. The Chinese burger and the jellyfish were very tasty. The ginger spinach was too vinegary for my liking. I did like the chicken soup: big noodles with mushrooms, delivered pipping hot. For two people and four dishes the price was $30 including tip -- a bargain that is hard to find in SF these days.

I am planning a return visit.
author: Jason C.

description:
Well well well. I'll be a regular at this restaurant from now on. The cumin burger was to die for. An explosion of spices on your tongue. The "bun" was so light I thought I could eat 5 of it. Sizzling oil noddles, hot hot hot delish. Hot and sour pork dumpling soup was spot on. The broth was out of this world. Kong pao chicken was okay normal, very tender chicken, big portion. Everything was oily and spicy and I have a weak stomach so I thought I might get heart burn after eating all that, but no nothing. That tells me it's a quality food. A must go if you are in the area!
