Went there again and had the pork burger, was delish as well. Another dish we had was the S chicken, but was disappointed bc it was bony chicken and pieces and bone was under my teeth so no fun. But the spices and the peanuts in the dish were amazing.
author: Nayiri H.

description: Got the stir-fried noodles, and I consider them the best stir-fried noodles I have ever had. The were fairly thick and had a nice consistency to them. Also, although I am not normally a fan of spicy food, I thoroughly enjoyed the spicy sauce they put in their dishes.  It was more of a pleasant mouth numbing type of spice rather than a "my mouth is on fire" type of spice. I'm taking off a star here only because the pita bread in the lamb soup I order felt a little too chewy.
author: Sherry S.

description:
Finally - a new Chinese restaurant in SF that's not Fusion, not a Truck, not a photocopy of every other spot, and brings new & distinct flavors! Thank you for existing, Terra Cotta Warrior

The BAD first: the place fills up, so get here early, be prepared to wait. That's it.  Oh, and stop at the corner store to grab a six-pack to bring with.

The GOOD: everything else.

As others have said, the Hot & Sour Soup with Lamb Dumplings was outstanding, the Shaanxi noodles were solid, and we loved the Lotus appetizer. Everything was fresh and full of flavor. Lots of spice and heat, but nothing overwhelming.  

The service was fast and friendly, and the prices are great.  They could duplicate this spot in the Marina and double the prices and the lines would probably be 3x as long.  Will be back!
author: Jeremy T.

description: I called them at 5:41pm they told me they closes at 9:45pm. I came at 9:31pm. They told me they are closed. And they said they told me its 9:30pm. Liars.
author: Vegg C.

description:
Wow, I was blown away by this place. I always wanted to try this place and we finally did. It's a nice small restaurant situated on Judah Street in Sunset. The atmosphere was comfortable and I love their tables with benches. We were there for lunch and then dinner. The food was promising and does not disappoint. 

For lunch and dinner, they have the same menu. We ordered their pita bread lamb noodle (the best of the best), pig's ears (kind of on the saltier side, but very very good), Garlic's chili pork meat (the bomb!!), Scallion chicken (well made dish), Hot and sour pork dumpling soup (great flavor and not too salty), fried noodles with beef and a fried rice with some shredded veggies/egg. 

You will not go wrong with any of their dishes there. I would definitely come back!
author: Elaine C.

description:
Spice is nice!

The cumin spiced lamb is superb and their spicy noodle soup is awesome. 

My wife and I eat here often and we have tried most of the menu. The consistency is impressive. It's no wonder they are always busy!
author: Anderson C.

description:
This review is a few months overdue.

We came here on a week day and were pleasantly surprised to see this restaurant filled with people (quite a contrast to the restaurant that was in this spot prior.)

Our server was nice, however when I asked if certain dishes had meat, she couldn't answer well. We ordered a couple of dishes and the noodles were first to arrive.

Since we didn't want our dish to get cold, my husband went up to one of the staff to ask for plates and utensils. This person (who seemed an authority figure) barked back at him to basically go away. Hubs was persistent and told her what we needed.

She came over and rudely gave them to us.

Despite this, the noodles were delicious.

Our second dish arrived, which I assumed would be vegetarian...wrong, I bit into a fatty and smoke-flavored piece of meat.

Even though our server was really nice, the extremely rude treatment of the other manager(?) left a bad impression.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Came here for a late Saturday night dinner. We arrived after 9pm and the restaurant was full! We didn't mind waiting for a table but the server came over and offered us counter seating.  Score! We settled on the spicy lamb burger, hot and sour dumpling soup and qishan noodles.  I forgot that the qishan noodles was a soup dish so we ended up with 2 soups.  

They brought out the lamb burger pretty quickly and it was tasty. Not oily or greasy but full of flavor and spice! Yummy! I liked the pita that it came with - not chewy but crunchy to add a nice texture.  

Hot and sour dumpling soup was the next dish brought out. This by far was my favorite - the broth was amazing! The dumplings were a generous portion in the soup and very tasty with a homemade skin.  

Finally the qishan noodle soup came out.  The server provided scissors to cut the hand pulled noodles.  The broth of this soup was very different from the hot and sour soup but was very delicious as well.  

We finished everything and was very satisfied.  Service was fine and our dishes came out pretty quickly.  I will def be back to try more dishes.
author: Julie F.

description:
Every single thing here is so good. I accidentally come here multiple times a week because i can't resist.

BESTS:
- Lotus root (though sometimes it's made inconsistently and can be super salty) (no longer on the menu in late 2016, sadly)
- Cucumber salad (healthy delicious)
- Shaanxi mianpi
- Laziji (the spicy mala chicken dish) (no longer on the menu in late 2016, sadly)
- Anything with the lamb, the lamb pita soup, lamb burger

My only con is just that it is inconsistently cooked sometimes. Also, service can be a little slow. Make sure to always wave the server down!
author: Carleen W.

description:
This is the best Chinese food I've had in SF....in all my 10 years of living here. Everything we tried was solid and authentic-tasting to this Northern Chinese gal. And even my white friends liked the pidan (preserved egg) with chiles. Say what? The twice cooked pork was the consensus favorite. 

Really nicely decorated and super clean. The waitress was friendly and quick to point out the Shanxi specialties. The bill was cheap and the beer was cold.
author: Carolyn F.

description: Best place in the city for me personally. Never tired of their noodle. Great lamb, great lamb soup. As great as. What I had in Xian china.
author: Wynne F.

description: Over all I will give it a 3.5. It's pretty clean and the flavor is good but I think it didn't exceed my expectation. Still recommend people to check this place out.
author: Sanli T.

description:
What an incredible addition to the Sunset. This is not your typical Chinese restaurant; Terra Cotta Warrior serves up specialty Xi'an cuisine (aka Northern Chinese food, with an emphasis on hearty broths and noodles).

Though this restaurant had only been open for a few weeks, it was packed at lunch hour. Food was tasty and reminiscent of flavors hard to find outside of China. My fam and I shared the following:
- Cold pidan egg with tofu, cilantro and peppers: Great starter if you're a fan of spice.
- Mian-pi: Cold noodles that, while good, were not amazing. Still refreshing on a warm day though.
- Shanxi minced pork noodles: By far my favorite dish -- hot and sour and satisfying. The texture of the noodles indicated they were freshly pulled. Yummers.
- Pita bread in lamb soup: This is the restaurant's specialty dish. SUPER filling, I highly recommend you share this. The "pita bread" is more like niangao (otherwise known as glutinous rice), I kinda wish it was on the side so I could dip it. Still good though.
- Spicy lazi chicken: Another crowdpleaser. Loved that it came with peanuts like it does in Beijing.

There is some room for improvement in terms of flavor, but its food is one-of-a-kind (at least in SF), and for that it gets 5 stars.

Will have to come back for the Chinese "burger"!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place that serves authentic Northwestern Chinese food. They have the best hand-pulled noodles I've had in the city. So fresh. So chewy. So springy. So perfectly imperfect in appearance. So delicious. Ugh. 

Must tries: 

1) Fried bean paste noodles 
2) Pita Bread Soaked In Lamb Soup 
3) Pigs Ears
4) Qishan minced pork noodles 
5) Shanxi Mian-Pi 
6) Hot & Sour Pork Dumpling Soup 
7) basically anything with pulled noodles.

Fair warning:
Some of the spices are no joke. There's a type of hot spice that's actually NUMBING. Like seriously, numbing. It has a natural chemical that causes your lips and tongue to go limp temporarily (few minutes, or the whole meal depending on how much you consume). But it's delicious. But if you can't handle that, do ask your waiter if it contains that particular spice.

Try this place!!!
author: Erin N.

description:
Astoundingly good Shaanxi food. Came here with a group of friends after hearing various people rave about this place  last week and ordered a wide variety of dishes.  Every dish was executed perfectly.  

1: The cold sliced pig ear is a great light and refreshing way to start the meal.
2: The cumin lamb "burgers" had great flavor, especially when paired with the on-table hot sauce.  
3: The noodles with sizzling oil were cooked perfectly and had a really nice amount of heat to them.  
4: The spicy and sour shredded potatoes were a real standout, with a great texture combined with a healthy amount of numbing sichuan peppercorn seasoning. Not mushy or starchy at all.
5: One of my friends wanted to try the lamb soup with soaked pita bread, and I'm glad he did.  This comprised of a hearty broth with nice big chunks of lamb, rice noodles, and small cubed pieces of pita bread that still had a great texture to them.  I know it sounds weird, but trust me on this one.  
6: Finally the twice-cooked pork was one of the best chinese pork dishes I've had, with the perfect mix of slightly sweet, sour, and spicy.

Portions here were massive, the decor is nice, and the service was fast and friendly.  If you like good food, give this place a try.
author: Joshua W.

description:
Terra Cotta Warrior features Northern Chinese cuisine particularly in Xi'an, Shaanxi province (aka NOODLES, DUMPLINGS AND SOUP GALORE!!!). It's become my favorite place to go order take out,especially since I now live so close to the restaurant. The restaurant decor is definitely a step higher than your standard chinese restaurant in the area. It's more modern and takes an homage to the Shaanxi province. 

If there's one thing you should come here to try, it's their noodles. Their hand pulled noodles are simply the best i've had so far. Their fresh thick and chewy noodles make the difference from an 'ok' dish to an great tasting one.

In the multiple times I've come here, my favorite dish has got to be the Shaanxi Minced Pork noodles. For those who may not like hot and sour dishes, this may not be best to try but for a girl who CRAVES hot and sour soup noodles nearly every other day, it's perfect. The complex flavoring of the broth with the chewy thick freshly made noodles is divine. 

For those who may not like the spicy dishes, I would highly recommend the tomato and egg noodle soup. The noodles in this dish are EXTREMELY wide and chewy, which works well with the tomato, egg and vegetable broth. 

Keep in mind that unless you're able to read the chinese characters on the menu carefully the food items you order here may be different from the types of food you would typically order at another Chinese restaurant. For instance, one might think the spicy beef noodle dish is the same type of dish you would find at Taiwanese restaurants, which is certainly not the case. 

The reason why I would knock one star off this place is how the service can be a hit or miss (like many other chinese restaurants..). The female servers are at times, unaware of whats going on with their diners' requests. However, the owner/manager of the restaurant is extremely nice and you can tell that he genuinely cares in making sure his patrons are well taken care of. :)
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Great location, fabulous decor, good atmosphere, and good looking menu. Why the 2 stars you ask?  Because the service SUCKS that's why the 2 stars. My friend ordered an appetizer and the male waiter brought out the wrong one and instead of taking the food back and correcting the order, he proceeds to argue with her saying she ordered what he brought out. I ended up telling him to leave the item and asked him to get what she did order. After the correct appetizer finally came, we sat there for 1 hour and he never came back to the table. We had to flag down someone else 1 hr later to take our order.  The original waiter finally came to our table while we were waiting for our dinner and asked if he could take away any plates and when we said no he picked up one of the plates and proceeded to walk away. I want to note that he spoke perfect English. He was either deaf or just didn't care.  My friend had been there before and this was my first time. The menu looked better than the taste. I ordered a pork burger which was recommended by the waiter and it was plain tasting and not worth having again. The appetizers (shredded cold potato salad and cucumber salad) were okay - tastier with hot sauce though. My friend ordered some noodles and she liked her dish. For an Asian restaurant in an Asian neighborhood, the majority of the Asians there were the people that work there - that says a lot. 

If you want slooooooow service, have rude waiters with okay food this is the perfect place for you.
author: Sandra V.

description: Hot sour soup has lemongrass taste, ginger, nori, a hint of chekgong vinegar, and cilantro. It is different and tasty. We ordered several noodles, and they were all different in texture. Best noodle house around.
author: James W.

description: The food is phenomenal. Both my boyfriend and I were blown away by the quality of the noodles. Five stars hands down.
author: Shuang J.

description:
After reading a lengthy article in the recent San Francisco Chronicle, we decided to give the Terra Cotta Warrior a try.  The article praised the uniqueness of this northern Chinese cuisine and the food in Xian.  Additionally, it is close to walking distance.  After eating there, this place is not that unique and not that similar to Xian food and is rather ordinary.  While we were there, an SF police officer who handles permits had his clipboard out and was talking with restaurant management.  Maybe because they have a relatively low (81) health rating and it was follow-up

Our party of 4 arrived about 1130 on a Friday morning, just after opening.  There were a few customers and the restaurant quickly filled up.  We sat on a "picnic" type table with long bench seats with out backs.  The interior was tastefully decorated and clean.

Our waiter was receptive to questions, but did not go out of his way to explain the various cuisines that makes this restaurant different than the typical Chinese restaurants.  We finally ordered six (6) separate dishes to share.  They include the sauteed water spinach ($8.95), fried rice with five vegetables ($7.25), Chinese burger with pork ($3.95), cumin lamb burger, Qishan minced pork noodles ($7.25), and noodles with lamb ($8.95).  The last two items were soup dishes and the waiter remained mute and should have mentioned that to us.

The water spinach was drenched with chunks of garlic.  The fried rice was overly salty and way short of vegetables.  It only had tiny bits carrots and something else.  Better fried rice can be found at Cantonese hole-in-the-walls.  Both burger consisted of pieces of meat in a bun that reminds me of pita bread.  The cumin lamb burger was too spicy for some in our party.  Even though the price is modest, so is the quantity.  The Qishan soup had a sour and vinegar taste, short on pork.  The noodles were good.  The lamb soup had chunks of lamb and vegetables with thick noodles.  

In general, quality of the food does not equate to the rather high prices.  We have eaten food in Xian and the Terra Cotta Warrior is just an Americanized version of it.  Maybe the SF Chronicle article over-inflated the pluses of this place and it got to their heads.  They need to come down to earth, if they want long-term returning customers.
author: Robert J.

description: The food is fine,But the service sucks , give us shitty face only cuz we wanted our food without green onion. And the funny thing is that the person who gave us the shitty face is the owner here. Can't imagine how they gonna keep up there business
author: Serena W.

description:
I didnt have huge or high hope for this place considering the reviews but was delightfully surprised when i came here to eat on a late wed with the hubby.
Arriving at closer to 830pm, there were a few tables still occupied, mostly taiwanese enjoying their food and slurping their noodles.
We were greeted right away by one of the staff and handed a menu and tea.

After some consideration and looking at the helfpul pics on the wall we got

-lamb burger with peppers and green onion
-minced pork spicy hand pulled noodles
-pigs ear
-hot n sour dumplings.

we were very satisfied with the lamb burger, after debating whether to get this or the pork one and asking  the waiter in my broken mandarin, he suggested this one. We did and did not regret. The texture of the burger was great- bun was thin, crispy, chewy which complimented the salty bits of lamb inside along with the jalopeno peppers inside. yum! great starter for two pl.

the minced hand pulled noodles were great, the chewyness of the noodles was delicious and my hubby and I agreed it was better than house of dumplings hand pulled noodles- more delicate, refined and not as wide. better for mouth feel!

pigs ear was delicious n refreshing. It came with some shavings of vinegary cucumber, cilantro, mixed in with sliced pigs ear. We preferred this over the spicy one at house of chili on clement, and thus far that was our fav until we had this one.

hot n sour dumplings- the skin was soft and delicate, not too thick, with good filling of meat. The broth was great with a tanginess to it. Came with some seaweed on top- nice touch.

$28.

Super cheap meal and good!

Service was great as we, unlike other guests didnt have any issues with being acknowledged, seated or ordering. It was easy, perhaps we came at a good slow time, but yes i wouldnt wait anything over 30 min to eat here-

and to all the folks complaining about bad slow rude service, well this IS a chinese restaurant afterall + in SF!! 

When were you born?
author: Petri Y.

description:
First thing first, I'm biased because I'm Chinese.

This place is one of the best Chinese places in SF I've tried so far. I'm not from the Shanxi region, but my Shanxi friend told me that this is what he used to eat back home. 

Their large plate of chicken (大盘鸡, sounds better in Chinese) is a must-try, so is the ground lamb hamburger (肉夹馍). But nothing we've ordered disappointed, we've been their about four times now.

It's a bit of a drive, but definitely worth a trip.
author: Funan S.

description:
After reading the reviews, I was worried about the waiting time and bad service.  It is a common problem among restaurants to be plagued by those two factors.  My experience here was excellent.  The service was great and it took them only a few minutes before the food started to come out.  I can't say anything negative regarding my experience, this time.

What I ordered:

Shaanxi mian pi - their signature dish.  For good reason, it was good.  However, it is pretty small - an appetizer for most people.

Chinese burger with pork - delicious, crispy and well cooked.  Like the first dish, it was also on the small side of things.  

Qishan minced pork noodles - the noodle without a doubt is very good.  Freshly made and chewy.  However, there were no meat to be found.  If they were minced, it was on a microscopic level. 

Hot and soup lamb dumpling soup - tasted good, the lamb taste was mild, as it should.  Not much to complain about.  Good dish.


My only complaint overall here is the lack of content.  All the dishes are tasty, well presented, and the restaurant is nicely decorated.  However, I was hungry 2 hours later... a little more protein in the dishes won't hurt.  ;)  If you haven't been here, try it, it is worth it.
author: Jason L.

description: very good Chinese style restaurant, not the American style Chinese restaurant! Happy about that, finally can show my American friends what is the food I used to talk to them!
author: Melody H.

description: Lots of lamb choices on the menu. The stir fried lamb with cumin was had good flavor though it was pretty oily. The lamb soup with two pita bread was a basic clear broth, some meat slices, a few veggies and clear noodles, and it would do on a cold night, but didn't knock my socks off. The one notably bad thing was that the little jar of chilis at the table had stinky mold growing in it.
author: Kris F.

description: My boyfriend and I had a really poor experience here. Living in NY, we frequent XFF and we were really looking forward to trying something similar with a more restaurant-y vibe. We came on a Saturday night when it seemed busy. I signed our name in for 2 while my bf went to go find parking. They called our name and I told them to skip us as he had not found a spot yet. After 30-40 minutes of searching for a spot, we resorted to ordering takeout. I went to the counter and it took forever for them to take my order. I asked for a good, spicy, vegetarian noodle, and they suggested the hot oil noodle. So we ordered that, broccoli, and he ordered pita and lamb soup. 5 minutes after ordering, he found a spot, so I asked "the lady in the glasses" if we could have the food for here and she said "No, it's too complicated to take out of the containers." This was a little annoying as there was no longer a wait for tables, but I accepted it as it seemed as if our food was already in the containers and ready to go. NOPE. We waited another 45+ minutes for our takeout to be ready... We watched people who sat while we waited get their food before us. The way the manager made it seem, was that our food was ready. I really don't understand why we couldn't have eaten it there if our order hasn't even gone through yet. Knowing that handpulled noodles don't taste as good after sitting, I decided to eat in the car. My noodles that we waited 45+ minutes for were COLD. They weren't spicy at all, which I asked for, and they were extremely salty and chewy. My boyfriend's lamb soup literally had 1 piece of lamb in it, which is a huge ripoff. This place left a horrible taste in my mouth after this experience. Next time I'm in SF I am not returning and I will gladly stick to my $6.00 Liang Pi from Xi'an Famous Foods. No thanks.
author: Laurel H.

description: 03.16.14 review update - 45 min after ordering, and we've only received our cold dishes thus far (yes, I'm writing this from the restaurant).  Proceed with caution when visiting here on the weekends (my first 4 star visit was on a weekday). Unexpectedly crowded, many dishes are sold out, and sloooooooow to receive our order as they must not have expected such high demand.  Hate to give only 2 stars, since food is still good compared to my first visit, but they won't earn their extra 2 stars back until they work out these opening kinks.
author: Mel T.

description:
I cannot stop thinking about the dinner I had last night! So good!

The prices were great considering the amount we ordered. We had 5 dishes and the bill came out to be around $30! Not bad at all!

We had the:
- Shaanxi mianpi
-Hot and sour pork dumplings
-Pita bread soaked in lamb soup
-Jelly fish appetizer
-Noodles with sizzling oil

SHAANXI MIANPI:
A must try! This was the first dish to come out and it was my favorite.  It was also only $3.95. The sauce was so good that my friends and I were drinking it (woops). We were super hungry so don't judge! Anyway, the sauce was basically chili oil mixed with vinegar. Tastes better than it sounds, trust me!

HOT AND SOUR PORK DUMPLINGS:
This dish was alright, I liked the taste of the hot and sour soup but the dumplings tasted average to me. Nothing special, but still simple and good. 

PITA BREAD IN LAMB SOUP:
Very special, never had tiny diced cubes of dough floating around in my soup before but it was pretty good. Definitely really filling because of the dough. They call it pita bread but it was more like doughy cubes. The taste of lamb is not overbearing. Overall, it felt like a very homey, comfort food-like dish. I can imagine drinking this on a cold, rainy day. My least favorite dish though because it didn't have as much flavor/spunk compared to the other dishes I had.

JELLY FISH APPETIZER:
So refreshing! I personally love jellyfish, so this appetizer made my tastebuds very happy. It was more like a jellyfish salad because of all the veggies it came with, but I enjoyed it a lot. It helped balance out all the starchy noodles I was having from the other dishes.

NOODLES WITH SIZZLING OIL:
We didn't mix these very well so it got pretty salty towards the end, but I would say that this was my 2nd favorite dish of the night. This was similar to the Shaanxi Mianpi, which is probably why I liked it so much. 

Everything here is just so good. Great ambiance and decor as well. Can't wait to come back and try everything else!
author: Annie L.

description: For Americans, it's definitely sth new and special. Because there is not a lot of Chinese northwestern food here. I love it!
author: Olivia Z.

description: AMAZING Chinese food! Not at all your typical Chinese Americanized cuisine but with great prices. I would have easily paid 4X more for the spicy fish, beef lung in chili oil, lamb with soaked pita, lamb dumplings, cold noodles and beer we had for barely more than $50. All these dishes had unique flavors e.g. numbing, sour, hot, umami etc. with my favorite being the fish in chili oil and beef lung. My boyfriend and his dad (Westerners) loved the lamb with soaked pita and dumplings the best as well as the cold noodles and the Tsingtao beer went with all the food as an excellent pairing. I wish I could eat here every week :)
author: Amy Y.

description:
Whoa! A wait in the Sunset? Damn you 7x7 - this is what happens when something gets featured on there. 

Everything we ordered was pretty good. 

Minced Pork Noodle Soup - handpulled noodles with a delicious broth. I didn't enjoy the minced pork much, but the soup is good enough to overlook this.

Pork Dumpling Soup - Delicious and vinegary. Big dumplings with lots of tender meat. 

Pork burger - this was pretty good. Crispy bun wrapped around some pork at 3.95 is a steal. 

Shanxi mian pi - cold, spicy noodle dish. This was a sleeper hit, a little spicy with some vinegar and utterly addictive. 

All of this for $24. When do I get to come back?
author: Mel L.

description:
This is the best meal I have had in SF for a while and I eat out at great SF restaurants frequently.  The handmade noodles are divine.  The Shanxi cold noodles with sesame sauce where so clean and refreshing and so homemade tasting, sweet and yummy too. The sweet and sour lamb dumpling soup is deeply nourishing and again both very cleansing and filling simultaneously.  The lotus root and spinach were perfect vegetable sides and I can't wait to come back and try the lamb burgers that look similar to Chairman Bao treats.

The staff was very sweet and the atmosphere is a soothing dark, wood tea house style.
author: Amy S.

description: Loved everything I ate. I want everyone to try the shredded potatoes, cabbage with chili sauce, lotus root slices in chili sauce, sauteed water spinach, and mapo tofu. So worth the trek to the Outer Sunset and the long wait.
author: Michelle G.

description:
Firstly, if you can't handle spicy foods, this place isn't for you.  But if you love the numbing heat from peppercorns and Chinese food, this place is definitely at least a must try.

Overall, I rate the heat levels of all the spicy foods around a jalapeno level or less.  I did not encounter anything spicier.  This concept is key to this style of cooking.  They're not attempting to blow your head off with heat.  It's all about cooking the chili flavor into the meats and dishes served here, and on this, they executed it very well for the stir-fried dishes.  You should expect the numbing feeling from dishes served with peppercorns:


I came here for lunch and my group order about 6 dishes from the menu.

5-star dishes:
The spicy cold noodle dish, served in a bowl, seasoned with chili oil, and mixed with vegetables (usually cucumbers) was fantastic.  We tried two versions.  The spicier version definitely is the better one.  There is a picture uploaded by an user showing this dish.

Lamb soup with vermicelli was the best.  It's a light broth with a small helping of greens, vermicelli, and meat.  The broth was very flavorful and has the homemade taste.

Spicy braised chicken with noodles - This is a large stir fry dish of soy sauce based chicken, peppercorns, red chilis, and noodles.   This dish really hits home if you're looking for spicy flavoring.  The heat level is bit less a jalapeno level, so it's not really intense.  But this dish is fantastic b/c the flavor of the chilis is cooked into the meat and noodles.  My only compliant would be the peppercorn balls in the dish.  They are essential to the flavor and the numbing effects, but it's a bit tedious to pick it out before you eat it. (though you don't have to pick them out at all).


4-star dishes:
Lamb & Pork Burger - tried both versions.  The burger with the minced peppers, green onions are the best.  The burger that appeared to be just seasoned meat was more 3-stars in my book

3-star dishes:
The cold spinach, and other cold vegetable dishes were average.  They were generally mildly-seasoned and mixed with oil.  I suppose cold dishes are a must have if you were dinning with a large group Chinese patrons at your table, but I would skip these fillers next time.

Service experience was average.  The waiters' attitudes were positive and friendly.  Service speed and responsiveness was average to below average due to the volume.
author: Mike D.

description: Not great; noodles were odd and not as spicy or good-tasting as we wanted them to be.
author: Gabe B.

description:
Wavering between 3 and 4 stars because I've only liked half the dishes I've tried here, but the ones I like are so addictive.  My favorites so far are the Shaanxi mian-pi, pork with hot pepper burger, and jelly fish in mixed sauce.  I like spicy food and can handle it, but I don't like sour food.  That's why I didn't particularly like the hot and sour dumpling soup and the popular Qishan minced pork noodle since the broth for both seem too sour for me.  

When you order, it seems like the servers take precautions to make sure you do not have any misconceptions about what you're ordering.  They tell you which dish you're ordering is spicy and ask you if you're OK with that.  When we ordered the mu-shu pork, they made sure to tell us that it's not the American style with the wrapper.  

With all the Asian restaurants in the area, it's nice to have a unique one that can introduce us to authentic Shaanxi cuisine.  If you can handle eating spicy peppers, come and try it out.
author: Renee L.

description: Rudest service I've ever experienced. Less than 5 min after we paid our waitress directly asked us to leave the restaurant. Not because we didn't leave enough tip or ordered enough food, just because they wanted to turn over faster.
author: C S.

description:
It's a small place and it seems to be packed every time we pass by! Eating there was an awesome and spicy experience. Food was at our table fast and everything we ordered was good... But can we get a REFILL on our TEA! Hehe !

BTW eat and enjoy your food! BUT can you eat with less CHIT CHAT OTHER PEOPLE ARE HUNGRY! ... You know who you are... THIS AINT A SOCIAL CLUB!
author: Wu T.

description: Came in today at about 730..no wait. Was recommended this restaurant and it was really really good.  Had jellyfish in mix saucecand it was so refreshing. Shaanxi stir-fried noodles was very tasty and for sure would order again.  Ordered Chinese burger with pork while sister ordered pork with hot pepper burger. Both burgers good size and cut in half so we each got to share our burger. Hers was spicy... Very spicy..but delish. Want to come back and try soup next. Pictures of food are on the wall and look appetizing.
author: Jaclyn S.

description:
One of the benefits of globalization is the opened access we have to some of the more nuanced cuisines inside of China. 

Terra Cotta Warrior serves Xian cuisine, which is typified by bright flavors and ingredients and, in particular, a playful balance between sour, salty and spicy flavors. 

The result, when well executed, is a really tasty cuisine which is exemplified by dishes like jellyfish with fresh vegetables, spicy lamb dumplings, and noodles with sizzling oil. 

This restaurant -- like many other Chinese restaurants -- struggles with the question of whether to stay true to authentic Xian cuisine (where the intensity of sourness and spiciness may turn off diners who aren't used to the cuisine) or adapt it to more western palates by reducing the spiciness and the sour crispness of the cuisine. 

They have recently been leaning more towards the western palate. I think some of this makes sense, but I hope they don't dilute the cuisine any more! 
San Francisco diners are sophisticated and I like to think folks can appreciate the brighter contrasts of a more authentic interpretation of Xian cuisine. 
So, if you the restaurant is reading he reviews: don't be afraid to be authentic with the flavors!
author: Kit T.

description: I only had Shanxi Mianpi and pork stuffed bun. The Mianpi tasted good but not the noodles. The noodles wasn't that chewy as what I had in the South Bay. But I guess it's how shanxi Mianpi tastes. Pork stuffed bun was ok. Not whole lot of meat on it. I ordered 4 of Mianpi but they forgot one. I found it after I got home. Too far to get it:(
author: Leylia N.

description: This place was very good. Different from the normal Chinese style restaurant. If you are used to the canton flavors then this place is not it. Be open minded. The flavors are more northern Chinese. I would definitely come here again. This place gets busy so come early. They don't speak much English so be prepared.
author: Valerie A.

description:
The food is great, the service... not so much.

The noodles were the chewiest and best tasting I've had.  With the recent influx of "handmade" or "knife cut" noodles in SF there is stiff competition.  Had the "chinese burger" the Shanxi stir fried noodles and the Qishan Minced Pork Noodles.  Both noodle dishes don't really have a lot of meat, but the taste is excellent and you better be able to deal with the spice level.  

However, it took an hour for 3 relatively simple dishes.  The kitchen appeared to be backed up at opening on a Sunday as the Qishan noodles made an appearance to 4 tables at once, all of which sat at various different times.  Apparently only one member on staff could take orders at the time, as we had to get the attention of the two other staff members for us to get our order in.  

Taste of the food overwhelms the negatives of the timing and the service, so, take out for now, maybe try dine-in later and hope they get their timing together later.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Great little place. If in the area I would definitely stop by. Quite different if you're not into exploring different food types, but  if you want to try a place unlike anything you've had before, go here. Prompt service and quick to get food too
author: Jimmy S.

description: First time here!  Brings back memories of my wonderful trip to Xian.  Decor is warm, handmade noodles, spices and flavoring of their dishes are delicious!  This is a nice little secret in the neighborhood!  Glad to have discovered it!
author: Darlene H.

description: I took my family here to try out this restaurant.  My dad loves the handmade noodles but the appetizers wasn't too impressive.   Maybe just come here for their noodles next time but nothing else.   The place is small.  Not recommended for big party.  2 to 4 people should be fine.  Parking arent so bad if you come before 7pm.  They don't take reservations. ..come before 6 and you should have no problem with seating for small group.
author: Wasabi L.

description:
Tried the sauteed water spinach ($9.95), Shaanxi braised spicy fish ($12.95), braised chicken and potato and pepper ($20.95), Qishan minced pork noodles ($8.95), noodles with beef ($8.95), and hot and sour pork dumpling soup.  The spinach, noodles with beef, and pork dumpling soup were good, but nothing really special that you couldn't get at any other Chinese restaurant; these were the only dishes my group finished.  The rest of the food had a *ton* of red peppers floating around in a *lot* of oil and liquid.  

The braised chicken looked spectacular when it arrived but was by far the least favorite of our group; there were 3 different types of peppers in the dish and one of them, when crushed while chewing, became gritty...somewhat like eating sand! The chicken was chopped into small portions, but there were small fragments of bone to contend with as you ate. The only good part of the dish were the noodles at the bottom, but because the food was mounded up so high and the dish was so full, it was difficult to get to the noodles; and when you did, the noodles were so long that it was difficult to get them in your bowl without making a mess. 

The spicy fish also came in a large amount of very oily liquid with lots of red peppers floating around; it was a strange dish that contained not only some fish but a piece of something that looked like Spam, some tofu, and something else that looked like well done liver... as I said, strange!  Both the chicken and fish came in huge portions, but because they weren't very popular with our party, there was a LOT left of both dishes. 


No serving utensils are given with the dishes, so everyone eats family style, I guess. We're all adept at using chopsticks, but it was difficult getting the very long noodles into our bowls. It would help if you took a pair of kitchen scissors to the restaurant with you!

The service was not great either; I had to ask for boxes for the leftover food 3 times. Quite frankly, I don't think anyone in my household will eat the leftovers, but I thought I'd take the food to see if somebody else would like to try it.  There were 5 adults and a child in our party, but only 5 place settings were given to us; we had to ask for another one. Each time we asked for anything (i.e. water), only 5 were brought to the table... I guess the 3 year old wasn't supposed to eat or drink! 

All in all, a very disappointing experience. I don't think we'll be returning any time soon.
author: Annie W.

description: A different type of cuisine from China. This is not your typical Chinese Restaurant. I especially enjoyed the pita bread lamb soup and the spicy noodles. The mixed jelly fish was refreshing and tasty. A word of caution, if you don't like the gamey taste of lamb you will not like the lamb soup. That gamey flavor does not go away. I also had the bun too which was a little too dry for my liking. Overall, a decent place to come for a nice warm bowl of soup.
author: Wendy L.

description: No big deal. Seems like every dish on the menu is noodles or buns. Not a lot of meat or protein to eat. It's also a small menu.  Paper menu like the menus restaurants pass out to the front of your house. It's a nice looking restaurant.  But if you're really hungry, be ready to eat noodles of buns. I've posted pictures on yelp.  We ordered six dishes. Of the six, three of the dishes are the sand noodles. Just prepared differently. One in soup. One stir fry with a little bit of meat and veggies. And another is a spicy soup sauce. Food tasted okay. Not bad. Restaurant looks clean and nice.
author: Jack L.

description: Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. The cold chicken scallion oil dish is amazing! I also like the lamb I'm cumin dish but it was too spicy for my sensitive stomach. Next time I'll just ask to have it be mild, then I would absolutely order that dish.
author: Michelle M.

description: Very bad experience in this place，the chicken is smelly and there is a bug in pancake！I have a stomachache now！Do not go to this place
author: Teng F.

description: Wonderful little Chinese restaurant located in beautiful Sunset district. Decor is inviting and food is delicious. The food is Shan Xi with flavor that are typically spicy and little sour. They are also famed for their noodles. It's refreshing to have Shan Xi cuisine amongst the mass of Cantonese cuisine in the sunset.  Service is nice and did I mention the food is delicious. Highly recommended.
author: Ellen T.

description:
This is my fav chinese restaurant all the time, I go there every week for at least once, my fav is the chinese lamp burger and some soup, I hav been to Shanxi and the food just taste like this!
you wont be disappointed about any dishes, they are all amazing, but if you dont eat spicy, makes sure to tell them.
its just amazing.
author: Sharon C.

description: Finally tried this place! Brought my parents here they've been in xi'an for decades so they are good judges for authenticity. Lamb dumplings, sour spicy noodles,xinjiang noodles, all the right flavor. Portion not huge but we are quite satisfied. So glad that my hometown restaurant is around!
author: Rong Y.

description:
This place is a great find, a true gem.  

I have only tried about 5-6 things on the menu despite being here many times, because those 5-6 things are always so good I have no need to order anything else.  

Must haves:  
Cucumber salad (I don't know what their secret is, but I've found nothing that matches it anywhere in SF, despite much effort, and despite how simple it is.  Trust me.)
Cumin Lamb (perfect amount of spice, nice onions, great lamb, oily, but good)
Burger with Pork (Amazing.)

Service is not perfect, but that's not why you come here.  Their wait staff seems to be a bunch of youngsters not professionally trained, but friendly and well intentioned.  Cut them some slack, enjoy your darn good food, and you'll leave happy, I'm sure.  Ambiance of the place is pretty good too.  Well worth the drive from just about anywhere in the city or beyond.
author: Mark H.

description:
The food is great.  As a long-time resident of Sunset used to dime-a-dozen Cantonese and Hong Kong restaurants in the hood, it's refreshing to see a Chinese place that is spicy and tasty and not strictly Sichuanese.  

We ordered the $20 chicken and potato dish.  That dish is HUGE.  It contains not just chicken and potato, but also a hidden trove of hand pulled noodles underneath.  Took a couple days just to finish the leftovers.  Also had the lamb burger which was bomb.  Definitely going back.
author: Tommy Q.

description: Food is delicious, staff is wonderful. Minced pork noodle soup is one of the house specialties, Pita soaked in lamb soup is wonderful - in fact, I've never had a single dish that wasn't awesome. Prices are reasonable, and you will wait on weekends. I've never had Shanxi food in China so I can't speak to the authenticity, but I love the place. I always experience courteous, helpful service. Try it!
author: Stephen E.

description: I'm so grateful that I've found this hidden gem! I'm from shaanxi, I miss the taste of our food! I love their shaanxi mian-pi,  noodle, and side dishes, I'd come here whenever I have chance.
author: Kelly C.

description: Wish I  can give them zero star. Customer services are HORRIBLE!!!!!!Do not come here, PLEASE!!!
author: Henry Z.

description: The food here is excellent. We came for lunch and had the minced pork soup - delicious homemade noodles and really flavorful broth - pork dumpling soup - perfectly spiced broth with a ton of cilantro for extra flavor - and finally a cold pickled cabbage dish. Everything was super tasty and I will definitely be back. The only down side was the depressing music selection playing in the background.
author: Peter S.

description:
I have been to Terra Cotta Warrior twice. I came here a second time because I really wanted to like this place, and also because it is conveniently located so close to my house. After the second time going to this restaurant, I can confidently say that I will never ever come here again. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND Terra Cotta Warrior to anyone. 

The first time we came, we ordered minced pork noodles. The dish lacked flavor and depth. Mediocre at best. The noodles were mushy and all I tasted in the broth was a hint of spiciness with not much else. The service was fine, so at this point I would have given it 2 or maybe 2.5 stars. 

Today, I wanted to give them a second chance by ordering something different. The second time I came is what really caused me to give this place a 1 star rating. I showed up and waited for over 25 minutes for someone to take our order. After about 15 minutes I told one of the waiters that I was ready to order and he nodded in acknowledgement yet continued to ignore me. He continued to clean other empty tables behind us but there wasn't anyone waiting in line to be seated! They should have addressed the customer who was sitting and waiting to place his order rather than clean tables that didn't need to be cleaned right away since no one is waiting in line to be seated in the first place. I waited patiently for ten more minutes before I noticed that the two people who had sat down AFTER me were already being served food! Keep in mind, I haven't even been able to SPEAK TO A WAITER YET AFTER TWENTY FIVE MINUTES!! 

The food is mediocre at best and the service is terrible. I will happily tell all of my friends in the neighborhood never to go to this restaruant because they don't respect their customers.
author: John M.

description: They ask you to leave before you finished your food. Very rude! This kind of behavior has never happened to me ever. I can't believe people behave in such a selfish and rude manner. I've been to thousands of restaurants in my life and not once has a restaurant ever ask me to leave before I finished my food. I can tell you the names of thousands of restaurants that will not ask you to leave before you finished eating. Do NOT eat at this restaurant! IT WILL RUIN your night!
author: Fan W.

description: Very eager to try after seeing Raving reviews despite recent change of management/chef(?). However very disappointed by the Shaozimian, the soup is not tasteful and pork belly chops not fresh. Shanxi mianpi is good, but not too exciting. Wish I had stopped by before it was closed for a couple months due to food safety issues. Overall a disappointment.
author: Foodie F.

description: Food is good. Portions are small compared to other chinese restaurants. Service is bad. The manager needs to hire at least two more waitresses for the weekends. We were told to "wait a min" a few times when we tried to order, ask for a water refill, ask for the check and a to go box. They don't ask who the dish is for and where to place it on the table. They just push the bowl with hot soup onto the edge of the table and rush away. One waitress had water in her hand when she walked by and I asked for a refill. She said " hold on" and walked to three tables away and offered them a water refill when she could have poured some water in my cup, which would literally take three seconds.... Anyways, decent food, bad service
author: H M.

description: Yummm! This smallish, beautifully decorated gem was packed today.  Some wonderful dishes that I loved are the:  Pig Ears Appetizer served with sliced cucumbers and garlic, Vegetable Fried Rice, Lamb Dumplings and the Pork Hamburger was delicious.  Service was fast, food was delicious and will definitely be back to try their noodle dishes!  =)
author: Steph Y.

description: Yum! Seriously. Definitely worth the trek out there. Not your typical Americanized Chinese food, it's way better.
author: Andrea W.

description:
lamb noodles. so so so fresh and clean. the broth was clear and almost a bit bland? i can't explain it. lacking a lot of lamb meat in this extremely large bowl of soup, but the noodles made up for it. my friend however, did not like their lamb noodle soup at all because there wasn't enough meat for him. i, on the other hand, really enjoyed the broth and noodles. it was perfect for me. i really appreciate good broth and understand the time and love it takes to master perfect soup. it's definitely not as dark in color as all other lamb noodle soups i've had in the area. i'm just going to assume that it's much healthier, cleaner and has less crap in it. i prefer food to be cooked this way and would definitely come back. 

spicy dumplings served in some sort of sour broth was perfect. nothing i've ever had before so it was different for me. can't hurt to give this place a try. the dishes are quite obviously from a particular region in china. not exactly common which is cool.

oh, and superrrrrrrr chewy noodles. all of them! as it goes for every restaurant in the world, not every item on their menu will be good. some dishes were just not worth trying a second time.
author: Thao T.

description: It is the worst dining experience ever. If I could, I would have given this no stars. Service was exceptionally bad - no bowls were provided for a long time for our appetizer soup dish and they forgot one of our dishes. When we asked the manager about it, he told us that he would check but never got back to us. The missing dish showed up 5 mins after everyone was done eating, so we rejected it. The waitress did not check in with us once after she took our order - no water, no bowls etc. The food was mediocre. Ordered the Szechuan pepper chicken and it was all bones. This place is not worth your time or money.
author: Stefanie N.

description: Delicious and fresh. Hands down some of the tastiest Chinese food I've ever had. Definitely get the lamb curry burger, you will NOT be sorry!
author: Ashley M.

description: One star for the decoration, one star for the unique  noodle.   Food taste so so.  The older waiter was rude when talking to us.   I had to wait half hour for a bowl of lamb noodle.  The people who ordered the food after me, almost done with their food, and my noodle hasn't show up yet.   They didn't even care that they forgot about my order.  At the end, after we are done, all the workers are busy counting receipts,  no one bother to check up on us.   This place has no customer service at all.    I wouldn't say the price is cheap either.    It's such a small place, yet they still failed  to take care of the customers.  I  know I won't go back to this place for a long time.  Don't know why most small Chinese restaurant workers in here never learn customer service.  Restaurant workers are more professional in China than in here.
author: Lucy J.

description: After spending 1.5 hour on the road, we arrived around 1pm on Saturday afternoon. After waiting in the front for 5 minutes, someone finally came and told us they've run out of basically everything. The restaurant wasn't crowded and we were the only two waiting, still it took them 5 minutes to come to tell us the simple fact. If I can give 0 star on a review, I would.
author: Angela Y.

description: man sucks this place closed. wonder why it had to close. i come here at least once a week and now its gone. says will be under new management in august so i hope the food is still good when they open again.
author: Dave Z.

description: I really, really wanted to like this place. It sounded delicious, and how could you go wrong with hand pull noodles. The noodles were good, however, the dishes that contained them were so greasy. The appetizer cold noodles were the tastiest of all we tried, but even those were soaked in tons of oil. I think this place needs to work out the kinks a bit. The restaurant was full, and the older waiter was sitting at the bar just surfing his phone. Bad form. With so many great choices nearby, its hard to say Iif I'd return.
author: Gwenn G.

description: Wow I tried 5 dishes and each one was unique and tasty. I definitely haven't had anything close to this before. I'll be back!
author: Janet B.

description: Place is surprisingly beautiful.  Food is wonderfully different, but the LADY waitress is rude and unfriendly and that would make me not want to come back nor recommend it.  Too bad.  I am a restaurant owner in San Francisco for 22 years and know how it goes.  Not like this.
author: Noel K.

description: I love liang pi, so this place gets 4 stars just for offering it. I liked the original way better than the peanut and/or sesame version. All the noodle dishes were good, and the burgers were yummy too.
author: Jenny J.

description: This place was better than I expected. The portions are huge and there are both spicy and non-spicy options. I've never tried Shanxi cuisine and was pleasantly surprised. The pita bread in lamb soup was really trippy and a nice alternative to the spicier minced pork noodles. Both were HUGE portions. Also tried the mian pi, which came in a tasty spicy sauce, and the pickled cucumbers which were pleasantly garlicky the way I like (and if I see it on a menu, I'm always ordering it). Would love to try some other dishes!
author: Andrey C.

description:
fresh off a northwestern china cooking class, we came here to explore more of the regional cuisine.

other reviewers get the food descriptions right, so i'll just sum it up:

lots of spicy things. lots of red chili oil. noodles, dumplings, soup, bread.

this region features very flavorful and spicy food, which i love.

i'll definitely be back when i'm in the area.
author: Shawn C.

description:
My first visit to Terra Cotta Warrior was a few days before their opening day. Everything was so new that the entire menu was handwritten in Chinese -- often a good sign for some authentic grub, so long as you bring along a friend who speaks the language to do the ordering for you. 

Too new that they were not even on Yelp. To be honest, if I wrote this review that night. I would have given it at least 4 starts. The service was alright, the food was great. I remember telling my friend that this place deserved a good review. 

I was hoping I quickly become a regular here. I've been to this restaurant at least a handful of times since. The service and food has slowly been declining since my first visit. The food isn't consistent --not just in how it's made but in quality. If they even have what you want. And most of of the time, they either don't have it, can't do it, won't do it, or they ask if you'll wait while they make more. Only if the kitchen actually made more and did not cancel your order without communicating with you.

Only a couple months in, and it's already very disappointing.
author: Jake M.

description: Don't come to this restaurant! Horrible service!!! They have a bizarre rule that they don't allow people to sit until all the people in the group have arrived. We were originally excited to try out this restaurant so we two (out of four) came all the way from South Bay Friday night caught in heavy traffic for 1.5 hours. When we get there our two other friends hadn't arrived. The waitress insisted that we can not sit at the table although there are at least 5 tables are wildly available. We ended up waiting at the door for 30 minutes until all our friends came. Off the chart stupidity. They don't care about customers at all. I don't see this business holds up long.
author: Reviewer T.

description: What else can I say?! This is an absolutely awesome place for Chinese local food! I think I should come here once per week. I may very well.
author: Dong C.

description: This is definitely the best hand pull noodles in town. Most of the dishes are a bit spicy and sour. For starter, we had cucumber salad, spinach with ginger sauce and pork with garlic sauce. I only like the thin slice pork with garlic sauce. For noodles, you must order with the sizzling oil. It was so good. Spicy and sort of numbing your tongue. We also tried qishan minced pork, scramble egg with tomato noodles, they are all different thickness of noodles. I already want to go back for the noodles with sizzling oil when I'm writing this review!!!
author: Julie H.

description: We came here during lunch and I heard that it can get pretty crowded during dinner time. We had the cucumber salad, spicy lamb dumplings and the noodle soup. The spicy lamb dumplings were really good and not too spicy. The cucumber salad was yummy but the portions were not too big. I am not a big fan of noodle soups but this one was just "good enough" and not exceptional. Overall the food is great for the price.
author: Rosanna T.

description: Love this place and most of their house specials are super great and authentic. 3 star this time for the chongqing spicy chicken..... Too crunchy and dry... Well I should not order a Szechuan dish at a Northwestern style Chinese cuisine place anyway.  I'd give 4 or 5 stars next time I come again trying their house special only.
author: Bo W.

description: Love this new spot in the  sunset. It's so refreshing to have a different style of Chinese food that is stir fried. Noodles are so fresh :)
author: Jaymee S.

description: I love noodles, and this is the place to go for noodles! I love this place. Everything is so unique; it's quite a refreshing change from the usual sweet and sour this, or kung pao that. Favorites are the shredded potatoes appetizer, and the noodles in sizzling oil. The braised fish is quite good, with tingly sichuan peppercorns! I can't wait to go back and try something new!
author: Marc C.

description: I am glad to find this Chinese restaurant to try Shanxi food. I visited Xian many times when I was a little girl and I have been crazy about Liangpi since then. Fortunately, I found this restaurant  and I have tried many Shanxi dishes in SF. My husband and I ordered cold crystal chicken which was really good, Chinese burger with lamb meat (Yummy), Shanxi cold rice noodle(Liangpi), cold rice noodle with sesame sauce, and Lamb soup with soaked pita bread. All dishes tasted good and we were so full after we finished all of them. The waiter who served our table were nice, polite and attentive. We definitely go back to try more noodle dishes. By the way, we like the decoration of the restaurant.
author: Wendy W.

description: Was recommended by a friend from Shanghai. Amazing hand-made noodles. Got the Mian pi with sesame sauce first. Super fresh and very rich! Then the noodle with sizzling oil and another dish I don't remember the name of. Both were very good and definitely handmade. Loved our server, was so friendly and gave perfect recommendations.
author: Tyler W.

description: Texture of the lamb and cold noddles are so so. The way it delivers the taste is not perfect. Recommend the lamb hamburger.
author: Wesley C.

description: These hand made high-gluten noodles are on point. Yesssssirrrrr. Sizzling oil noodles are tasty, but be sure to dress them up with some more soy and vinegar- as they were a bit bland as is. I'll def be back to sample some more delectables.
author: Anthony R.

description: I really like this restaurant, I came San Francisco from northern china, I know they do good job, I will be there again. And food is sooo yumm! Mianpi, chinese burger...
author: Dave T.

description: We love the lamb dumpling soup- it is a comfort food and has a tangy broth. We pair it with the cucumber salad, the wide noodles and the spinach side. It's a nice environment and very affordable!
author: Helen M.

description: Awesome.  I don't get out to the outer sunset often, so when I found myself out this way my friends and I took another friend's rec and tried terra cotta warrior.  We were not dissapointed.  The lamb dumpling soup was amazing and the side of spinach and garlic was a treat.  We also had a sesame dish I can't pronounce and then decided to order more.  We finished up with some stir fry lamb and cold crystal chicken.  The lamb was really tender and perfectly spicy while the sweet chicken was really tasty as well.  I already want to return.
author: Bob V.

description: I recognized a cute girl eating there from my gym. She was with whom I assume was her boyfriend, but that don't matter cause the food was good. And for a Chinese resto, the place was clean. So yeah, I recommend
author: Chaz G.

description: I came to celebrate a birthday dinner with family - the food is really good - we had the classic lamb dish, the lamb pita soup, the eggs with tofu, and a fish with bell peppers dish. The only reason this was not a five star experience is because the restaurant does not take reservations so there can be quite a wait.
author: H C.

description: Learned it from the SF Chronicle.  Truly enjoyed Pita Bread Soaked in Lamb Soup, Noodles with Sizzling Oil, Spinach with Ginger Sauce and Celery with Dried Bean Curd Sticks.  Service is fine and place is not big but clean and cozy.  I am planning to visit there two weeks after.
author: Patricia W.

description: As authentic a Shaanxi place as you can get, try lamb soup with pita bread, and any noodle dish here.
author: Tian W.

description: Very good and authentic central/northwestern Chinese food.  Yes, i have been to Xian! Make sure you check your bill as they forgot a dish we ordered (which we then cancelled yet still got charged for).  Also try not to go to the restroom if you can avoid it....you know what i mean.  Finally, they do not keep the place heated....everyone eating here was wearing their hats and jackets!  I would come back for the food, when the craving is there as their brand speciality is something that the Sunset has not had much of any before.  This place is a very welcome break from all the Canton/Sichuan/Shanghai Chinese restaurants.
author: Jason C.

description: Authentic Shaanxi cuisine. My husband who's from Xi'an and I had a lovely meal here. The restaurant is nicely decorated with comfortable seating. Our dishes came quickly after we ordered. The Lamb soup with skinny clear noodles and "Chinese Dow /pizza" was amazing (羊肉泡馍）. The cold spicy green bean noodle (凉皮/面皮）appetizer was perfectly prepared. If you like spicy food you will love the spicy dishes here. Lastly the pork burger (肉夹馍）is authentic (without cilantro) and not too greasy. Wish there's a place like this in Chicago where we live!!
author: S t.

description: There are not so many choices on the menu,but each dish we Oder taste super yummy,and it's very typical Chinese food(cos I am Chinese),their service is good,the dishes come up fast and look good,taste even better,I'll definetly come back again.And the environment is very good in the restaurant.
author: Judy H.

description:
So I made a review under "Terracotta Warrior" rather than "Terra Cotta Warrior".  Below is what I posted on the "Terracotta Warrior" review.

AMZAZING.  Refreshing to have a Chinese restaurant open up without an overlapping menu of the same tired items.  I'll warn you though...  Some items are spicy.  I really liked the spinach with ginger and the noodles with sizzling oil.

We will be back to explore more of their menu
author: Nate W.

description: As a half Xi'an nese. the most traditional and awesome place to eat Xian food in San Francisco.
author: Cherry C.

description: On a cold and dreary Saturday in SF my daughter ( a local) took me to Terra Cotta Warrior for some "noodles." While we waited I checked out the other diner's plates - fantastic looking plates of chicken, giant plates of noodles. We shared the excellent lamb soup and the Shanxi Stir fried wide noodles - fantastically stretchy, chewy with a spicy red sauce. A cucumber appetizer (simple but delicately flavored) help offset the heat. Highly recommend it. Prices very reasonable. I need to go back at least 5 times in order to sample the other dishes.
author: Steve D.

description: The host, I assume also owner, is very personable and gave some good recommendations. This is shaanxi cuisine; so spicy but not very. Their menu is simple and all of what we ordered was good. Cumin lamb is delicious. So was the noodle with sizzling oil. They have great hot sauce that they probably make themselves.
author: H C.

description: Usually I won't write such review. However, we are really mad and upset about the experience with this restaurant! Service is really really slow and the tea is light like water! The dishes are so salty and they added MSG! They changed our noodle type without asking us. Their portion is small, especially the Hot peppers preserved eggs. I won't say eggs, it maybe just have one egg in the dish. I asked the waitress, and she said "that's because the dish is so cheap here!" Really! I have been so many ShaanXi restaurants! This is the worst one and as I am born in ShaanXi, I feel shame of this restaurant! So suggestion is never go there!
author: Zhangzhang L.

description: Forgot our order and refused to admit that they forgot. After 30 minutes, we still had no food, so we left. Shit service and no respect for customers
author: Andrew D.

description: thums up to their  lamb soup with soaked pita bread! The best I've had outside of Xi'An in China. Will come back to try other dishes.
author: Eleanor C.

description: We have been looking for chewy long noodle soups and dishes. And finally found one that we liked a lot. Their noodles are so long we had to borrow a pair of scissors to cut before we can share. We will need to make several more visits to taste every dish.
author: Manabu T.

description: Love the food there and the great service there! Their spicy chicken is the best a definite must try!
author: Michael P.

description: They just raise prices on all their dishes by 20-30%. Fried rice for $10.00 with no visible ham or shrimp? Food is decent but with the recent price hike, we won't be going as often. My favorite hot and sour soup pork dumpling soup is now out the door about $10.00. Guess that's good for all those people who are willing to wait in line for this restaurant.
author: Dinah Y.

description: The decor and service of this restaurant were absolutely amazing. Everything on the menu looked great. The hand-pulled noodles were so chewy.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
I'm liking the noodles here, very fresh and good texture. They have quite a few to select from but ours came in a soup that was mildly sour like the taste of suan cai. We also had the pork lung which was great at first, but eventually become too large to eat. If you've never eaten pork lung you should check it out here. 

The interior is nice compared to many Irving/Judah places and the service is friendly. I'm looking forward to coming back to try another one of their noodle dishes.
author: m K.

description: I like this place and it is pretty authentic Shaanxi cuisine (make sure you order the house special dishes). I am so happy that finally there are other style of Chinese cuisine in America.
author: Ming L.

description: One of the best, most authentic, and well-priced Northern Chinese food in SF. The big tray of chicken was amazing! We ordered the small serving with some other plates and it was plenty for 6 people. The chicken was cooked so tenderly and the noodles were soo bouncy. One of the best for sure!
author: Richard C.

description: We sampled a large variety of their dishes, all were tasty. My 10 year old daughter and I liked the pork burger the best, 9 year old son liked the noodles with beef, husband liked the cumin lamb.
author: Hope C.

description:
This is one of the best Northen Chinese Cousine restaurant in the city. 
We tried the following, and each was good. 

1. 岐山哨子面 (noodles are chewy, can tell it's handmade)
2. 陕西面皮 (good, not the greatest, but hey, it's SF)
3. 孜然羊肉 ( thinly sliced, cooked just right)
4. 酱菠菜 (hmm, delicate flavor, better than home made).

The noodle was big enough for 2 people to share. I will definitely come back.
author: Kate J.

description: Their food is tasty. Try some of the house special dishes--they're quite authentic. The portions are quite big so order accordingly!
author: Wilson W.

description: Delicious shaanxi food. Noodle dishes has some of the best thick chewy noodles that soak up the aromatic porky oil. I crave this type of food often and previously has to drive down to south bay to get decent version.
author: Sarah L.

description: All bad. The online prices were inaccurate and they don't take cards for orders under 25$ (this is illegal). The food tastes strange and is full of undercooked potatoes. I won't go back.
author: Jessica G.

description:
After returning from a short  trip, my friend and I happen to be in the area so we decided to get a small bite at a this restaurant since my friend has not been here and was in the mood for some dumplings. We got there at around 7:30 pm and we were promptly seated. After a few minutes the waiter brought us some tea and took our orders. We waited and waited.... Then over 30 minutes passed by and our food still hasn't arrived yet and no one even came by to update us on the status of our order. Finally, the  family of 5 who was waiting by the door got seated. I was annoyed when I saw the family of 5 got their appetizer and food before us. Then I had flagged down the waitress to question her about our order. I told her that we had been seated and ordered our food WAY before the family of 5 arrived and they got their food before us. No apologies.... Instead the waitress got defensive and said the reason for the delay is because the kitchen was busy during the time we placed our orders. What BS!!! I would have left but my friend was determined to get his dumplings so we stayed. Finally, after 45 minutes at 8:15 pm our food was brought to our table. 

I do know not to expect much from a Chinese restaurant but I don't think I have EVER waited this long at any Chinese restaurant before. With the fancy restaurant name, well written menu, photos of historic terra cotta soldiers and elegant decor and well thought out specialty dishes,  you would naturally expect to get a little better service. The management and owner should know better. It's almost like displaying a genuine Monet painting on the wall of a Chinese dim sum house.
author: M M.

description: The awful lighting in this place was so distracting that I couldn't really enjoy my food. It was like a fluorescent spotlight right in my eye. Food was good, but not a relaxing setting. Maybe I would order again to go.
author: Renee B.

description: Went with my 6.5 year old son. He said it is "soooooo good."  He was hoping for moo-shu chicken. They only have moo-shu pork and there are no pancakes. We learned the pancakes are an American thing. He enjoyed the moo-shu. Loved the noodles and all things they had.
author: Kevin T.

description: SF Chinese food is surprisingly limited in selection compared to soCal's plethora of Mandarin options. By Mandarin options I mean anything other than the ubiquitous Cantonese fare found all over the city. If you want some proper northern Chinese cuisine like pulled Shanxi noodles to go with your cumin lamb burger then Terra Cotta is where you should park your mouth hole. Parking can be painful at times and the place gets pretty cramped for dinner. $25 min for credit cards. It's a solid four stars but I'm bumping it up to a five because it's not Cantonese.
author: John B.

description: I want to give the place a 5 also but they aren't there yet.  It is a unique style of food.  And it was all very good.  But they have to work out the problems.  It was a little crowded and the food was incredibly slow.  Their system is all messed up.  The staff ends up running around like mad and not getting anything done.  My wife use to own a Chinese restaurant and was tempted to go back and tell them how to fix up their system.  Most importantly the owner just stood around.  When you own one of these places you have to pitch in wherever it is needed.  If they don't work it out all may be lost.
author: v n.

description: Delicious food in a nice relaxing restaurant with attentive staff.  I had the Shanxi noodles which were delicious and spicy.  My husband had the hot and sour soup with pork dumplings which was very good but nothing like the hot and sour soups I am accustomed to.  This was more broth but I loved that you could taste the individual flavors of the ginger, garlic and other ingredients.
author: L C.

description: Great restaurant+authentic food! It's a must if you want some real northern food or if you are into spicy stuff.
author: Joanne X.

description: Xian dishes. Not your typical Chinese dishes. Awesome authentic xian dishes. Was referred here by a co worker who was from Xian. Must try for authentic experience. The mor, the pita bread looking thing with stew meat. The qi Shan minced pork noodle, probably one of the most famous noodle in Northern China. Try it yourself and taste the harmony of the flavors dancing in your mouth.
author: Karakara M.
